An abdominal x-ray shows distended loops of small bowel with air-fluid levels . There is no air in the rectum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Calcification of a bicuspid aortic valv
Myxomatous degeneration of the aortic valve
Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve
Myxomatous degeneration of the tricuspid valve
Rheumatic disease of the mitral valve
Rheumatic disease of the tricuspid valve

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Obstruction of the small bowel occurs from partial or complete blockage of the small bowel lumen and typically presents with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Partial small bowel obstructions will allow a degree of continued flatus with diminished stooling, and complete obstructions will result in obstipation. Small bowel obstruction (SBO) has many potential causes, although the most common are post-surgical peritoneal adhesions and hernias. On physical exam, SBO typically presents with abdominal tenderness, distention, tympany to percussion, and borborygmi (high-pitched, hyperactive bowel sounds). Potential complications of SBO include bowel rupture and/or necrosis, which can result in sudden-onset peritonitic abdominal signs such as rebound tenderness and guarding. Abdominal x-rays typically demonstrate multiple air-fluid levels in the setting of dilated small bowel loops. Management requires bowel rest and intravenous hydration and sometimes surgical intervention. If the patient has a partial obstruction, the patient should be monitored and provided supportive care. If the patient demonstrates features concerning for a complete obstruction, an exploratory laparotomy should be performed to alleviate the cause of the obstruction. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, and E. Cecal volvulus (Choice A) results from twisting of the cecal mesentery and can be a cause of large bowel obstruction. It is less common than sigmoid volvulus and can be associated with a hyper-mobile cecum. lieus (Choice B) refers to intestinal hypomotility without a mechanical obstruction, most commonly occurring following surgery or in the setting of electrolyte abnormalities, and typically presents with diffuse small and large bowel dilatation. Pseudo-obstruction of the colon (Choice D), also known as Ogilvie syndrome, results in dilatation of the large bowel without a mechanical obstruction. It most commonly occurs in elderly patients or patients with severe comorbidities and/or electrolyte derangements. - - r-- r " , r ,

distractor_explanations.B: involves dystrophic calcification of the fibrous annulus of the mitral valve. This increases the risk for development of mitral stenosis, which is evidenced by a diastolic murmur best heard in the left fourth or fifth intercostal space along the midclavicular line. Myxomatous degeneration of the aortic valve (
distractor_explanations.C: , mitral valve (
distractor_explanations.D: , and tricuspid valve (
distractor_explanations.E: can be primarily or secondarily related to an underlying connective tissue disorder (eg, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan syndrome). Myxomatous degeneration increases the risk for regurgitant murmurs of the involved valve. Rheumatic disease of the mitral valve (
distractor_explanations.F: and tricuspid valve (
distractor_explanations.G: may be acute or chronic in nature. Acute rheumatic heart disease is a sequela from infection with group A streptococci and most commonly affects the mitral valve. Acute rheumatic disease can lead to incompetence of the involved valves and late sequelae of chronic rheumatic disease can result in stenosis of the involved valves. Neither mitral nor tricuspid stenosis would result in a systolic murmur in the right second intercostal space. r-- r " , r ,

vignette.presentation:
32. A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive shortness of breath . He now has shortness of breath after walking 200 feet. He coaches a soccer team and is unable to keep up with his
players on the field . He occasionally has wheezing and a nonproductive cough. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His wife resumed smoking 18 months ago after quitting for 3 years . He has three healthy children . His father
died of alcoholic cirrhosis at the age of 55 years . The patient's temperature is 36.9°C (98 .5°F), pulse is 76/min , respirations are 20/min , and blood pressure is 124/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen
saturation of 90%. End-expiratory wheezes and occasional rhonchi are heard bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . An x-ray of the chest shows increased lucency and bullous changes at both
lung bases . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: a -Antitrypsin deficiency results in the early development of panacinar emphysema and liver disease. It is a hereditary disease resulting from misfolding of a -antitrypsin, which aggregates in hepatocytes. This results 1 1 in hepatocyte injury and progression to cirrhosis at a young age. As well, because of the lack of functional a -antitrypsin release into the systemic circulation, there is an imbalance of proteases and anti-proteases in 1 the lung parenchyma, resulting in the destruction of alveolar septa and development of panacinar emphysema. Panacinar emphysema is characterized by emphysematous destructive changes of pulmonary alveolar tissue beginning in bilateral lung bases resulting in bullous changes of the lungs, with the potential to spread diffusely. In patients with a -antitrypsin deficiency, the development of both cirrhosis and panacinar 1 emphysema can occur without significant additional risk factors for each disease.

distractor_explanations.B: commonly occurs in the setting of roofing, plumbing, and shipbuilding. It increases the risk for pulmonary asbestosis, characterized by the development of pleural calcified plaques and potential lower lobe predominant interstitial fibrotic changes, not panacinar emphysema. It also increases the risk for bronchogenic carcinoma and mesothelioma. Exposure to radon (
distractor_explanations.C: is the second leading cause of lung cancer following smoking. Radon occurs naturally in the environment, potentially exposing individuals within their homes, especially the basement. Exposure to secondhand smoke (
distractor_explanations.D: is also a risk factor for the development of lung cancer. This patient presents with symptoms of panacinar emphysema, not lung cancer, which may present with cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. Pulmonary fibrosis (
distractor_explanations.E: has many different causes such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, sarcoidosis, and chemotherapeutics such as bleomycin, and results in a restrictive lung pathology. It typically presents with dyspnea, dry crackles, and shallow breathing, along with symptoms related to the underlying causative pathology. r-- r " , r ,

vignette.presentation:
33. A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever, chills, headache, and joint and muscle pain. She says that she was recently hospitalized in another city for treatment of an
overactive thyroid and was given two medications on discharge . She recalls no further details . Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) , pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/70 mm Hg. Examination
shows lid lag, exophthalmos , a prominent goiter, and a supple neck. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There are no skin or joint abnormalities . Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 45%
Leukocyte count 1400/mm 3
Segmented neutrophils 5%
Lymphocytes 95%
Platelet count 287,000/mm 3
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Drug-induced neutropenia is an adverse effect of both propylthiouracil and methimazole, which are thioamides used in the treatment of hyperthyroidism. The patient exhibits symptoms of hyperthyroidism secondary to Graves disease, including exophthalmos, goiter, and lid lag. Propylthiouracil and methimazole inhibit thyroid peroxidase, while propylthiouracil also inhibits peripheral conversion of T to T by blocking 5'-deiodinase. A 4 3 rare adverse effect of these medications is agranulocytosis, resulting in insufficient production of segmented neutrophils. This results in susceptibility to a variety of infections and increased risk for sepsis in the setting of neutropenic fever. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, and E. Autoimmune neutropenia (Choice A) is a rare hematologic disorder characterized by autoantibody-induced destruction of neutrophils. This patient exhibits symptoms of hyperthyroidism for which she received medication therapy and developed the adverse effect of agranulocytosis. Cyclic neutropenia (Choice B) is a rare disease resulting in recurrent episodes of neutropenia, typically every 3 weeks. Patients can also present with symptoms of lethargy, fever, and mucosal ulcerations. Radioactive iodine-induced neutropenia (Choice D) can occur due to myelosuppressive effects of radioactive iodine, although this is rare given the low doses used for the treatment of hyperthyroidism secondary to Graves disease. The patient received medical therapy for her hyperthyroidism, not radioactive iodine therapy. Thyroid storm (Choice E) is a serious potential complication of hyperthyroidism following an acute stress such as trauma or infection. Characteristic presenting symptoms of thyroid storm include fever, diarrhea, tachyarrhythmia, altered mental status (eg, delirium, agitation), and potential coma or death if not emergently treated. Management requires treatment with intravenous corticosteroids, beta-blocker, propylthiouracil, and potassium iodide. r-- r " , r ,

vignette.presentation:
34. A previously healthy 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of progressive sensory loss . Initially, only her feet felt numb , but the loss of sensation has slowly ascended symmetrically to the
umbilicus . She also has had urinary urgency and frequency , nocturia , and the perception of a tight band-like sensation around her midabdominal region . Examination shows slowing of left eye adduction during saccadic
movement of the eyes to the right. There is diffuse hyperreflexia . Sensation to pinprick is decreased to the level of the umbilicus . The most likely explanation for the slowing of left eye adduction is a lesion at which of the
following sites?

question_stem:
The most likely explanation for the slowing of left eye adduction is a lesion at which of the
following sites?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The left medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) allows for the communication between the right abducens nerve nucleus and left oculomotor nerve nucleus. This allows for the coordinated horizontal movement in the same direction for both eyes. The patient presents with multiple focal neurologic deficits including sensory loss, urinary symptoms, and hyperreflexia. In a younger female, neurologic deficits occurring in separate neurologic pathways over time raises suspicion for multiple sclerosis. The most common lesion affecting the MLF is an inflammatory plaque from multiple sclerosis. A lesion affecting the left MLF would result in impaired left eye adduction during movement of the eyes to the right, due to impaired signal to the left oculomotor nerve nucleus. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Left cerebral hemisphere (Choice A) lesions may result in a variety of neurologic deficits ranging from motor and sensory deficits involving the right side of the body and aphasia, depending on the location of the lesion and the side of the patient's dominant hemisphere. If the lesion involves the left frontal eye fields, the patient would present with conjugate gaze deviation toward the lesion. A lesion within the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) (Choice C) would result in conjugate movement of both eyes away from the side of the lesion. For example, a left PPRF lesion would result in conjugate gaze deviation to the right. Right cerebellar hemisphere (Choice D) lesions would result in ipsilateral extremity ataxia, intention tremors, and loss of balance toward the side of the lesion. Right sixth cranial nerve nucleus lesions (Choice E) would result in loss of motor output to the lateral rectus, resulting in a horizontal gaze palsy characterized by medial ipsilateral eye deviation. r-- r " , r ,

vignette.presentation:
35. A 20-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a severe sore throat , hoarseness , and dysphagia for 8 hours . She appears toxic . Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F) . She has severe pharyngitis and
strider . Laboratory studies show leukocytosis . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Culture and Gram stain of sputum

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Laryngoscopy and endotracheal intubation are the most appropriate initial steps for epiglottitis. Epiglottitis refers to acute infection of the epiglottis. It was commonly caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b prior to widespread pediatric vaccination. Epiglottitis presents with fever and acute severe pharyngitis, drooling, hoarseness, and dysphagia. On lateral neck x-rays, it appears as a "thumbprint sign." Patients typically present in a toxic state and can exhibit rapid respiratory decompensation with the development of strider and airway obstruction. Because of this, first-line therapy is to emergently establish a protected airway through endotracheal intubation. In the setting of epiglottitis, endotracheal intubation should take place in the operating room under direct visualization with a laryngoscope if the patient is stable enough to permit transfer out of the emergency department.

distractor_explanations.A: would evaluate for infection by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, which can present with acute pharyngitis and production of gray oropharyngeal pseudomembranes. Complications of diphtheria include myocarditis and neuropathy. Culture and Gram stain of sputum (
distractor_explanations.B: can be used for the characterization and speciation of respiratory infections. X-ray of the chest (
distractor_explanations.C: is appropriate in the evaluation of primary pulmonary pathology but offers no pertinent findings in acute pharyngitis. Barium swallow (
distractor_explanations.D: evaluates pharyngeal swallowing function and timing and is utilized to evaluate causes of dysphagia. It should not be used to evaluate acute pharyngeal pathology. r-- r " , r ,

vignette.presentation:
36. A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-day history of sore throat , cough , and fever . The cough is nonproductive but keeps her awake at night. She subsequently develops hoarseness . Her temperature
is 38.3°C (100 .9°F). Crackles are heard over the right posterior lower chest. X-rays of the chest show patchy, lower right alveolar infiltrates with increased interstitial markings . Her leukocyte count is 10 ,000/mm 3 with 75%
segmented neutrophils and 1% bands .
Correct Answer: E.
Mycop/asma pneumoniae is the most likely infectious agent for this patient's infection. The patient presents with a fever, nonproductive cough, and crackles along the right posterior lower chest. Her x-ray demonstrates patchy,
lower right alveolar infiltrates along with increased interstitial markings. This constellation of findings is consistent with a community acquired pneumonia secondary to an atypical infection, especially given the patient's young
age. There are a number of viruses and bacteria that can result in the development of an atypical pneumonia, such as Chlamydophi/a pneumoniae, Mycop/asma pneumoniae, Legionella pneumophila, and influenza. The most
common infectious agent for pneumonia in a patient of this age would be Mycop/asma pneumoniae, which is best treated with a macrolide antibiotic.
Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, F, G, H, and I.
Cytomegalovirus (Choice A), also known as human herpesvirus-5 (HHV-5) can be transmitted through multiple modes, including sexual contact, urine, respiratory droplets, and transplacental. It can cause a variety of
presentations, including mononucleosis in immunocompetent patients, and retinitis, infectious esophagitis, and pneumonia in immunocompromised patients.
Haemophilus influenzae (Choice B) is an encapsulated gram-negative bacterium that can result in various mucosal infections such as conjunctivitis, otitis media, bronchitis, and pneumonia. It was the leading cause of
epiglottitis in children prior to widespread immunization.
Klebsiella pneumoniae (Choice C) is also an encapsulated gram-negative bacterium that can present with lobar pneumonia, especially in patients with diabetes mellitus or alcohol use disorder. It can also cause nosocomial
urinary tract infections.
Legionella pneumophila (Choice D) is a gram-negative rod that is transmitted primarily through aerosols from water sources. It can lead to Legionnaires disease, characterized by fever, pneumonia, and gastrointestinal
symptoms. Legionnaires most commonly occurs in chronic smokers or those with chronic underlying lung disease.
Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly P. carinit) (Choice F) is a yeast-like fungus that primarily affects immunosuppressed patients. It results in a bilateral pneumonia consisting of diffuse reticulogranular (ground-glass) opacities on
imaging. Treatment consists of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX), atovaquone, or pentamidine, with TMP-SMX serving as first-line preventive therapy for HIV patients with a CD4+ count less than 200/mm 3
.

vignette.presentation:
37. In September , 5 days after returning from a business trip, a 57-year-old woman develops fever , abdominal cramps , and watery diarrhea followed by a cough 24 hours later. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20
years . Her temperature is 39°C (102 .2°F), and pulse is 90/min . Crackles are heard diffusely over both lung fields . Her leukocyte count is 16,000/mm 3 with a predominance of segmented neutrophils . X-rays of the chest show
alveolar infiltrates in the right upper and lower lobes and in the left lower lobe. Gram stain of sputum shows many segmented neutrophils but no predominant microorganism .
CorrectAnswer: D.
Legionella pneumophila is a gram-negative rod that is transmitted primarily through aerosols from water sources (e.g., air conditioning systems). It can lead to Legionnaires disease, most commonly occurring in patients who
are chronic smokers or have underlying chronic lung disease. Legionnaires disease is characterized by fever, atypical pneumonia, and gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea and abdominal pain. The atypical pneumonia
may appear as diffuse, patchy alveolar and interstitial opacities on lung imaging. It can also be associated with hyponatremia. Additionally, in healthy adults Legionella pneumophila can cause mild flu-like symptoms and a
fever, which is called Pontiac fever. First-line therapy for Legionella pneumophila includes administration of either macrolides or respiratory fluoroquinolones.
Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, E, F, G, H, and I.
Cytomegalovirus (Choice A), also known as human herpesvirus-5 (HHV-5) can be transmitted through multiple modes, including sexual contact, urine, respiratory droplets, and transplacental. It can cause a variety of
presentations, including mononucleosis in immunocompetent patients, and retinitis, infectious esophagitis, and pneumonia in immunocompromised patients.
Haemophilus influenzae (Choice B) is an encapsulated gram-negative bacterium that can result in various mucosal infections such as conjunctivitis, otitis media, bronchitis, and pneumonia. It was the leading cause of
epiglottitis in children prior to widespread immunization.
Klebsiella pneumoniae (Choice C) is also an encapsulated gram-negative bacterium that can present with lobar pneumonia, especially in patients with diabetes mellitus or alcohol use disorder. It can also cause nosocomial
urinary tract infections.
Mycop/asma pneumoniae (Choice E) is a common atypical bacterial cause of community acquired pneumonia in young adults, resulting in the development of alveolar and interstitial infiltrates on chest imaging.
Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly P. carinit) (Choice F) is a yeast-like fungus that primarily affects immunosuppressed patients. It results in a bilateral pneumonia consisting of diffuse reticulogranular (ground-glass) opacities on
imaging. Treatment consists of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX), atovaquone, or pentamidine, with TMP-SMX serving as first-line preventive therapy for HIV patients with a CD4+ count less than 200/mm 3
.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Choice G) is a gram-negative rod that can result in numerous clinical infectious conditions, including urinary tract infections, osteomyelitis, otitis externa, folliculitis, hospital or ventilator-associated
pneumonia, and sepsis.

38. A 19-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of pain with urination and a watery urethral discharge . He has not had fever . He has no history of sexually transmitted diseases . He was sexually active with
a female partner 3 weeks ago and another female partner 2 weeks ago, and he did not use condoms. He is not sure if his partners have had genitourinary symptoms . His temperature is 37 .1 °C (98.8°F) , pulse is 80/min , and
blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg. Examination shows no lymphadenopathy . The penis and testes appear normal. There is a mucopurulent , whitish urethral discharge . Rectal examination shows a normal-sized , nontender
prostate . A Gram stain of the urethral discharge shows segmented neutrophils without intracellular organisms . Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?

question_stem: the most likely causal organism?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Chlamydia trachomatis is a common sexually transmitted disease that can cause various symptoms such as cervicitis, pelvic inflammatory disease, epididymitis, and urethritis. Urethritis secondary to infection from Chlamydia trachomatis typically presents with painful urination and urethral discharge. Gram stain of urine typically demonstrates a sterile pyuria, characterized by the presence of white blood cells without organisms. Diagnosis is achieved through a urine nucleic acid amplification test. Treatment requires administration of either azithromycin or doxycycline in combination with ceftriaxone for the potential of Neisseria gonorrhoeae coinfection.

While commonly a pathogen located in respiratory and oral secretions, it does have the potential for sexual contact transmission leading to genital herpes. HIV-1 (
distractor_explanations.C: is the most common strain of the human immunodeficiency virus, a retrovirus that infects human T cells, resulting in immunosuppression. It is diagnosed through the combination of an ELISA followed by Western blot assay. It can result in an acute HIV syndrome presenting with systemic inflammatory symptoms such as fever, chills, night sweats, fatigue, weight loss, and sore throat. Neisseria gonorrhoeae (
distractor_explanations.D: is a gram-negative diplococcus that can present with various symptoms such as cervicitis, pelvic inflammatory disease, Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, disseminated gonorrhea, septic arthritis, and urethritis. Urethritis secondary to infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically presents with severe mucopurulent discharge, different than the watery discharge from Chlamydia trachomatis. Treponema pallidum (

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Nonketotic hyperosmolar state is a condition of severe hyperglycemia and increased serum osmolality resulting in profound dehydration, without the abnormal production of ketones. This typically occurs in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus after an inciting stress event, such as an acute infection. The increased osmolality results in excessive osmotic diuresis in the kidneys, which leads to progressive, marked dehydration. Presenting symptoms include lethargy, thirst, polyuria, altered mental status, and potential coma and death if untreated. Laboratory values typically demonstrate hyperglycemia (greater than 500 mg/dL), and increased osmolality (greater than 320 mOsm/kg) without acidosis because of the lack of ketone production. Treatment requires aggressive fluid resuscitation with isotonic intravenous fluids and insulin.

distractor_explanations.C: typically occurs in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus following a stress event. It presents with hyperglycemia and high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Lactic acidosis (
distractor_explanations.D: can occur following multiple different causes but most commonly from hypoperfusion states such as septic shock. Anaerobic metabolism results in excessive lactic acid production, which leads to an anion gap metabolic acidosis. r-- r " , r ,

41. A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever, chills, and cough . She had pneumococcal pneumonia 1 year ago . Her temperature is 39°C (102 .2°F). Examination shows bronchial
breath sounds at the right lung base with increased dullness and egophony . Her leukocyte count is 87,000/mm 3 (15% segmented neutrophils, 82% lymphocytes, and 3% monocytes). A Gram stain of sputum shows
gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococci. Which of the following is most likely to confirm this patient's deficit in host defenses?

question_stem: most likely to confirm this patient's deficit in host defenses?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Quantitative immunoglobulin assay is indicated for the evaluation of patients presenting with recurrent infections and findings indicative of a lymphoproliferative disorder. This patient's markedly increased leukocyte count with a predominance of lymphocytes raises concern for lymphocytic leukemia. Given the patient's demographics and history of recurrent infections during the past year, the most likely diagnosis is chronic lymphocytic leukemia {CLL). CLL typically occurs in patients older than age 60 years and is often initially asymptomatic, with the slow progressive development of symptoms such as fatigue, fevers, chills, night sweats, and weight loss. Smudge cells are a characteristic finding on peripheral blood smear, along with marked lymphocytosis on laboratory evaluation. CLL may also result in an increased risk for recurrent sinopulmonary bacterial infections, as the monoclonal propagation of nonfunctional B lymphocytes most commonly results in hypogammaglobulinemia. Patients presenting with a lymphoproliferative disorder and findings concerning for immunodeficiency should undergo a quantitative immunoglobulin assay to assess for hypogammaglobulinemia.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Choledocholithiasis refers to the presence of a gallstone located within the common bile duct. This can result in varying degrees of obstruction, which dictates the severity of presenting symptoms. Obstructive choledocholithiasis results in colicky right upper quadrant or epigastric pain (biliary colic), nausea, vomiting, and increased direct bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase. Direct hyperbilirubinemia can lead to scleral icterus and jaundice. Depending on the location of the common bile duct stone, choledocholithiasis can result in acute pancreatitis, which manifests with epigastric pain and increased pancreatic enzymes (amylase, lipase). If acute bacterial infection of the biliary tree ensues, this can lead to fever and acute cholangitis. The primary treatment for choledocholithiasis is an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with sphincterotomy, followed by cholecystectomy. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, and E. Alcoholism (Choice A) is a common cause of acute pancreatitis, which can result in epigastric pain and increased amylase, although would be unlikely to result in direct hyperbilirubinemia. Cholecystitis (Choice B) results from obstruction of the cystic duct by a gallstone with resultant bacterial infection of the gallbladder, and presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. It would not typically present with increased liver function tests or pancreatic enzymes. Hepatoma (Choice D), also known as hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), can present with right upper quadrant tenderness and hepatomegaly with associated hepatic enzyme (AST/ALT) and a-fetoprotein elevation. The main risk factors for HCC are cirrhosis and chronic hepatitis B infection. Pancreatic carcinoma (Choice E) often presents with nonspecific symptoms such as chronic abdominal pain radiating to the back, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and weight loss. If the pancreatic carcinoma is located in the pancreatic head/neck region, it can result in painless obstructive jaundice. Pancreatic carcinoma would not typically present with acute abdominal pain or increased pancreatic enzymes. r-- r " , r ,

1. A 32-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Six weeks ago, she was diagnosed w ith sinusitis and
began a 10-day course of amoxicillin-clavulanate therapy. She has occasional nonproductive cough ; she otherwise feels well.
During the past 6 years, she has had eight episodes of sinusitis treated with amoxicillin , amoxicillin-clavulanate , and
azithromycin . One episode required a 1-month course of amoxicillin therapy. The patient also has had two episodes of
bacterial pneumonia during the past 3 years that resolved with moxifloxacin therapy. She currently takes no medications . Her
maternal uncle died of pneumonia at the age of 28 years . The patient is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 64 kg (140 lb); BMI
is 24 kg/m 2 Vital signs are within normal limits. Scattered rhonchi are heard over the right lower lung base. The remainder of
.
the examination shows no abnormalities . Results of a complete blood count , liver and kidney function testing , and HIV
antibody serologic testing are within the reference ranges. A CT scan of the paranasa l sinuses shows mucosal thickening of
the maxillary, sphenoid, and ethmoid sinuses . A CT scan of the chest shows bronchial thickening and dilation of the bronchi
in the lower lobe of the right lung. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Recurrent infections, as seen in this patient, raise concern for an underlying primary immunodeficiency. Primary immunodeficiencies may result from abnormalities of acquired immunity (B-cell , T-cell), innate immunity, or combined dysfunction. Specifically, a decreased, absent, or aberrant production of immunoglobulin by B-cells can result in recurrent sinopulmonary infections, leading to multiple recurrent sinus infections and pneumonia, which this patient demonstrates . These recurrent pulmonary infections can lead to the development of bronchiectasis over time . For further differentiation of the patient's primary immunodeficiency, quantitative immunoglobulin testing should be performed to delineate the patient's immunologic pathophysiology. B-cell disorders include such diseases as X-linked agammaglobulinemia, selective lgA deficiency, and common variable immunodeficiency . Given the patient's age and presentation, common variable immunodeficiency is the most likely etiology since it typically presents in early adulthood and characteristically leads to increased sinopulmonary infections.

distractor_explanations.B: is recommended to definitively identify the infectious organism present in the setting of severe and/or persistent pneumonia. Open lung biopsy (
distractor_explanations.C: may be indicated for a variety of clinical scenarios (eg, interstitial lung disease , pulmonary nodule/mass), but is not necessary for the diagnosis of an immunodeficiency. Sputum culture for acid-fast bacilli (
distractor_explanations.E: most commonly is used to evaluate for a mycobacterial infection. "' , r-- ,. ,,,

3. A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because she is concerned about her risk for osteoporosis . She has
hypertension and deep venous thrombosis . Current medications include metoprolol and warfarin . There is no personal or
family history of fractures . She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg. Examina tion shows no
abnormalities . A DEXA scan shows findings consistent with osteoporosis. In addition to calcium and vitamin D
supplementation , which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Osteoporosis is a metabolic bone disease characterized by diffusely low bone density. Evaluation for osteoporosis occurs through performance of a DEXA scan and is defined as a bone mineral density less than 2.5 standard deviations compared to a young, normal population (T-score). The most common risk factors for the development of osteoporosis are age, smoking, chronic inflammatory disease , corticosteroid use, and estrogen-depleting conditions in women. Osteoporosis is often asymptomatic but increases the risk for fractures, most commonly involving the hip, vertebrae, and distal radius. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation are the first line for treatment and prevention of osteoporosis. Reduction of active osteoporotic risk factors should also be pursued . Weight-bearing exercises are recommended to slow deterioration of bone mineral density. Bisphosphonates (eg, alendronate) inhibit osteoclast activity. They are utilized once an individual is diagnosed with osteoporosis to reduce further loss of bone mineral density.

distractor_explanations.B: is a native hormone which inhibits osteoclast activity and reabsorption of calcium within the renal tubules . It is rarely used for the treatment of osteoporosis given its cost and side effect profile, but can be used in the setting of severe, symptomatic hypercalcemia. Estrogen (
distractor_explanations.C: does result in positive bony remodeling, which would in theory lead to increased bone mineral density, although administration of estrogen results in a significantly increased risk for the development of life-threatening venous thrombosis. lsoflavones (
distractor_explanations.D: are postulated to improve postmenopausal symptoms and delay osteoporosis, although there is currently insufficient data on their effectiveness and safety. Raloxifene (
distractor_explanations.E: is a selective estrogen receptor modulator, which acts as an agonist for positive bony remodeling from increased osteoblast activity. It is useful in the prevention of osteoporosis, but due to off-target effects is generally third line following bisphosphonates. ,. "' , r-- ,. ,

and blood pressure is 112/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. There is no

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Discitis-osteomyelitis refers to an acute infection of a vertebral disc and the adjacent vertebral bodies, most commonly secondary to S. aureus. In adults, it most commonly occurs from direct spread from an adjacent soft tissue infection and less likely from hematogenous seeding of bacteria to that site. In children and intravenous drug users, hematogenous seeding is more common given the propensity for bacteremia and distant seeding of the bacteria to the involved site. In intravenous drug users, S. aureus and Pseudomonas are the two most common pathogens. On imaging, discitis-osteomyelitis can present with destructive changes of the vertebral bone with collapse of the disc space. Given the patient has a systolic murmur and fever in the setting of intravenous drug use, there is the potential he may have infective endocarditis, which would serve as a source of hematogenous bacterial seeding to the vertebral column.

Reactivation of a latent organism (
distractor_explanations.E: may refer to any number of various infectious processes (eg, reactivation tuberculosis, herpes simplex viruses), although this patient's discitis-osteomyelitis is related to intravenous drug use and possible infective endocarditis with subsequent hematogenous seeding . ,. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: There are a number of modifiable risk factors that lead to an increased risk for cerebral infarction . Among these, hypertension remains the largest risk factor because of its consequent ability to result in vascular remodeling and progression of atherosclerotic disease. While ideal blood pressure targets remain controversial, a blood pressure of >140/90 has been shown to significantly increase a patient's risk of stroke. Additionally, the patient in the vignette demonstrates consequences of chronic hypertension including an S heart 4 sound, possibly indicating left ventricular hypertrophy and a resultant stiff ventricular wall . Given the patient's elevated blood pressure and its known relationship with significantly increased risk of stroke, the patient would most benefit from appropriate antihypertensive therapy to decrease his future risk of cerebral infarction.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage most often presents from a ruptured intracranial aneurysm in the setting of hypertension. These are often "berry" aneurysms in the Circle of Willis, and typically occur with a "thunderclap" worst-headache-of-life, neck stiffness, and photophobia. The aneurysm rupture may have been precipitated by an event increasing her mean arterial pressure, which would increase stress on the aneurysmal vascular wall. Lumbar puncture demonstrates a significant number of red blood cells, which are typical in the setting of subarachnoid hemorrhage. A CT scan of the head without contrast is typically obtained in the acute setting to confirm the presence of subarachnoid blood, and if confirmed, further angiographic imaging of the head is necessary to identify the presence of an aneurysm.

distractor_explanations.D: classically presents with an acute headache, fever, photophobia, and neck stiffness, with variable etiologies from bacterial, viral, or fungal sources. Leukocytes would be elevated on cerebrospinal fluid analysis. Migraine headaches (
distractor_explanations.E: characteristically recur over time and may present with a pulsatile, unilateral, or bilateral headache with associated photophobia or phonophobia. They are often triggered by foods, medications, noises, menses, or illness. ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

medications . Her pulse is 70/min , and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Examination shows mild edema and prominent
varicose veins of the distal left lower extremity . There is an 8-cm area of hyperpigmentation over the left ankle. Examination
of the right lower extremity shows no abnormalities . Peripheral pulses are normal. Ultrasonography of the lower extremities
shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient 's edema?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient 's edema?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Valvular insufficiency is a common complication of deep venous thrombosis. As a thrombus occludes the cross-sectional area of a deep vein, the valves, which originate from the walls of the veins, become involved in the thrombus either through compression against the wall of the vessel or through incorporation into the thrombus during propagation. When the thrombus resolves, the residual valve may be dysfunctional from damage to the leaflets, annulus, or diameter of the native vessel. This prevents the valve from functioning effectively and results in retrograde venous flow secondary to gravity. Inadequate venous drainage of the lower extremities can result in varicose veins, chronic edema, and stasis dermatitis.

distractor_explanations.A: is characterized by inflammation in the skin and demonstrates erythema, induration, warmth, and edema . Most commonly, it is acute and results from a bacterial infection of the skin . Obstruction of the iliac vein (
distractor_explanations.B: would present with edema of the entire left lower extremity as opposed to the calf in isolation . Further, the patient's ultrasound was normal, without evidence of an obstruction. On duplex ultrasound, the iliac vessels would not necessarily be visualized, although doppler venous waveforms can suggest a proximal obstruction if present. Obstruction of lymph channels (
distractor_explanations.C: results in nonpitting edema of the affected extremity, though would be less likely given the patient's anatomically correlated history of a deep venous thrombosis and lack of infectious (eg, filariasis), surgical, malignant, or traumatic history to explain injury to the lymphatic system. Saphenous vein reflux (
distractor_explanations.D: could explain lower extremity edema and varicose vein development; however, it is a superficial vein and this patient has no known history of thrombosis or structural damage to it. ,. "' , r-- ,. ,

vignette.presentation:
9. A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of severe left ear pain. At the onset of pain, he
flushed his ear with water ; the pain has become increasingly severe since then . He has no history of ear problems . He has a
30-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus poorly controlled with insulin . Examination shows moist debris and edema of the
left ear canal. Granulation tissue is seen on the floor of the ear canal. Laboratory studies show :
Leukocyte count 18,000/mm 3
Segmented neutrophils 78%
Lymphocytes 22%
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 100 mm/h
Serum glucose 450 mg/dL
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Necrotizing otitis externa refers to infection of the external ear canal typically from Pseudomonas or Enterobacteriaceae, which both thrive in moist environments. It is frequently seen in patients with poorly controlled diabetes and immunocompromised states. Classically, it presents with external ear pain exacerbated with movement of the tragus or pinna, purulent discharge, and an edematous/erythematous external ear canal often containing granulation tissue. When the infection is severe and has infiltrated outside the external ear canal causing extensive tissue destruction, it is termed necrotizing (or malignant) otitis externa, which requires treatment with intravenous antibiotics. Otitis externa is not always necrotizing. The non-necrotizing variant is commonly known as "swimmer's ear," and presents with mild external ear pain, watery discharge, swelling, and erythema of the external acoustic meatus. Treatment of non-necrotizing otitis externa consists of adequately cleaning the ear, acidifying the canal, and administering fluoroquinolone (ciprofloxacin or ofloxacin) ear drops.

distractor_explanations.A: presents with erythema and tenderness posterior to the ear, over the mastoid bone. It often results as a complication from otitis media. Acute otitis media (
distractor_explanations.B: classically occurs in children, often from viral or bacterial pathogens. It presents with ear pain, often with fever, and with an erythematous tympanic membrane with retrotympanic pus or middle ear effusion. Angiocentric T-cell lymphoma (
distractor_explanations.C: is a rare cutaneous malignancy often involving natural killer cells, and typically presents as single or multiple plaques/nodules, which can sometimes ulcerate. Chronic otitis media with effusion (
distractor_explanations.D: presents with chronic middle ear pain and a retrotympanic effusion, a feature not seen on this patient's exam. Fungal otitis externa (
distractor_explanations.E: would present similarly to this patient's exam but would be less likely than a bacterial cause ; it may be more likely subacute and indolent. ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

vignette.presentation:
10. A previously healthy 57-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of a 3-week history of increasing fatigue,
constipation, urinary frequency, and increased thirst. She appears lethargic . Her pulse is 116/min, and blood pressure is
150/70 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes . Serum studies show a calcium concentration of 15.2 mg/dl ,
phosphorus concentration of 2.1 mg/dl , and parathyroid hormone concentration of 800 pg/ml. Which of the following is the
most likely explanation for this patient's polyuria and volume depletion?

question_stem: most likely explanation for this patient's polyuria and volume depletion?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Primary hyperparathyroidism results in hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia secondary to the aberrant increased production of parathyroid hormone (PTH). The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a parathyroid adenoma, with parathyroid hyperplasia and carcinoma additional possibilities. Common symptoms of primary hyperparathyroidism are secondary to the patient's resultant hypercalcemia and include recurrent nephrolithiasis, bone pain from osseous resorption, polyuria, dehydration, constipation, and psychiatric disturbances. Polyuria and associated volume depletion are secondary to the direct effects of hypercalcemia on the kidney, which results in renal resistance and lack of response to anti-diuretic hormone (ADH), known as nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. The resistance to ADH results in insufficient aquaporin expression in the collecting tubules of renal nephrons, leading to increased urine volume, which manifests clinically as polyuria and volume depletion.

distractor_explanations.A: results in pyuria (predominantly eosinophils) and azotemia often related to the use of certain classes of medications such as diuretics, penicillins, proton pump inhibitors, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and sulfonamides. Central diabetes insipidus (
distractor_explanations.B: results in polyuria and volume depletion secondary to insufficient production of ADH from a brain injury or lesion. Chronic pyelonephritis (
distractor_explanations.C: often occurs in patients prone to recurrent episodes of acute pyelonephritis, with risk factors such as chronic obstructing renal stones or vesicoureteral reflux. Glycosuria (
distractor_explanations.D: refers to glucose in the urine, often in patients with hyperglycemia secondary to diabetes mellitus. Hypertensive nephropathy (
distractor_explanations.E: is a common cause of chronic renal failure, resulting from glomerular damage from chronic hypertension. ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

Decreased absorption due to decreased serum magnesium concentration
Decreased absorption due to increased serum ionized calcium concentration
Increased calcium binding by phosphate in the small bowel
Increased suppression of parathyroid hormone due to increased serum ionized phosphorus concentration

vignette.presentation:
13. A47-year-old man with alcoholism is transferred from the hospital to a drug rehabilitation facility. On arrival, examination
shows hyperreflexia and a tremor in both hands when they are outstretched . His serum calcium concentration is 8.1 mg/dl.
Which of the following is the most likely additional serum electrolyte abnormality in this patient?

question_stem: the most likely additional serum electrolyte abnormality in this patient?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Patients with alcohol use disorder often develop multiple vitamin, mineral, and electrolyte deficiencies due to malnutrition from lower dietary intake and the concomitant diuretic effect of alcohol, leading to excessive urinary losses. This patient's examination demonstrates neurologic symptoms, including hyperreflexia and tremor in the setting of alcoholism. Magnesium deficiency is common in patients with alcoholism and often presents with hyperreflexia and tremor. Additional symptoms of magnesium deficiency can include seizures, muscle spasms, and dysrhythmias (eg, Torsades de Pointes).

distractor_explanations.A: infrequently occurs in isolation, and when present, is usually associated with imbalances in sodium, acid-base, or volume status . Most patients do not have symptoms of hypochloremia independent of the presenting condition, such as dehydration from diarrhea, vomiting, or central nervous system symptoms associated with concomitant hyponatremia. Hypokalemia (
distractor_explanations.B: , while often occurring in alcoholism, presents commonly with cardiac conduction abnormalities, such as acquired long-QT syndrome or dysrhythmias, but does not typically present with peripheral neurologic deficits. Hyponatremia {
distractor_explanations.D: is often asymptomatic if chronic and slowly developing, although when acute, it is associated with central nervous system symptoms such as headache, nausea, vomiting, confusion, delirium, weakness, seizures, and coma. Hypophosphatemia (
distractor_explanations.E: can occur in the setting of nutritional deficiency, especially anorexia nervosa or bulimia. Symptoms result from depletion of adenosine triphosphate and include muscle weakness, cardiorespiratory depression, and neurologic depression such as seizure or coma. ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

14. A previously healthy 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of frequent pain with urination
and episodes of loss of urine . She has no history of similar symptoms , and she has not had pelvic pain or change in bowel
function. Menses occur at regular intervals and last 4 days; her last menstrual period was 10 days ago. Vital signs are
within normal limits . Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. The external genitalia , vagina , and cervix appear
normal. There is no cervical motion or uterine tenderness , but the bladder is tender to palpation . Which of the following is
the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: is used for the treatment of bladder and bowel incontinence. The S2-S4 nerve roots are modulated to allow for

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Urinary tract infections (UTls) affect women more frequently than men and may present with lower and/or upper urinary tract symptoms. Lower urinary tract symptoms include increased urinary frequency, urgency, suprapubic pain, and dysuria. Upper urinary tract symptoms include flank pain, costophrenic angle tenderness, and systemic signs/symptoms such as fevers and rigors. Diagnosis of a lower urinary tract infection should be made based on clinical symptoms and supported by increased leukocyte esterase and nitrites on urinalysis along with growth of culprit organisms on urine culture. Uncomplicated UTls should be treated with nitrofurantoin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole , cephalexin, or a fluoroquinolone depending on local sensitivity and resistance patterns. Criteria for a complicated UTI, which would require longer courses of antibiotics, include male gender, urinary obstruction, renal transplant, recent urinary tract instrumentation, or the presence of a urinary catheter.

distractor_explanations.B: is an anti-muscarinic medication used to treat urge incontinence from an overactive bladder and detrusor instability. Intermittent self-catheterization (
distractor_explanations.C: is utilized for the treatment of overflow incontinence from incomplete emptying secondary to detrusor underactivity or bladder outlet obstruction. Catheterization increases the risk of urinary tract infection , although intermittent self catheterization imparts less risk than an indwelling Foley or suprapubic catheter. Sacral nerve stimulation (
distractor_explanations.D: is used for the treatment of bladder and bowel incontinence. The S2-S4 nerve roots are modulated to allow for improved voiding, as these play a crucial role in the autonomic regulation of micturition . The midurethral sling procedure (
distractor_explanations.E: is used to treat stress incontinence and entails a surgical procedure utilizing synthetic mesh to support the urethra . ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

This patient demonstrates a microcytic anemia (MCV < 80 µm 3 common etiologies of which include iron deficiency, anemia of ), chronic disease, thalassemia, and sideroblastic anem ia. Her fraction of hemoglobin A is abnormally elevated, 2 suggestive of an impairment in heme synthesis and diagnostic of beta-thalassemia trait.

vignette.presentation:
16. A 27-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of irregular menses. During this time,
she has had vaginal spotting so frequently that she does not know the dates of her actual menstrual periods . Previously,
menses occurred at regular 28-day intervals. She also reports increased hair growth over the face , chest , and lower
abdomen . She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications . Her blood pressure is 120/60 mm Hg. Physical
examination shows coarse hair over the upper lip, chin, and abdomen . Abdominal and pelvic examinations show no
abnormalities. Her serum dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate concentration is 75 µg/ml (N=0.5-5.4 ). An overnight
dexamethasone suppression test shows no suppression of cortisol. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step
in management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate next step
in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cushing syndrome is characterized by excess production of cortisol. This results in symptoms such as oligomenorrhea, hirsutism, weight gain, skin changes, osteoporosis, and hyperglycemia. Non-suppression of cortisol on overnight dexamethasone suppression test is diagnostic of Cushing syndrome . There are multiple potential etiologies of Cushing syndrome, including pituitary adenoma, adrenal tumor, or ectopic paraneoplastic ACTH secretion (eg, small-cell lung cancer). Along with the increased production of cortisol, Cushing syndrome from an adrenal etiology can also result in increased concentrations of dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEA-S) produced within the zona reticularis of the adrenal cortex. Elevated DHEA-S can also occur in the setting of adrenocortical carcinoma and adrenal hyperplasia. Given the increased DHEA-S , the likely etiology is localized to the adrenal gland. To further assess the patient's pathologic production of cortisol, a CT scan of the abdomen would be the

distractor_explanations.A: would be inaccurate for the evaluation and diagnosis of Cushing syndrome. Serum potassium concentration (
distractor_explanations.B: is variable in the setting of Cushing syndrome and may be within normal limits or mildly decreased. This is secondary to cortisol's mild affinity for mineralocorticoid receptors (eg, aldosterone) in the kidney, resulting in increased excretion of potassium in the urine. The patient's irregular menses are explained by excessive cortisol and DHEA-S from Cushing syndrome, which does not require ultrasound of the pelvis for further investigation (
distractor_explanations.C: , as the etiology is likely secondary to an adrenal process in this instance . MRI of the brain (
distractor_explanations.E: is useful for evaluation of intracranial pathology, including pituitary adenomas. Given the patient's elevated DHEA-S, the etiology for the patient's elevated cortisol is likely within the adrenal gland, not the pituitary gland . ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

vignette.presentation:
17. A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of increasing fatigue, weakness, malaise , and
darkening of his skin. During this period, he has had a 9-kg (20-lb) weight loss. He now has difficulty rising from a chair or
climbing stairs . He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years . He appears cachectic . His blood pressure is
160/98 mm Hg while sitting . Examination shows hyperpigmentation of the skin and proximal muscle wasting and mild pitting
edema at the ankles . His hemoglobin concentration is 11 .5 g/dl , serum potassium concentration is 3.0 mEq/L, and serum
glucose concentration is 130 mg/dl. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Small cell carcinoma of the lung

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The combination of the patient's history of smoking, weight loss, fatigue, weakness, and cachexia is suggestive of an underlying malignancy. Small-cell carcinoma of the lung is associated with multiple paraneoplastic endocrine, neurologic, dermatologic , and musculoskeletal syndromes . This patient has developed paraneoplastic Cushing syndrome, marked by proximal muscle wasting, hyperpigmentation, hypertension, edema, elevated blood glucose, and hypokalemia due to an elevation in adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) leading to chronic adrenal hyperstimulation and unregulated, overproduction of cortisol. In small-cell lung cancer, the ACTH is typically released ectopically from the malignancy itself.

distractor_explanations.A: presents with hypotension , hypothermia, hypoglycemia, weakness, and variable metabolic and acid-base derangements , depending on the level (primary vs. secondary) of the lesion. Bronchial carcinoid (
distractor_explanations.B: is a less likely cause of pulmonary malignancy as compared with small-cell carcinoma and presents with syndromes related to neurotransmitter excess such as flushing, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Hemochromatosis (
distractor_explanations.C: results in excessive iron levels and presents with hepatic, cardiac, and renal failure in addition to hyperpigmentation. Hyperthyroidism (
distractor_explanations.D: can present with weight loss, hair loss, tachycardia, tachypnea, diarrhea, diaphoresis, and muscle wasting and weakness, however it is not as likely a cause as lung cancer in a cachectic patient who smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years . ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

changes in bowel movements , diarrhea, or blood in the stool. She has a 2-year history of pruritus. She has hypertension
treated with hydrochlorothiazide . She has no known allergies . Her mother has Graves disease , her sister has systemic
lupus erythematosus , and a paternal uncle has hemochromatosis . Her pulse is 80/min and regular, respirations are
14/min, and blood pressure is 120/85 mm Hg. Examination shows excoriations over the upper and lower extremities and

in the gallbladder and mild splenomegaly. Which of the following is most likely to suggest the diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Primary biliary cirrhosis is an autoimmune disease of the biliary tree resulting in destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts. It often affects middle-aged women. Because of disordered biliary excretion, it classically presents with jaundice, pruritus, hypercholesterolemia, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies. It is associated with a positive serum antimitochondrial antibody, although biopsy is needed for definitive diagnosis. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the first-line therapy, improving biliary excretion, but liver transplantation may be necessary in progressive, severe disease.

distractor_explanations.E: are used to evaluate the gallbladder, which, when inflamed or obstructed, presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting , anorexia, or diarrhea. This patient is symptomatic with multiple biliary laboratory abnormalities (eg, bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase), and, therefore, further diagnostic steps are required to guide therapy (

19. A 25-year-old man comes to the physician 1 day after noticing pink-tinged urine. Two days ago, he had an upper respiratory
tract infection with a nonproductive , hacking cough ; his symptoms are now resolved . He has not had pain , fever, or chills .
He has no history of serious illness . Current medications include over-the-counter cough syrup . He does not smoke , drink
alcohol , or use illicit drugs . His temperature is 37.1°C (98.?°F) , pulse is 72/min , respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure
is 114/68 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities . Urinalysis shows a pH of 5.5, 4+ blood, and greater than
50 RBC/hpf. His serum creatinine concentration is 1.1 mg/dl, and serum complement concentration is within the reference
range. Ultrasonography of the kidneys and bladder shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely
diagnosis?

question_stem:
the most likely

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: lgA nephropathy (Berger disease) is a type of nephritic syndrome resulting in episodic gross hematuria often following an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. On urinalysis, there will be a significant quantity of red blood cells (RBCs) and the possibility for RBC cast formation. Serum complement levels, including C3, are typically normal, which differentiates lgA nephropathy from postinfectious glomerulonephritis, which results in low serum C3 complement. Additionally, anti-streptolysin O and anti-DNase titers will be negative in lgA nephropathy.

distractor_explanations.A: refers to inflammation of the urinary bladder, which most commonly is secondary to an acute bacterial urinary tract infection. A typical infectious cystitis presents with increased urinary white blood cells, with elevated leukocyte esterase and possibly elevated nitrites depending on the infectious organism. It does not typically follow an upper respiratory infection, and hematuria may be variably present. Nongonococcal urethritis (
distractor_explanations.C: is typically secondary to infection from Chlamydia trachomatis and presents with characteristic findings on gram stain of numerous neutrophils but no bacteria (sterile pyuria). Postinfectious glomerulonephritis {
distractor_explanations.D: is a nephritic syndrome presenting with urinary RBCs and RBC casts, which typically occurs 2-6 weeks after infection with group A beta-hemolytic streptococci. On laboratory examination, it demonstrates low serum C3 levels, and positive anti-streptolysin O and anti-DNase titers. Renal cell carcinoma (

Diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma typically occurs with contrast-enhanced CT or MRI and is confirmed by biopsy at the time of nephrectomy. ,. "' , r-- ,. ,

vignette.presentation:
20. An 82-year-old man with metastatic lung cancer is brought to the emergency department by his children because he has
been unresponsive for the past 24 hours. His family reports that he has become increasingly sleepy and confused over the
past 2 weeks. His lung cancer was diagnosed 3 years ago and initially treated with palliative radiation therapy to his chest
and right femur. Nine months ago, he and his oncologist agreed to discontinue treatment. He has had a 16-kg (35-lb) weight
loss over the past 9 months . He has lived in his son's house for the past 6 months and has received palliative care only. The
patient has an advance directive indicating that he does not want lifesaving treatment , and the son has stated that his father
recently confirmed these wishes verbally. His daughter, who lives out of state , disagrees with the plan to provide palliative
care at home only and is concerned about her father's weight loss. After a family meeting, both siblings now request that the
physician switch to an aggressive treatment plan. The patient appears cachectic but well groomed . He responds to painful
stimuli only. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 52 kg (115 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m 2 His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F),
•
pulse is 122/min, respirations are 34/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 85/50 mm Hg. Serum studies show:
Na+ 142 mEq/L
Ca2+ 13.2 mg/dl
Creatinine 2.8 mg/dl
Albumin 3 g/dl
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Perform lifesaving measures until the family issues can be resolved

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Advance directives are formal specifications of a patient's wishes, created and executed during a time of decision-making capacity. They are enacted when the patient loses capacity to communicate preferences about healthcare wishes . Often, these documents govern end-of-life care, and are commonly used in cases of terminal illness, with late-stage malignancy a very common time of use. Advance directives should reflect a patient's wishes as expressed during periods of stable values and preferences, and the medicolegal strength of an advance directive is greater when family members or persons who know the patient corroborate the document's accurate reflection of long-standing and stable wishes. In this case, this patient had an advance directive written and prepared for use in such a case, and his son, who lives locally and seems to know the patient and his preferences , corroborates what his father would have wanted. Following the advance directive is the most appropriate course of action, while showing compassion and empathy to the family.

The patient's wishes are clearly stated in his advance directive, and there is no evidence that the patient's wishes for himself have changed since the time of drafting and execution. The patient has clearly stated that he does not want lifesaving measures (
distractor_explanations.D: , and he and his oncology team had also agreed that aggressive care (

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Sarcoidosis is an immune-mediated systemic disease resulting in formation of noncaseating granulomas in a variety of involved organs. It is most common in African American females and is often asymptomatic except for lymphadenopathy, with radiographs potentially demonstrating bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and reticulonodular opacities of bilateral lungs. Granulomatous inflammation can result in autonomous production of 1-alpha-hydroxylase , which converts 25-hydroxy-vitamin D3 to the active form 1,25- dihydroxy-vitamin D3. This granulomatous expression of the enzyme results in an increased production of active vitamin D3, which leads to increased intestinal absorption of calcium, resulting in hypercalcemia. This vitamin D3- dependent hypercalcemia results in physiologic suppression of parathyroid hormone. Glucocorticoids are the first line therapy for sarcoidosis, which are utilized to suppress the granulomatous inflammation characteristic of the disease.

distractor_explanations.C: treats symptomatic cancer-associated hypercalcemia through inhibition of osteoclast activity. Plicamycin (
distractor_explanations.E: inhibits RNA synthesis, serving as an anti-neoplastic antibiotic , and is rarely used for the treatment of hypercalcemia. Dialysis (
distractor_explanations.F: is utilized for the removal of excess solutes, toxins, and/or water from patients in emergent settings of acute renal failure or chronic end-stage renal disease. Dialysis may be indicated in cases of severe hypercalcemia, where native renal clearance mechanisms will be insufficient or inappropriately slow. Parathyroidectomy (
distractor_explanations.G: is indicated for the treatment of hypercalcemia caused by primary hyperparathyroidism . ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

There is no peripheral edema . His fasting serum glucose concentration is 130 mg/dL , and fasting serum cholesterol
concentration is 270 mg/dl. An x-ray of the chest shows mild cardiomegaly and Kerley B lines. An ECG shows left
ventricular hypertrophy. Echocardiography shows a thickened left ventricle and an ejection fraction of 40% without
segmental wall abnormalities . Which of the following is most likely to have prevented the echocardiographic findings?

choices.text: Adequate control of serum glucose concentrations

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hypertension is a common cause of chronic systolic and diastolic left-sided heart failure and is considered a modifiable risk factor. This patient's history, signs, symptoms, and exam findings are consistent with chronic left-sided heart failure. Given the lack of an elevated jugular venous pulse, it is unlikely the patient has developed right-sided heart failure. On echocardiography, the patient has a reduced ejection fraction, indicative of systolic heart failure. On physical exam, there is an S gallop with evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy on 4 electrocardiogram , which indicates diastolic heart failure. Additionally, his chest x-ray demonstrates evidence of pulmonary edema (eg, Kerley B lines), a consequence of left-sided heart failure. Adequate control of blood pressure decreases afterload and reduces the degree of cardiac myocyte hypertrophy, which decreases the risk of developing heart failure .

distractor_explanations.B: reduces the risk of microvascular complications of diabetes mellitus, such as retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy. Evidence for tight glucose control as a means of significantly reducing macrovascular complications from diabetes mellitus is less clear. Beta-adrenergic agonist therapy (
distractor_explanations.C: is the appropriate treatment for obstructive lung disease such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or moderate persistent asthma. Low-cholesterol diet (
distractor_explanations.D: would assist in the treatment of hypercholesterolemia, a modifiable risk factor, reducing the likelihood of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. This would reduce his risk for coronary artery disease, with a less direct impact on his risk for developing chronic heart failure . Smoking cessation (
distractor_explanations.E: is a modifiable risk factor in the reduction of cardiovascular and pulmonary disease, although uncontrolled hypertension imparts greater relative risk in this case. ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

vignette.presentation:
23. A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the onset of severe chest pressure and nausea . He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications . He has smoked three packs of
cigarettes daily for 20 years . He is employed as a truck driver and has a sedentary lifestyle . He appears anxious and diaphoretic . He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 107 kg (235 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m 2 His pulse is 44/min
•
and regular , and blood pressure is 160/94 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities . Peripheral pulses are normal. An ECG is shown . Which of the following is the most likely cardiac rhythm?

question_stem: the most likely cardiac rhythm?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Complete heart block is characterized on an ECG by complete dissociation of P waves from the QRS complex. This ECG shows an inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction. The inferior wall of the heart and the atrioventricular (AV) node often share a common blood supply from the right coronary artery (RCA). When the RCA is blocked, infarction of both the inferior wall and the AV node can occur, which can lead to an AV block with a junctional escape rhythm. In normal sinus rhythm, there is a one-to-one relationship between the P wave and QRS complex, which is not seen in the setting of complete heart block. In fact, there is no relationship between the P and QRS frequencies, with each maintaining its own unique, separate rate per minute. This ECG shows an escape rhythm; the R-R interval is constant and the QRS complex is narrow suggesting a pacer focus located in the common bundle or just distal to the AV node within the His-Purkinje system.

distractor_explanations.B: results in a prolonged P-R interval, defined as greater than 200 milliseconds. While this ECG shows some PR intervals greater than 200 milliseconds, the absence of a consistent P-QRS relationship indicates complete heart block. Mobitz type I (Wenckebach type) block {
distractor_explanations.C: is diagnosed when the PR interval progressively lengthens, resulting in a non-conducted beat and resultant absence of the corresponding QRS. Following a short pause, the cycle begins again, resulting in a phenomenon on ECG known as "grouped beating." Mobitz type II block {
distractor_explanations.D: is seen as a consistent P-R interval; however, a number of normal beats are followed by a dropped QRS (a non-conducted P wave). This occurs in a discrete ratio, often three-to-two or two-to-one. Sinus bradycardia {
distractor_explanations.E: is characterized by a one-to-one ratio of P to QRS, with a ventricular rate less than 60 beats per minute. r-- r " , r ,

vignette.presentation:
24. A previously healthy 25-year-old graduate student comes to the physician because of numbness of her left leg, stiffness of
her right leg, and urinary urgency. Examination shows increased tone and deep tendon reflexes in the right lower extremity.
Babinski sign is present on the right. Sensation to pinprick is decreased over the left lower extremity and below the level of
T9 on the left. Sensation to vibration and proprioception is intact. Gait testing shows stiffness and circumduction of the right
lower extremity . This patient is most likely to have a lesion at which of the following locations?

question_stem: most likely to have a lesion at which of the following locations?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: A lesion within the spinal cord can result in injury to a single or multiple spinal cord tracts. This can lead to asymmetric physical exam findings depending on the location of the lesion. Fine touch (pinprick) and temperature are transmitted by the anterolateral spinothalamic (ALS) tract. Motor function is carried along the lateral corticospinal tract (CST). Sensation of vibration and proprioception are transmitted along the dorsal columns-medial lemniscus pathway (DC-ML). A lesion located within the anterior and lateral fascicles of the spinal cord white matter would result in injury to the ALS tract and lateral CST. This would result in contralateral loss of fine touch and temperature perception since the primary sensory neuron for the ALS tract decussates within the spinal cord along the ventral white commissure, followed by ascent within the anterolateral tract of the spinal cord. Additionally, there would be findings of ipsilateral motor weakness as motor decussation occurs in the brain stem. With injury to the lateral CST, the patient would manifest upper motoneuron exam findings such as spasticity, hyperreflexia, and Babinski sign.

distractor_explanations.A: typically result in ipsilateral loss of cranial nerve function (variable depending on the location within the brain stem) and contralateral loss of long-tract spinal cord function (ie, CST, ALS , or DC-ML) . For example, a lesion within the lateral medulla results in Wallenberg syndrome , manifesting with ipsilateral loss of sensation to the face and contralateral body, along with additional cranial nerve symptomatology such as dysphagia, hoarseness, and decreased gag reflex . A lesion within the cerebral hemisphere (
distractor_explanations.B: would result in a contralateral focal neurologic deficit dependent on the location of the lesion. Lesions within the cerebral hemisphere do not result in bilateral asymmetric neurologic exam findings. Peripheral nerve lesions (
distractor_explanations.C: result in symptoms (lower motoneuron weakness, paresthesias, and numbness) within a specific dermatome or peripheral nerve distribution (eg, radial nerve). Conversion reaction (
distractor_explanations.E: , also referred to as functional neurologic symptom disorder, can result in loss of motor or sensory function that cannot be explained by a physical illness or injury. Patients are often aware of the symptoms but indifferent about their significance ("/a belle indifference'). ,. "' , r-- r ,,,
