25. A 38-year-old African American man with accelerated hypertension is admitted to the hospital. His blood pressure is
230/130 mm Hg and he has grade 111 retinopathy. Serum creatinine concentration is 3. 7 mg/dl. Antihypertensive therapy is
begun. Twenty-four hours later he develops oliguria, and 5 days later his serum creatinine concentration increases to
6.8 mg/dl. He has substernal chest pain and a pericardia! friction rub. Which of the following is the most likely underlying
cause of the pericardia! disease?

question_stem:
the most likely underlying
cause of the pericardia! disease?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Uremia can present with nausea, asterixis, encephalopathy, platelet dysfunction, and pericarditis. This patient's presentation is consistent with uremic pericarditis in the setting of acute renal failure, as a result of uncontrolled hypertension. Accelerated hypertension (now known as hypertensive emergency) is defined as an abrupt, significant increase in blood pressure resulting in end-organ damage. The brain, retina, heart, vasculature, and kidneys are commonly affected , in this case reflected by vision changes in the setting of acute hypertension. Acutely increased blood pressure can result in end-organ damage to the kidney secondary to glomerular and arteriolar injury, which can sometimes be worsened by abrupt antihypertensive therapy. If severe enough, oliguria with an associated rise in serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen can result, leading to symptoms and signs of uremia.

distractor_explanations.A: relates to systemic genetic and autoimmune connective tissue diseases such as Alport syndrome, systemic sclerosis, systemic lupus erythematosus, Marfan syndrome, or Ehlers Danlos syndrome . All of these conditions would be expected to present with a different constellation of symptoms, some of which have the potential for acute renal failure, but typically this is superimposed on the chronic disease state. Pericarditis related to an infection is common, although this patient demonstrates neither signs of infection nor preceding history (eg, fever, viral prodrome) making pyogenic infection (
distractor_explanations.B: , tuberculosis (
distractor_explanations.C: , and viral infection (
distractor_explanations.E: unlikely, especially given the temporal relation of the patient's accelerated hypertension to renal failure and pericarditis. ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

vignette.presentation:
26. A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine follow-up examination. She has mild, intermittent asthma treated
with an albuterol inhaler as needed . During the past 3 weeks, she has had three to four weekly episodes of shortness of
breath and wheezing that resolve with use of the inhaler. She has never required intubation for asthma . She is otherwise
asymptomatic . She has no other history of serious illness and takes no other medications . There are no known sick
contacts . Her temperature is 36 .?°C (98°F) , pulse is 88/min , respirations are 16/min , and blood pressure is 118/64 mm Hg.
Wheezes are heard bilaterally. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate
next step in pharmacotherapy?

question_stem:
the most appropriate
next step in pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: Increase the dosage of albuterol to four times daily

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Asthma is characterized by reversible obstruction of the bronchi secondary to hyperreactivity and airway inflammation . Patients present with episodes of wheezing, dry cough, and dyspnea . On physical examination, wheezes are heard, and there is sometimes a component of prolonged expiration relative to inspiration. Chest radiographs are typically normal. Pulmonary function tests may be normal between symptomatic exacerbations but during such episodes demonstrate an obstructive pattern with increased residual volume and total lung capacity. The severity of asthma is graded based on frequency of day- and night-time symptomatic episodes. Intermittent asthma is characterized as symptoms occurring S2 days per week and S2 nights per month and requires as needed short-acting bronchodilators for symptomatic relief. Individuals with mild persistent asthma (such as this patient) exhibit symptoms >2 days per week or >2 nights per month, which requires the addition of daily low-dose inhaled corticosteroids (eg, fluticasone). Moderate persistent asthma is treated with the addition of long-acting inhaled beta-2 agonists (eg, salmeterol) to the regimen of low-dose inhaled corticosteroids and as-needed short acting bronchodilator. Severe persistent asthma is treated with the addition of high-dose corticosteroids to the regimen.

distractor_explanations.A: act as stand-alone treatment for intermittent asthma to assist in shortening symptomatic exacerbations. While albuterol plays a role in the management of all types of asthma, her asthma is mild persistent and requires the addition of a steroid. Salmeterol (
distractor_explanations.C: is a long-acting beta-2 agonist, used in treatment of moderate persistent asthma, working in conjunction with low-dose inhaled corticosteroids. Theophylline (
distractor_explanations.D: results in bronchodilation through the inhibition of phosphodiesterase. It has a narrow therapeutic window, resulting in significant cardiotoxicity and neurotoxicity. It is a late and/or last-line treatment. Tiotropium (
distractor_explanations.E: is a long-acting anti-muscarinic agent resulting in bronchodilation, which is indicated for use in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease . ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

67-year-old woman has the onset of fever and chills. Six months ago, she had gastrointestinal bleeding and had no

39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse is 105/min , respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Examination of the skin
shows no abnormalities . The lungs are clear to auscultation . Serum studies of a post-transfusion sample show no free
hemoglobin. A direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test is negative . The ABO blood groups of the patient and donor are verified ,
and a second crossmatch reconfirms compatibility . In addition to intravenous administration of crystalloid solution, which of
the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acute febrile transfusion reactions occur during the administration of blood transfusions secondary to preformed cytokines in the transfused blood. This reaction is not related to inaccurate cross matching or administration of an incorrect blood type to the patient. It is treated with acetaminophen plus fluids to blunt the hypothalamic response to cytokines. In contrast, hemolytic transfusion reactions would present with a positive Coombs test and free hemoglobin in serum.

distractor_explanations.B: is commonly used to treat malignant hyperthermia, which is characterized by rigidity, hyperthermia, and autonomic instability, often due to anesthetic medications or nitrates . Epinephrine (
distractor_explanations.C: is used to treat anaphylactic transfusion reactions which would be characterized by tachycardia, wheezing, hypotension, angioedema, itching, urticaria, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Penicillin (
distractor_explanations.D: is an antibiotic used to treat various gram-positive and spirochete infections. In the setting of a fever occurring during a transfusion, the time course is likely too abrupt to reflect a new infection, even if acquired from the blood. Prednisone (
distractor_explanations.E: is used to treat multiple inflammatory, atopic, infectious, and autoimmune conditions . It has no specific role in managing an acute febrile transfusion reaction. ,. "' , r-- ,. ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma most commonly occurs in the pancreatic head. It is often initially characterized by nonspecific vague abdominal discomfort or weight loss. As the pancreatic mass increases in size, it can lead to the obstruction and dilation of both the common bile duct and main pancreatic duct, referred to as a double-duct sign on ultrasound. This can result in painless jaundice and/or pancreatitis from obstruction of these ducts. If the pancreatic adenocarcinoma continues to spread and results in infiltration of surround ing abdominal viscera and/or encasement of adjacent neurovascular structures, this can manifest with severe abdominal pain. The nonspecific nature of pancreatic adenocarcinoma's early symptoms creates a diagnostic dilemma , as many benign conditions present similarly. It is frequently asymptomatic until it creates an obstruction, gastrointestinal dysfunction, perineural or vascular encasement/invasion, or metastatic disease .

distractor_explanations.A: presents with acute right upper quadrant and epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting, often following a fatty meal in a patient with either known gallstones or risk factors for them. This patient had a cholecystectomy and while post-cholecystectomy syndromes including ductal stones are possible, they are less likely. Primary biliary cirrhosis (
distractor_explanations.C: results in destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and classically presents in middle-aged females . It is characterized by jaundice , pruritus, anorexia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase. Sclerosing cholangitis (
distractor_explanations.D: presents either primarily or in patients with a history of ulcerative colitis. It presents as inflammation and chronic fibrosis of the biliary tree resulting in a beaded appearance to the biliary tree with multifocal strictures . Symptoms of sclerosing cholangitis include anorexia, nausea , vomiting, and malabsorption. Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction (
distractor_explanations.E: would result in dilated biliary and pancreatic ducts on imaging; however, this would be transient and not necessarily accompanied by an elevation in alkaline phosphatase or additional symptoms such as pain and itching. ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

30. A 42-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of progressive shortness of breath, cough, and

asymptomatic . Nine months ago, she was intubated and mechanically ventilated for 2 weeks for management of

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Tracheomalacia refers to softening and deterioration of the tracheal cartilage, which results in excessive end-expiratory collapse due to atrophy and/or reduction of the tracheal elastic fibers and decreased integrity of tracheal cartilage. In adults, this most commonly occurs after prolonged intubation with an endotracheal tube, which results in damage to the tracheal cartilage directly, and can increase the risk of tracheomalacia. Clinically, this presents with shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and expiratory stridor. It can also sound like wheezing on lung auscultation.

distractor_explanations.A: . Her high-pitched, end-expiratory wheezes and other symptoms are likely secondary to tracheomalacia and its associated expiratory collapse. Guillain-Barre syndrome (
distractor_explanations.B: is typically self limited and affects the lungs through diaphragmatic paralysis, not through an obstructive airway mechanism as seen in this patient. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (
distractor_explanations.C: results in shortness of breath, cough, and fever after exposure to a specific antigen. Paradoxic vocal cord motion (
distractor_explanations.D: occurs when the vocal cords close during breathing, resulting in an obstructed airway. There are many causes of paradoxic vocal cord motion, including exercise, coughing, and acid reflux. ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: A nevus of the skin is more likely to be a malignancy such as melanoma when it demonstrates asymmetry, irregular borders, uneven coloring, diameter ~6 mm, and rapid evolution. Appropriate management of a potentially malignant dermatologic lesion consists of excision with negative margins , which is both diagnostic and therapeutic. This is performed either through minimally invasive surgery such as Mohs, or through a wider traditional surgical excision.

Cryotherapy (
distractor_explanations.C: with liquid nitrogen is indicated for premalignant lesions, such as actinic keratosis, or hyperkeratotic lesions, such as condylomas (warts). Punch biopsy (
distractor_explanations.D: would provide diagnostic information but would not be therapeutic, since a portion of the lesion is left behind, and negative margins would not be confirmed. This lesion shows several concerning features for an aggressive malignancy, which must be diagnosed and treated (

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) results in a hyperchloremic, non-anion gap metabolic acidosis from dysregulation of the renal tubules. There are three types of RTA, varying in etiology and pathophysiology , but all resulting in a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. This patient demonstrates a low bicarbonate level , with a normal anion gap of 12, consistent with a non-anion gap acidosis. Distal RTA (type 1) results from a defect in renal secretion of W, which results in the lack of generation of HCO ultimately leading to a metabolic acidosis. It is -, 3 characterized by a urine pH >5.5. The most common causes of type 1 RTA include analgesic nephropathy, congenital obstructive urinary tract anomalies , drugs (eg , amphotericin), and autoimmune diseases resulting in hypergammaglobulinemia (eg, rheumatoid arthritis, Sjogren).

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Dysphagia has many structural, malignant, neurologic, infectious, and inflammatory causes. In the setting of weight loss, fatigue, low-grade fever, and intravenous drug abuse, the white oropharyngeal plaques are consistent with esophagitis from Candida species as a cause of dysphagia, a common opportunistic infection in an immunocompromised host such as a person with HIV. The patient's cervical lymphadenopathy is likely reactive to the adjacent esophageal infectious process. Herpes simplex virus and cytomegalovirus are also common infectious etiologies of esophagitis in this population, but these typically present with esophageal ulcers.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis represents a mixed type Ill and IV hypersensitivity reaction to various environmental antigens. This typically results in episodic dyspnea, fever, and cough which starts a few hours after the exposure to the antigen. Classically, this occurs in farmers and individuals exposed to bird droppings. It can also occur secondary to the use of hot tubs and resultant antigen exposure, as seen in this patient. Similarly, her symptoms may also represent a chemical pneumonitis or bronchitis from inhaled chlorine. Treatment requires avoidance of the specific inciting antigen. If chronic exposure occurs, this can result in alveolar thickening, noncaseating granuloma formation, and possible upper lobe predominant pulmonary fibrosis.

Swimming pool use (

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pulmonary tuberculosis can present in various stages. Primary tuberculosis results from an initial exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, leading to the development of hilar lymphadenopathy and a Ghon focus (Ghon complex). Reactivation tuberculosis (secondary) typically results in apical pulmonary opacity with fibrocaseous cavitary lesions. This may present clinically with prolonged fever, night sweats, weight loss (including skeletal muscle wasting), and hemoptysis. A PPD skin test can be negative in the setting of tuberculosis infection if the patient is immunocompromised. Reactivation tuberculosis requires combination anti-microbial treatment including rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, along with initial respiratory isolation.

distractor_explanations.A: occurs in patients at risk for aspiration (eg, elderly, stroke, dementia). It commonly presents with cough and fever following an aspiration episode, with consolidation most commonly occurring in the dependent portions of the right middle or lower lobes. Bronchiectasis (
distractor_explanations.B: refers to chronic dilation of the bronchi and/or bronchioles as a result of chronic necrotizing infection, most commonly related to chronic bronchial obstruction, cystic fibrosis, Kartagener syndrome, and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. Sarcoidosis (
distractor_explanations.C: is a chronic non-caseating granulomatous systemic inflammatory condition, which most commonly affects the hilar lymph nodes and lungs . Pulmonary sarcoidosis can result in coarse reticular pulmonary opacities, which may progress to a restrictive lung disease from interstitial fibrosis, although acute fever and hemoptysis would be rare. Septic pulmonary emboli (
distractor_explanations.D: typically occur in the setting of endocarditis (eg, tricuspid valve) or infected sources of thromboemboli (eg, Lemierre syndrome) . Wegener granulomatosis (
distractor_explanations.F: can result in multifocal cavitary pulmonary nodules, but typically also occurs in the setting of upper respiratory tract symptoms (eg , perforated nasal septum, chronic sinusitis) and glomerulonephritis (eg, hematuria). r , ,. ' , F'

diaphoretic . His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 88/min , respirations are 18/min , and blood pressure is 150/84 mm Hg. Examination
shows no lymphadenopathy . The abdomen is distended with epigastric tenderness . A photograph of the genitalia is shown . There is a lesion
under the prepuce . The lesions over the penile shaft are tender , but the lesion over the glans penis is nontender . Serum rapid plasma reagin is

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease from the spirochete Treponema pallidum that can present in multiple stages. Primarily syphilis presents with a painless chancre (ulcer) of the genitalia. There are typically no systemic signs or symptoms of syphilis infection at this stage. Rapid plasma reagin can be falsely negative in the primary stage of syphilis . Dark-field microscopy of fluid from the chancre is the most sensitive test for diagnosis of primary syphilis . The treatment for primary syphilis is a single benzathine Penicillin G intramuscular injection.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Simvastatin is a lipid-lowering agent that primarily reduces LDL in patients with hypercholesterolemia through the inhibition of hydroxymethylglutaryl-CoA reductase. While recommendations for lipid levels vary by recommending organization, general recommendations for individuals with diabetes mellitus center around a target LDL <100 mg/dl, HDL >40 mg/dl, and triglycerides <150 mg/dl. Patients with diabetes mellitus exhibit a higher incidence of cardiovascular disease, with increased morbidity and mortality secondary to macrovascular complications such as myocardial infarction, peripheral arterial disease, and stroke. It is critical to implement lipid-lowering agents to achieve target ranges for lipoprotein levels. Treatment of LDL cholesterol levels is considered the first priority for pharmacologic therapy. Statins are the first-line treatment medication for the improvement of dyslipidemia in the setting of diabetes mellitus.

distractor_explanations.A: is an oral hypoglycemic drug which binds to PPAR-gamma nuclear transcription factor to increase insulin sensitivity. Metformin (

distractor_explanations.C: inhibits angiotensin converting enzyme, which can be utilized for hypertension management, prevention of diabetic nephropathy, and to decrease mortality in the setting of heart failure management. This patient's LDL level is currently suboptimal, requiring initiation of simvastatin (

Which of the following interventions will most rapidly correct this patient's visual and memory disturbances?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Polycythemia vera is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder resulting in disordered, increased production of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets secondary to a JAK2 mutation . It often presents with increased pruritus, especially after hot showers secondary to increased mast cell production. Additionally, it can result in episodic severe, burning pain with red-blue discoloration secondary to blood clot formation in extremity vessels , referred to as erythromelalgia. The marked increase in red blood cell production and hematocrit can lead to the development of hyperviscosity syndrome , which presents with blurred vision and central nervous system symptoms related to vascular congestion . Therapeutic phlebotomy results in decreased red blood cell mass and blood volume, which would be the best initial treatment for reversal of the patient's symptoms.

distractor_explanations.D: would result in decreased red blood cell concentration (hematocrit), although would further increase blood volume. ,. "' , r-- ,. ,

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Inflammatory bowel disease comprises both Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. Crohn disease is characterized by transmural inflammation that can involve any portion of the gastrointestinal tract, manifesting with skip lesions. It particularly involves the terminal ileum and typically spares the rectum. Clinically, it can present with chronic abdominal pain, low-grade fever, weight loss, and watery or bloody diarrhea. Physical exam findings of Crohn disease include perianal fissures/fistulas, abdominal tenderness, and possible positive fecal occult blood, although bloody stools are not required for the diagnosis. Colonoscopy can demonstrate aphthous or linear ulcers with luminal strictures, inflammatory lesions, and a cobblestone mucosa. Biopsy is required for definitive diagnosis.

distractor_explanations.A: is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy resulting from autoimmune-mediated intolerance of gliadin. This results in inflammatory damage to the small bowel mucosa that primarily affects the distal duodenum and/or proximal jejunum, which leads to decreased mucosal absorption. Cytomegalovirus colitis (
distractor_explanations.C: occurs in patients with immunodeficiency, most commonly AIDS, and typically presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, rectal bleeding, and fever, often superimposed on the patient's primary condition. Giardiasis (
distractor_explanations.D: presents with foul-smelling, fatty diarrhea and bloating, typically in campers who ingest cysts from standing freshwater. Irritable bowel syndrome (
distractor_explanations.E: presents with recurrent abdominal pain, which improves with defecation, along with a change in frequency and consistency of stool. ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Contact dermatitis is a type IV T cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction following exposure to an allergen, which results in the development of a pruritic, erythematous, and papular rash. It is characteristically distributed along the location of clothing, perfume, plant contact, or nickel jewelry contact. The rashes are often described as linear or angular in shape. In some cases, the rash can spread from the point of initial contact through transfer of the allergen by hand contact. Frequent allergens resulting in contact dermatitis are nickel, topical antibiotics, and poison ivy or oak . Diagnosis for the specific causative allergen can be made through patch testing, with first-line treatments being topical corticosteroids and avoidance of the culprit allergen.

distractor_explanations.A: is a beta-1 selective antagonist, used in the management of hypertension and supraventricular dysrhythmias. Side effects of atenolol include bradycardia and atrioventricular block. While perfume (
distractor_explanations.B: can result in a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, the patient's rash is located specifically at the site of the new watch, which likely contains a component of nickel. Her rash does not appear to demonstrate the appropriate location or timeline to be presumed secondary to the perfume . As well, given the temporal and spatial relationship to the wearing of a new watch, along with erythematous papules, this is unlikely to represent a patch of dry skin (
distractor_explanations.C: . Contact dermatitis occurs secondary to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which is T-cell dependent, not secondary to an impaired T-lymphocyte response (

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Inguinal hernias can be subdivided into reducible, incarcerated, and strangulated categories. The contents of a reducible hernia easily return to their native position with gentle pressure, or with resolution of a triggering maneuver such as a Valsalva. The contents of incarcerated hernias become trapped within the hernia defect, and in spite of counterpressure, will not return to their native position. If this type of hernia contains bowel, an obstruction can result. Strangulated hernias occur when the herniated contents lose their blood supply, with the potential for necrosis or perforation. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Scombroid poisoning results from ingestion of accumulated histamine, produced by bacteria from the high histidine content of dark meat fish. When ingested, the histamine triggers a reaction variably presenting with flushing, urticaria, wheezing, itchiness, blurry vision, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and headache. In severe cases, it can present similarly to anaphylaxis. In this case, the mahimahi may have been improperly stored, leading to the accumulation of the histamine.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pulmonary contusions may occur after blunt or penetrating trauma to the chest. They often underlie the region of trauma to the chest wall and result from damage to capillaries with associated leakage of intravascular and extravascular fluid into the pulmonary interstitium and alveolar airspaces, respectively. This can result in hypoxia if it involves and compromises a large enough region of the lung. On chest radiographs, pulmonary contusions appear as interstitial infiltrates and/or patchy alveolar opacities. The extent and distribution depend on the mechanism, location, and force of trauma to the chest wall. Management of pulmonary contusions is supportive with control of pain, pulmonary toilet, lung expansion, and maintenance of adequate ventilation/oxygenation of the patient.

distractor_explanations.A: typically occurs following a long-bone fracture with resultant fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypoxia, petechiae, and conjunctiva! hemorrhage. Flail chest (

distractor_explanations.D: often occurs secondary to a hypervolemic state (eg, heart failure, renal failure, cirrhosis) or inflammatory state (eg, pneumonia , acute respiratory distress syndrome) and can present with tachypnea, tachycardia, hypoxia, cough, respiratory distress, and interstitial and/or alveolar opacities. Pulmonary thromboembolism (

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure secondary to chronic pulmonary pathology with increased pulmonary vascular resistance and right-sided heart pressures. This patient has a history of systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), with decreased lung expansion and inspiratory crackles on examination, indicating the presence of underlying interstitial lung disease (ILD) and a restrictive pulmonary pathophysiology. Chronic ILD is a risk factor for the development of pulmonary hypertension. Right heart failure presents with venous congestion, seen as jugular venous distention, peripheral edema, and hepatomegaly with or without ascites. The patient exhibits all of these symptoms, making cor pulmonale secondary to ILD the most likely clinical scenario .

distractor_explanations.B: occurs from obstruction of venous drainage from the head and bilateral upper extremities, often related to an underlying malignancy and associated mass effect, or from thrombosis from an indwelling catheter. Biventricular heart failure (
distractor_explanations.C: refers to heart failure of both the left and right ventricles. Left heart failure presents with symptoms such as paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, and pulmonary edema, which are not seen in this patient. Cirrhosis of the liver (
distractor_explanations.D: occurs secondary to many etiologies, the most common being alcoholic and non alcoholic fatty liver disease. Cirrhosis presents with ascites, anasarca, jaundice , elevated transaminases, low albumin, and impaired hepatic synthetic function . Idiopathic membranous nephropathy (

Lymphedema (

distractor_explanations.H: refers to facial and periorbital swelling in the setting of hypothyroidism. Pretibial myxedema may be seen in Graves disease . Venous insufficiency (
distractor_explanations.I: often occurs secondary to a history of deep venous thrombosis; it can lead to stasis dermatitis and cutaneous ulcers of the affected extremity. ,. "' , r-- r ,,,

1. A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of growths on her lips and tongue for several years. Examination shows nodules on the lips,
buccal mucosa, and tongue; cafe au lait spots over the trunk and limbs; and scattered nodules on the skin. This patient is at greatest risk for which
of the following conditions?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Mucosa! neuromas, growths on the oral mucosa and lips, are a finding of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 2B. Other features of MEN2B include medullary thyroid carcinoma, and pheochromocytoma. MEN2B is also associated with neurofibromatosis type I, and these disorders can present simultaneous ly. Neurofibromatosis type I (von Recklinghausen disease) is a genetically inherited disorder caused by a defect in NF1, the gene which encodes neurofibromin on chromosome 17. It follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. It is characterized by a constellation of cutaneous manifestations (neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibromas, cafe au lait macules, and axillary freckling), a variety of central nervous system tumors including optic nerve glioma and iris hamartoma (Lisch nodule), and bony abnormalities such as long bone dysplasia and sphenoid wing dysplasia. Patients are also at higher risk for developing astrocytomas, brainstem gliomas, and soft tissue sarcomas. Neurofibromatosis type II has a different constellation of findings: bilateral acoustic schwannomas, cataracts, meningiomas, and ependymomas, and is not associated with MEN.

distractor_explanations.B: is a central nervous system neoplasm formed from ependymal cells which typically arises in the fourth ventricle. Ependymoma is a feature of neurofibromatosis type II. Lymphoma (
distractor_explanations.C: is a hematologic malignancy derived from lymphocytes which has many different subtypes and presentations. CNS lymphoma is a type of intracranial neoplasm, but it is not seen in neurofibromatosis type I or MEN2B.

2. A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of gradually progressive weakness in the shoulder and hip muscles. She
has hypothyroidism treated with thyroxine but is otherwise healthy. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows moderate
bilateral weakness of the deltoid, biceps, triceps, psoas, glutei, and quadriceps muscles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
Her erythrocyte sedimentat ion rate is 85 mm/h, and serum creatine kinase activity is 2456 U/L. Complete blood count and urinalysis are within
normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Electromyograp hy and nerve conduction studies

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Electromyography and nerve conduction studies are used to support a diagnosis of inflammatory myopathy such as polymyositis, as in this case. Polymyositis is an autoimmune condition affecting the proximal muscles. It is closely related to dermatomyositis, however, unlike dermatomyositis, it does not present with cutaneous findings. The muscular inflammation is characterized by endomysial COB+ inflammatory infiltrate. This is in contrast to dermatomyositis which demonstrates a perimysial CD4+ inflammato ry infiltrate. An inflammatory infiltrate of the muscle occurs, causing damage to the myocytes, leading to release of creatine kinase, an intracellular molecule. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is also increased, indicating the presence of inflammation. This can be used to monitor disease progress in polymyositis. Both polymyositis and dermatomyositis are characterized by several autoantibodies: positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) and anti-Jo-1, anti-SRP, and anti-Mi-2. Treatment of polymyositis involves systemic steroids followed by long-term immunosuppressive therapy with medications such as methotrexate or azathioprine.

distractor_explanations.A: is used to evaluate damage to small and large nerve endings, not primary muscle inflammation. MRI of the spinal cord (
distractor_explanations.C: would be beneficial in evaluating muscle weakness because of a spinal epidural abscess or tumor. While these pathologies can cause proximal muscle weakness, other symptoms such as fever, back pain, and sensory deficits would also be seen. As polymyositis is an inflammatory myopathy with no spinal cord involvement, imaging of the spinal cord will not be helpful. Skin biopsy (
distractor_explanations.D: is indicated in evaluation of suspected dermatomyositis. However, this patient does not demonstrate any cutaneous findings, and thus, a skin biopsy is not warranted. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Polymyositis and dermatomyositis are autoimmune inflammatory myopathies. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies are part of the initial evaluation of these diseases. .,.

4. One day after undergo ing an elective cholecystectomy, a 67-year-o ld woman becomes confused and belligerent. She has a 2-year history of mild
dementia, Alzheimer type. She takes no medications. Intramuscular haloperidol is administered, and 1 hour later, she begins to repetitively
hyperextend her neck. She also has repetitive conjugate upward movements of the eyes that she says she cannot control. Examination shows no
other abnorma lities. Administration of a medication with which of the following properties is the most appropriate treatment?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acute dystonias can occur in response to antipsychotics, such as haloperidol, antiepileptic drugs, or antiemetics. Common presentations include torticollis (head tilted to the side and down), retrocollis (head tilted back), opisthotonos (arching of the back), and oculogyric crisis (upward deviation of the eyes). It rarely presents with laryngospasm and strider. These movements are involuntary and cannot be controlled by the patient. The pathophysiology is an imbalance in the dopaminergic-cholinergic pathways of the basal ganglia. Risk factors for development include male sex, young age, recent cocaine use, and a history of

distractor_explanations.B: agents are used primarily in the treatment of schizophrenia and include agents such as haloperidol. Antidopaminergic agents can also be used to treat nausea. As acute dystonias are caused by an imbalance in the dopaminergic and cholinergic pathways, further antagonism of dopamine would likely worsen symptoms. Antiserotonergic (
distractor_explanations.C: medications are used to treat nausea, especially chemotherapy-induced nausea and emesis. Some antidepressants and antipsychotics also have antiserotonergic activity. However, serotonin is not involved in the pathophysiology of acute dystonia. Cholinergic (
distractor_explanations.D: agents increase the amount of acetylcholine present in the neuromuscular junction, which leads to increased muscular contraction. They can be used to treat myasthenia gravis, to reverse neuromuscular blockade, and to improve symptoms associated with Alzheimer disease. Choliner ic a ents would worsen this atient's acute d stonia.

explanation.educational_objective: Acute dystonia most commonly occurs in response to typical antipsychotics and presents with torticollis, retrocollis, opisthotonos, and oculogyric crisis. Treatment involves anticholinergic medications, such as diphenhydramine or benztropine. .,.

vignette.presentation:
5. A previously healthy 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of progressive sensory loss. Initially, only her feet felt
numb, but the loss of sensation has slowly ascended symmetrically to the umbilicus. She also has had urinary urgency and frequency, nocturia, and
the perception of a tight band-like sensation around her midabdominal region. Examination shows slowing of left eye adduction during saccadic
movement of the eyes to the right. There is diffuse hyperreflexia. Sensation to pinprick is decreased to the level of the umbilicus. Which of the
following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Multiple sclerosis, the most prevalent immune-mediated demyelinating disease, may present initially with transverse myelitis though can also demonstrate neurologic symptoms from lesions in other central nervous system (CNS) locations. Transverse myelitis refers to inflammation that extends transversely across the spinal cord, leading to bilateral sensory, motor, or autonomic dysfunction. When sensory tracts are involved, sensory deficits are evident at a clear dermatomal level (also known as a sensory level, likely T10 in this patient) and may present as a band-like sensation at that level. Autonomic symptoms may present as urinary urgency or incontinence, bowel incontinence, or sexual dysfunction. According to the McDonald criteria for multiple sclerosis diagnosis, patients must have evidence of demyelinating lesions that are separated in time and location. This evidence can be based on subjective symptoms or imaging evidence. This patient presents with evidence of lesions separated in space (a T10 spinal cord lesion, a lesion potentially affecting the medial longitudinal fasciculus, several corticospinal tract lesions as evidenced by diffuse hyperreflexia). Though the patient did not experience discrete symptomatic episodes separated by time, the presence of multiple lesions in discrete locations makes multiple sclerosis the most likely diagnosis (as the other deficits likely arose at different times). MRI of the brain typically shows white matter hyperintensities in the periventricular region, cortex, subcortical region, cerebellum, or spine. Oligoclonal bands of immunoglobu lins, indicating immune overactivation, can be found in the cerebrospinal fluid but are not necessary for diagnosis. Treatment includes corticosteroids for symptomatic management of acute flares and long-term disease-modifying treatments such as interferon or monoclonal antibodies.

distractor_explanations.A: is a rare X-linked peroxisomal disorder that results from the accumulation of very long fatty acid chains in various tissues. As a result of peripheral neuropathy and myelopathy, female carriers of the disorder may present with bilateral spastic paraparesis, sphincter dysfunction, neurogenic bladder, and sexual dysfunction. However, multiple sclerosis is more common, .... r ~ - - - , - - - - - - -- - - - -- - - - - - - -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - r,

Patients with multiple sclerosis may present initially with transverse myelitis, which may demonstrate a sensory level and a band-like sensation, along with possible autonomic and motor symptoms.

vignette.presentation:
6. A 67-year-old woman is brought to the physician 3 hours after a 5-minute episode of visual loss in her left eye. She has not had any other
symptoms. She has hypertension and stable angina pectoris. Medications include lisinopril and metoprolol. Her pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure
is 150/92 mm Hg. Funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best at the apex. Neurologic
examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Amaurosis fugax describes brief episodes of transient, unilateral vision loss and is indicative of retinal ischemia caused by either microembolization or inflammation of the ophthalmic artery. It often precedes the onset of central retinal artery occlusion , which is considered an ophthalmic stroke. In the absence of signs and symptoms of giant cell arteritis, such as fever, chills, weight loss, temporal headache and tenderness, or jaw claudication, amaurosis fugax is most suggestive of embolic retinal ischemia and should prompt an emergent evaluation for sources of emboli. The majority of emboli to the ophthalmic vasculature originate from the carotid arteries and cardiac valves. Evaluation should include prompt carotid duplex ultrasonography, as well as echocardiography. Treatment of carotid vascular or cardiac valvular disease can prevent central retinal arterial occlusion, which may cause irreversible blindness.

However, this patient's lack of other symptoms renders carotid arterial disease, rather than giant cell arteritis, as the more likely cause of her amaurosis fugax. Visual field testing (
distractor_explanations.C: may be useful for the diagnosis of glaucoma or cortical vision loss. Delaying the search for embolic sources while pursuing other diagnostic tests puts the patient at risk for ischemic stroke and blindness. MRI of the brain (
distractor_explanations.D: may be useful for the diagnosis of optic neuritis. It is not useful for identifying the source of emboli that are causing this patient's amaurosis fugax. Vision loss secondary to optic neuritis typically lasts for several days or weeks, rather than minutes. ....

It often precedes the onset of central retinal artery occlusion, which is an ophthalmic stroke. Patients who present with amaurosis fugax should undergo an emergent evaluation with carotid duplex ultrasonography and echocardiography to prevent an ischemic stroke of the eye or of the brain. .,.

vignette.presentation:
7. An 11-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a 2-day history of increasing weakness and a prickling
sensation in her legs. She was previously healthy except for a mild flu-like illness during the past week. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is
78/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Examination of the lower extremities shows a muscle strength of 1/ 5 and
decreased sensation to pinprick. Achilles tendon and patellar reflexes are decreased . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A
lumbar puncture is performed. Analysis of cerebrospinal fluid shows a total protein concentration of 80 mg/dl and a leukocyte count of 4/mm3. In
addition to close observation, oxygen therapy, and maintenance of fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient most likely has Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS), leading to polyneuropathy, which is typically treated with immune globulins or plasma exchange. In GBS, a preceding infection (eg, Campylobacter jejuni, influenza-like illnesses) leads to autoimmune cross reactivity with the myelin of the nerve roots exiting the spinal cord. The ventral nerve roots, containing motor and sympathetic efferents, are most commonly involved, though the dorsal nerve root (controlling sensation) may also be affected. As such, patients typically present with acute symmetric muscle weakness with depressed or absent deep tendon reflexes (reflecting a lower motor neuron pattern of dysfunction) that begins in the lower extremities and may rapidly ascend to involve the upper extremities, bulbar muscles, or respiratory muscles. Autonomic dysfunction (eg, blood pressure fluctuations, cardiac irregularities) is common. Sensory deficits and pain can also occur (though these symptoms are typically mild compared to motor dysfunction). The diagnosis is confirmed by increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell counts on lumbar puncture, termed albuminocytologic dissociation, thought to reflect generalized inflammation. Management includes respiratory support and, for severe cases, plasma exchange or intravenous immunoglobulin therapy. Intravenous immunoglobulin therapy may work by neutralizing the cross-reactive antibodies that cause GBS.

8. A 42-year-old woman with alcoholism has severe burning paresthesias of both feet and decreased vibratory sensation in both ankles 2 months after
beginning treatment for active, cavitary pulmonary tuberculosis. At the time of diagnosis she was malnourished, and isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol,
vitamin B and folic acid were prescribed. The most likely cause of paresthesias of her feet and decreased sensation in her ankles is failure to take

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Primary tuberculosis results from an initial exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, leading to the development of hilar lymphadenopathy and a Ghon focus (Ghon complex), as in this case. In the primary infection, patients present with subacute fevers, weight loss, night sweats, cough, and malaise. Active tuberculosis is treated primarily with a combination of rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. lsoniazid binds vitamin B (pyridoxine) which may result in early excretion and inactivation of pyridoxine, 6 and also inhibits pyridoxine phosphokinase, which is necessary to activate it. Pyridoxine deficiency then results, of which the primary symptoms are peripheral neuropathy or paresthesia. Therefore, all patients taking isoniazid concurrently take pyridoxine supplementation. Pyridoxine deficiency limits synthesis of histamine, hemoglobin, and neurotransmitters including epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine, serotonin, and y-aminobutyric acid (GABA). In addition to peripheral neuropathy, deficiency commonly presents with dermatitis, sideroblastic anemia, glossitis, and seizures.

Folate is contained in leafy vegetables and absorbed in the jejunum. Folate deficiency is often seen in patients with malnutrition, alcohol use disorder, and patients taking anti-folate medications (eg, phenytoin, methotrexate). It is not caused by any of the medications used to treat tuberculosis. lsoniazid (

9. A 20-year-old college student comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 2 days after sustaining a head injury when he ran into another
player while playing flag football. He did not lose consciousness but does not remember anything from the rest of the game. He was evaluated in
the emergency department 1 hour after the injury; a CT scan of the head showed no abnormalities and he was discharged. Today, he reports a mild,
persistent headache that improves with acetaminophen. He has not had nausea, vomiting, or memory problems and was able to return to school
today. Examination shows no abnormalities. He asks about playing i11 a flag football playoff game tomorrow. Which of the following is the most
appropriate recommendation?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Mild traumatic brain injury, also known as a concussion, commonly results in loss of consciousness, confusion, amnesia, headache, dizziness, nausea, or vomiting minutes after the injury. Symptoms that commonly develop within the following days include mood disturbances, photophonophobia, trouble concentrating, or insomnia. Focal neurologic symptoms, such as limb weakness or vision changes, indicate traumatic vascular injury. As such, all patients with suspected concussion should undergo a thorough neurologic examination, and a subset of at-risk patients should receive neuroimaging. All patients should be monitored closely for 24 hours for neurologic deterioration, which may indicate a developing intracranial hematoma. To prevent cumulative brain injury (eg, from a second concussion), patients with concussion should return to their usual activities in a graded fashion, beginning with the return to school or work. Each day, a more intense activity can be introduced (eg, first light aerobic exercise), culminating with contact sports after a week in uncomplicated and improving cases.

10. A 19-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by paramedics after having a seizure at a dormitory party on campus. According to
her boyfriend, who accompanied her, she had been drinking more water than usual and then became silent and began staring. He then witnessed
her collapse to the floor and begin shaking for approximate ly 1 minute. On arrival, she is mute and unresponsive to questions. She appears
restless and periodically grinds her teeth. Her temperature is 39.6°C (103.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is
150/95 mm Hg. Physical examination shows profuse diaphoresis and piloerection. Pupils are 5 mm bilaterally. The remainder of the examination
shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Prothrombin time 16 sec
Serum
Na+ 114mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 40 mg/dL
Creatinine 2 mg/dL
ALT 90 U/L
Creatine kinase 1200 U/L
The most likely diagnosis is intoxication with which of the following substances?

question_stem: The most likely diagnosis is intoxication with which of the following substances?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MOMA), called ecstasy or "Molly," is a psychotherapeutic agent and drug of abuse. It is a stimulant and causes feelings of increased energy, euphoria, and disinhibition. Minor characteristic side effects include agitation, bruxism (grinding teeth), diaphoresis, and blurry vision. However, serious side effects also accompany ecstasy use. Autonomic instability (hypertension, tachycardia, and hyperthermia) can lead to life-threatening cardiovascular toxicity. This patient demonstrates another serious complication: hyponatremia secondary to increased water intake and secretion of anti-diuretic hormone. Severe hyponatremia may be accompanied by seizures, as seen in this case, as well as confusion, coma, or death. This is a particular risk in young women. Treatment includes rapid administration of hypertonic saline if recurrent seizure activity occurs, followed by gradual correction of sodium and management of autonomic instability.
explanation.educational_objective: 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MOMA), called ecstasy or "Molly," can potentially cause both minor and serious side effects, including autonomic instability, cardiovascu lar toxicity, and severe hyponatremia. .,.

11. A 47-year-o ld man with a history of alcoholism is brought to the emergency department by his family because of confusion. He lives alone, and
they found him disoriented 4 hours ago. An empty plastic container with a sweet odor was found in his apartment. He is oriented only to place.
Cranial nerves, motor strength, and sensation are normal. Serum studies show a creatinine concentrat ion of 1.5 mg/dl, bicarbonate concentrat ion
of 8 mEq/L, and an increased anion gap. Serum ketones test is negative. Urinalysis shows crystals. Exposure to which of the following is the most
likely cause of these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Patients with ingestion of ethylene glycol may present similarly to patients with alcohol intoxication, with central nervous system effects such as disorientation and altered mental status. Ethylene glycol is metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase to toxic metabolites including glycolate, glyoxylate, and oxalate. These metabolites are directly toxic to the kidneys through tubular damage as well as oxalate crystal precipitation causing tubule obstruction, resulting in acute kidney injury. Oxalate crystals are seen on urine microscopy. These metabolites also contribute to an anion-gap metabolic acidosis. Management of ethylene glycol poisoning involves fomepizo le, an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor that prevents metabolization of ethylene glycol to its toxic metabo lites. For severe ingestions, hemodial ysis to remove ethylene glycol and its metabolites may be necessary.

vignette.presentation:
12. A 77-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician for a routine follow-up examination. He feels well. His only medication is a diuretic.
His blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. On neurologic examination, cranial nerves are intact. Muscle tone and strength are normal. Deep tendon
reflexes are absent in the ankles but otherwise normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Measureme nt of urine lead concentration

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: A thorough neurologic examination should include evaluation of the cranial nerves, gait, coordination, movement, muscle strength and tone, light touch, pain and temperature sensation, deep tendon reflexes, and the plantar response (Babinski sign). Deep tendon reflexes can be checked over the biceps, triceps, brachioradialis, knee, and Achilles tendons using a reflex hammer. They are graded on a scale of Oto 4 where 0 is absent, 2 is normal, and 4 is clonus (continual contraction). Reflex strength should be compared on either side and within the same patient. The Achilles reflex test is particularly useful for evaluating pathology of the S1 nerve root and differentiating upper from lower motor neuron dysfunction. However, bilaterally absent Achilles reflex is also a normal variation, the proportion of which increases with age. Thus, in this case, the absence of both Achilles reflexes does not require any additional management. Educational Objectives: A, B, C, and D. Measurement of urine lead concentration (Choice A) is appropriate when lead poisoning is suspected. Symptoms of lead poisoning occur within days or weeks of exposure and include distal motor neuropathy. While this does cause hyporeflexia, it would affect all the reflexes in the body, not just the Achilles. It would also cause other lower motor neuron symptoms such as muscle weakness, atrophy, and fasciculations, which this patient lacks. MRI of the lumbar spine (Choice B) would be beneficial in evaluating hyporeflexia because of a spinal nerve or spinal cord lesion. Neither of these pathologies would present with bilaterally absent Achilles reflexes alone without other symptoms like back pain or muscle weakness. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies (Choice C) are used to support a diagnosis of inflammatory myopathy such as polymyositis or dermatomyositis. This condition is associated with muscle weakness, not peripheral neuropathy. These studies are not necessary in this asymptomatic individual.
explanation.educational_objective: The proportion of individuals who have bilaterally absent Achilles reflexes increases with age. Without other symptoms such as back pain or weakness, an older patient with bilaterally absent Achilles reflexes may be reassured that it is a normal finding. .,.

13. An otherwise healthy 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of decreased libido and delayed ejaculation. He says
that his symptoms are having a detrimental effect on his relationship. He has not had similar problems in the past. Four months ago, he was
evaluated for low mood and loss of interest and productivity; his symptoms have been well controlled with sertraline since that time. He takes no
other medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following neurotransmitters is most likely responsible for this
patient's current symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Increased serotonin likely explains this patient's sexual dysfunction. Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that increases synaptic serotonin activity and improves mood in patients with major depressive disorder. SSRls commonly cause sexual dysfunction within all three phases of sexual response (libido, sexual arousal, and orgasm). If the sexual dysfunction is persistent and distressing, management commonly involves lowering the SSRI dose, switching to an antidepressant with a lower risk for sexual dysfunction (eg, bupropion, mirtazapine), or adding bupropion or a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor such as sildenafil. Libido is typically enhanced by dopamine and gonadal hormones and may be inhibited by medications such as antipsychotics and SSRls. Arousal is promoted by acetylcholine, which leads to vasodilation of the helicine/vaginal arteries and consequent penile/clitora l tumescence. Medications with anticholinergic activity and SSRls inhibit arousal. Norepinephrine enhances orgasm (and ejaculation), and beta blockers and SSRls inhibit orgasm.

distractor_explanations.A: mediates arousal via the vasodilation of the helicine or vaginal arteries. Medications with anticholinergic activity, which include paroxetine but not sertraline within the SSRI class, may inhibit arousal but would not likely affect libido or ejaculation. y-Aminobutyric acid (
distractor_explanations.B: , or GABA, is the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter. GABA is not known to be involved in sexual response. Dopamine (
distractor_explanations.C: , which may be increased by methylphenidate, amphetamines, and cocaine, increases libido and may play a role in ejaculation. However, antidepressants do not affect dopamine signaling. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRls) commonly cause dysfunction in libido, sexual arousal, and orgasm/ejaculation. Lowering the SSRI dose, switching antidepressant medication, or adding phosphodiesterase inhibitors or bupropion may improve sexual dysfunction. .,.

vignette.presentation:
14. A previously healthy 27-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of pain in his neck and left shoulder radiating through
the lateral surface of his left arm to his thumb and index finger. Examination shows a decreased biceps reflex on the left. Muscle strength is 4/5 on
extension of the left wrist. Sensation to light touch is decreased over the left thumb and index finger. The remainder of the examination, including
neurologic examination, shows no abnormal ities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: C6 radiculopathy is the most likely diagnosis. The C6 dermatome is located on the lateral aspect of the forearm and extends to the lateral two digits of the hand. Injury to the C6 nerve roots will cause decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in these distributions along with motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension. The C6 nerve root carries efferent information for the biceps reflex. Dermatomes and myotomes are components of the embryonic somite, a paired segment of paraxial mesoderm. When fully developed, the dermatome is an area of skin whose afferent fibers travel within a single spinal nerve, and myotome is a group of muscles innervated by efferent fibers from a single spinal nerve. Radiculopathy refers to pathology of a spinal nerve root and may be caused by spondylosis (degenerative changes of the spine), disc herniation, infection, tumor, demyelination, or infarction. Disc herniation and spondylosis are the most common causes and lead to compression of the nerve root as it exits the spinal cord. Sensory deficits, motor dysfunction, and pain typically occur in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected nerve root.

distractor_explanations.A: would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction in the neck and shoulders around the acromioclavicu lar joint. Sensory and motor dysfunction in the distal upper extremity and an absent biceps reflex are more consistent with C6 radiculopathy. C5 radiculopathy (
distractor_explanations.B: would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction in the lateral aspect of the shoulder and upper arm. C5 radiculopathy typically results in an absent biceps reflex, as the C5 nerve root carries afferent information for this reflex. However, C5 radiculopathy would not cause decreased sensation in the digits. . - -- - -- - - - - - - -- - -- .. - - - - -- - -- -- - - .. -- - - .. --- - -- .. -- - -- ....

explanation.educational_objective: Radiculopathy refers to nerve root pathology that leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesia, and pain in a dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected root. C6 radiculopathy will cause decreased sensation, pain, or paresthesia in the lateral forearm and lateral two digits. Additionally, C6 radiculopathy causes motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension, with an absent biceps reflex.

vignette.presentation:
15. A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of a ?-day history of increasingly severe pain around the waist. He says that it feels like a
burning belt from the left midback to the umbilicus. He has a history of chronic low back pain. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with
glyburide and asthma treated with beclomethasone and albuterol inhalers. He completed a 10-day course of corticosteroids for asthma 3 weeks
ago. Examination shows numbness in the left T12 distribution. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is
the most likely explanation for these findings?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's history of diabetes and presenting signs and symptoms of burning pain in a dermatomal distribution are, in the absence of other findings, consistent with a diagnosis of diabetic radiculopathy. Formation of advanced glycation end products in chronic diabetics leads to microvascular ischemic damage to various tissues, including to the vasa nervorum. This mechanism underlies the pathogenesis of both diabetic polyneuropathy, as well as diabetic radiculopathy. Diabetic thoracic radiculopathy presents with unilatera l burning and electric-like pain extending from the back to the anterior abdomina l midline in a dermatomal distribution that may involve one or several spinal levels. Patients often experience numbness and muscular weakness of the affected nerve distribution. Most patients experience improvement in their symptoms over several months with conservative treatment.

distractor_explanations.A: is an autoimmune disorder affecting the axial joints, especially the intervertebral and sacroiliac joints. Patients present with slowly progressive, dull, lower back pain and stiffness that characteristically improves with activity. Patients usually present in the third decade of life and rarely experience burning pain. Atherosclerotic vascular disease (
distractor_explanations.B: may cause claudication, which presents with pain of the lower extremity that occurs in the setting of exercise and resolves with rest. Patients may experience coolness, pallor, hair loss, and poor wound healing of the affected limb. . - - - - -- - - -- - - -- - - - -- -- - - - - - -- - -- - -- - -- -- ----- ....

explanation.educational_objective: Diabetic microvascular damage to nerves may result in polyneuropathy or radiculopathy. Diabetic thoracic radiculopathy presents with unilateral burning and electric-like pain extending from the back to the anterior abdominal midline in a dermatomal distribution involving one or several spinal levels.

vignette.presentation:
16. A 12-year-old girl with systemic lupus erythematosus is brought to the emergency department by her parents after they had difficulty awakening
her this morning. She has needed constant stimulation to stay awake. Over the past 2 days, she has had a flu-like illness and vomiting. She has
been unable to take her corticosteroid and antihypertensive medications. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are
40/min, and blood pressure is 180/130 mm Hg. She is obtunded but moves all extremities to painful stimuli. Funduscopic examination shows
bilateral papilledema with flame hemorrhages. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk and symmetric. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 12 mm/h.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hypertensive encephalopathy is a known complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and results from acute and severe increases in blood pressure. It may manifest with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizure, and can progress to obtundation and coma. Visual symptoms may result from cortical hypertension or from hypertensive retinopathy, manifesting as papilledema and flame hemorrhages on fundoscopic examination. Treatment includes carefully lowering the blood pressure while avoiding excessively rapid drops, which can cause cerebral or cardiac ischemia. In general, a decrease in the mean arterial pressure of 25% within the first hour is appropriate, with gradual correction over the

distractor_explanations.B: as a manifestation of SLE is rare. Cerebral vasculitis can present with neurologic deficits, headache, seizures, or coma. Hypertensive encephalopathy is more likely in this patient. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (
distractor_explanations.D: presents commonly in younger, overweight females taking vitamin A, oral contraceptives, or danazol. It is usually associated with a holocephalic headache and blurry vision. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Hypertensive encephalopathy may result from acute and severe increases in blood pressure. It may manifest with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizure, and can progress to obtundation and coma. .,.

vignette.presentation:
17. A previously healthy 4-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a 3-day history of increased drowsiness.
During this period, she also has been feeding poorly and "spitting up" after each feeding. She has not had fever. She was born at term following an
uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. On arrival, she is responsive to tactile stimuli. She is at the 25th percentile for length and weight and
90th percentile for head circumference. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/70
mm Hg. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanel. There is a hyperpigmented macule with hair growth on the upper lumbar spine; her
parents report that this finding was noted at birth. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Chiari malformations are rare congenital malformations that typically present in infancy with feeding and breathing problems, spina bifida (classically manifesting as myelomeningocele), and obstructive hydrocephalus (presenting as large head circumference and bulging anterior fontanel in this patient) as a result of the downward displacement of the cerebellar vermis and tonsils. This patient's hyperpigmented macule with hair growth on the upper lumbar spine likely represents spina bifida occulta (a small defect in the vertebrae). Some patients also demonstrate eye movement abnormalities. Some Chiari malformations present in adolescence with bilateral cranial nerve palsies, weakness, and cerebellar dysfunction as a result of the downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils and consequent brainstem compression. Imaging typically demonstrates downward displacement of the cerebellar vermis and tonsils, along with ventriculomegaly from hydrocephalus. Treatment involves surgical intervention for neural tube defects, shunting for hydrocephalus, and medical management of feeding and respiratory difficulties.

distractor_explanations.A: typically presents with fever and signs of meningeal irritation (nausea, irritability, confusion, anorexia, headache, and nuchal rigidity). Spina bifida occulta is not associated with acute bacterial meningitis. Hydrocephalus may result from bacterial meningitis. Idiopathic increased intracranial pressure (
distractor_explanations.C: would present with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (nausea, vomiting, positional headache) without hydrocephalus or other central nervous system pathology. Spina bifida occulta would be atypical. . .... r ~- - - , - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - r - - - - ,- - - -

Spina bifida occulta may present as a hyperpigmented macule with hair growth in the lumbar region. Imaging demonstrates downward displacement of the cerebellar vermis and tonsils, along with ventriculomegaly from hydrocephalus. .,.

vignette.presentation:
18. A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of headaches accompanied by nausea and vomiting over the past 2 weeks; they are located
behind the left eye and improve after sleep. The headaches started during final examinations, and she now is missing 2 to 3 days of school weekly
because of the pain. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Examination
shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Migraine is a common condition that presents with recurrent primary headaches. Migraine headaches are typically severe, unilateral, throbbing, and associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia. The pain is usually located behind or adjacent to the eye. Some patients additionally experience an aura before or during the headache, which may present with vision loss followed by the perception of scintillating shapes or lines or paresthesia. Migraine triggers include stress, menstruation, weather changes, fasting, and alcoholic beverages. Sleep may improve migraines. Migraines are postulated to arise from deficient serotonin inhibition of descending pain pathways. Acute migraine treatment includes triptans and/or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). For patients with disabling or frequent migraines, prophylactic treatment is also recommended and includes ~-adrenergic blockers, antidepressants such as tricyclic antidepressants and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, and anticonvulsants.

distractor_explanations.A: may cause generalized headaches associated with vomiting that typically occur while patients are lying supine as a result of increased intracranial pressure and may be accompanied by papilledema and blurred vision. This patient's headache improved in the supine position. Cluster headaches (
distractor_explanations.B: are primary headaches that typically present with short-lived, unilateral, severe pain in the orbital, supraorbital, or temporal region of the head and are accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (eg, miosis, ptosis, lacrimation, nasal congestion). This patient did not demonstrate autonomic symptoms. Sinusitis (
distractor_explanations.D: may be associated with bilateral, pressure-like, periorbital headaches and nasal congestion. Headaches are not typically associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia. This patient's unilateral headaches that started during a stressful period are more consistent with migraine. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Migraines are typically unilateral, pulsating headaches that are associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia, and may also present with visual or sensory aura. Stress is a common migraine trigger, and sleep may improve headaches. .,.

19. Over the past year, a 72-year-old man has had progressive aching in his lower extremities when he walks in the shopping mall. Initially, the pain
began after 15 minutes of walking and resolved after he stopped; now, it starts after 5 or 10 minutes of walking, and it occasionally occurs when he
stands up after sleeping all night. The pain radiates from his buttocks to his feet. He describes it as a "terrible" pain. He has mild chronic
obstructive pulmonary disease but continues to smoke one pack of cigarettes daily. He has cervical arthritis and often has neck and arm pain.
Examination shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Strength and sensation are normal in the extremities. Babinski's sign is absent bilaterally.
Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in both knees and ankles and 2+ in the upper extremities. Dorsalis pedis pulses are normal. Which of the following is
the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Alcoholic rhabdomyolysis J) Hypokalemic periodic paralysis
Amyotrophic lateral scleros is K) Hypothyroid myopathy
Becker muscular dystrophy L) Lumbar spinal stenosis
Epidural metastatic carcinoma P) Sensorimotor periphera l neuropathy

20. A 25-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of increasing low back pain that is most severe on awakening in the
morning. His pain is relieved by stretching. There is no history of trauma. He is otherwise healthy except for occasional dysuria. Examination
shows decreased forward flexion of the spine and tenderness over the lumbosac ral area and at the insertion site of the Achilles tendon. Which of
the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Abdomina l aortic aneurysm G) Metastatic cancer
Herniated disc at L4-L5 I) Pyelonephritis
lnterverteb ral discitis J) Rheumatoid arthritis
Lumbar spinal stenosis L) Systemic lupus erythematosus

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Ankylosing spondyl itis (AS) refers to an inflammatory arthritis of the spine and other joints (eg, the sacroiliac joints) along with extra-articu lar inflammation. Patients typically present at younger than age 40 years with insidious chronic low back pain that worsens at night and improves with activity (caused by the mobilization of inflammatory material from joints). This pattern of pain is known as inflammatory back pain. Sacroiliac arthritis and enthesitis (inflammation of the attachments of tendons and ligaments to bone) are other common joint manifestations. Extra-articular manifestations commonly include anterior uveitis, psoriasis, and inflammatory bowel disease. AS is associated with reactive arthritis, which classical ly presents with post-infectious conjunctivitis, arthritis, and urethritis. Over time, patients with AS can develop decreased spine mobility, hyperkyphosis, osteopenia, and an increased risk for vertebra l fragility fractures. Laboratory studies demonstrate increased acute phase reactant concentrations (eg, erythrocyte sedimentation rate) along with a positive HLA-B27 test in many patients. Plain x-rays may illustrate fused vertebrae and sacroiliac joints. Treatment typically begins with nonsteroida l anti-inf lammatory drugs and escalates to disease-modifying immunomodulating medication in refractory cases.
explanation.educational_objective: Ankylosing spondylitis is an inflammatory condition of the spine and sacroiliac joints, leading to insidious back pain in patients typically younger than age 40 years. The pain is worse at night and improves with activity. Extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis are common. Vertebral fusion and decreased spine mobility commonly result.
explanation.concept: Ankylosing spondylitis is an inflammatory condition of the spine and sacroiliac joints, leading to insidious back pain in patients typically younger than age 40 years. The pain is worse at night and i

vignette.presentation:
21. A 67-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after a 25-minute episode of right facial droop, weakness of the right arm
and hand, and an inability to talk. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, chronic atrial fibrillation, and gout. Her
medications include metoprolol, fosinopril, glyburide, and allopurinol. Her pulse is 80/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 18/min, and
blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Cardiac examinat ion shows no murmurs. Sensation is decreased to pinprick in the distal lower extremities.
Achilles tendon reflexes are decreased. The remainder of the neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. A CT scan of the head shows no
areas of infarction or hemorrhage . Echocardiography shows dilation of the left atrium with thrombus in the left atrial appendage, left ventricular
hypertrophy, and mild mitral regurgitation. Carotid ultrasonography shows mild stenosis of both the right and left internal carotid arteries without
thrombus or ulceration. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prevent similar episodes in the future?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prevent similar episodes in the future?

choices.text: Cataplexy G) Simple partial (motor) seizure with generalization
Complex partial seizure H) Simple partial (motor) seizure without generalization
Migraine I) Simple partial (sensory) seizure with generalization
Panic attack J) Simple partial (sensory) seizure without generalization
Primary generalized seizure L) Transient ischemic attack

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Transient ischemic attack is defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia without evidence of infarction. This patient has multiple risk factors for ischemic stroke including hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, atherosclerotic disease, and atrial fibrillation. An embolic ischemic stroke involves an event in which a clot breaks off and travels to the brain, occluding blood flow at a cerebral artery. Emboli can come from proximal vessels, such as the internal carotid artery, or from an atrial thrombus. This patient has an atrial thrombus, which can embolize and cause an ischemic stroke. After a transient ischemic attack, measures for prevention of an ischemic stroke should be enacted. In this patient with atrial fibrillation and a known atrial thrombus, an anticoagulant would be the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to help prevent ischemic stroke. Warfarin is an anticoagulant that interferes with the carboxylation of coagulation factors. This occurs through the inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is necessary for recycling vitamin K, an essentia l cofactor in the synthesis of coagulation factors in the liver.

distractor_explanations.C: is a phosphodiesterase Ill (PDE3) inhibitor, which reduces the degradation of cAMP in platelets and vascular smooth muscle cells resulting in the inhibition of platelet aggregation and vasodilation. Ticlopidine (
distractor_explanations.D: is also an antiplatelet agent that inhibits platelet aggregation. It is not commonly used because of adverse effects of neutropenia and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.
