24. A 67-year-o ld man is brought to the physician by his wife because of a 6-week history of progressive cognitive changes and "twitching movements"
of his arms and legs. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild
ataxic dysarthria. Muscle strength is 5/5 throughout. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ throughout. He has an ataxic gait and frequent irregular jerks of
the upper and lower extremities. On mental status examination , he is alert but distractible. His Mini-Mental State Examination score is 19/30. A
lumbar puncture is performed. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows:
Glucose 80 mg/dl
Total protein 45 mg/dl
WBC none
RBC none
An MRI of the brain shows vague areas of abnormal T2 signal in the basal ganglia; these areas have no mass effect and do not enhance.
Additiona l CSF analysis is most likely to show which of the following abnormalities?

Positive herpes simplex polymerase chain reaction test

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's signs and symptoms of rapidly progressive deme ntia, myoclonus, and ataxia are consistent with a diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a neurodegenerative prion disorder characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins. CJD common ly develops sporadically but may be inherited or acquired through transmissible prion particles. In prion disorders, misfolded proteins induce the misfolding of normal, native proteins, leading to a rapid intracellular accumulation of the misfolded variant and to neuronal cell death. CJD produces spongiform encephalopathy identifiable as neuronal vacuolization on brain biopsy, along with MRI signal abnorma lities typically in the basal ganglia. CSF typically contains an increased concentration of 14-3-3 protein. CJD is uniformly fatal and most patients die within 1 year of symptom onset.

Patients with leptomeningeal disease often manifest decreased concentrations of CSF glucose. vignette.presentation:
25. A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of gradual hearing loss in the left ear. She also has had difficulty
maintaining her balance over the past 3 months. Six months ago, she had an episode of nephrolithiasis complicated by a severe urinary tract
infection requiring intravenous antibiotic therapy. Examination shows a decrease of the left nasolabial fold and a slight perioral droop when she
smiles. The forehead movements are intact bilaterally. Her gait is normal, but she has difficulty with tandem walking. Audiomet ry shows moderate
high-frequency hearing loss on the left with impaired speech discrimination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient most likely has an acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) compressing the vestibulocochlear nerve and the upper motor neurons that synapse on the facial nerve. Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors consisting of Schwann cells that arise from the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII). Lesions of the vestibulocochlear nerve typically disrupt ipsilateral hearing and the sensation of head and body position, which leads to difficulty with balance and tandem (heel-to-toe) gait as in this patient. Mass effect from progressive ly enlarging acoustic neuromas can compress the neighboring facial nerve or the upper motor neurons synapsing on the facial nerve, leading to a flattened nasolabial fold and perioral droop. If the upper motor neurons are affected, the forehead is spared, as the facial nerve nucleus that controls forehead musculature is dually innervated by upper motor neurons from bilateral precentral gyri. Because of this, the patient would be expected to symmetrically raise her eyebrows. Alternatively, lesions involving the lower motor neurons of facial expression (eg, facial nerve inflammation in Bell palsy) affect the forehead and lower face together. Depending on patient age, tumor size, and symptom burden, acoustic neuromas can be managed with observation, radiation, or surgery.

distractor_explanations.B: can damage the cochlea or the vestibular organs. However, facial nerve palsy and the onset of vestibular symptoms months after aminoglycoside exposure would be atypical. Brain stem infarction (
distractor_explanations.C: could lead to variable cranial nerve dysfunction. However, the onset would be acute and the cranial nerve deficits would occur simultaneously. This patient instead ,experienced slowly progressive cranial nerve dysfunction over months. Mastoiditis (
distractor_explanations.D: refers to an infection of the mastoid air cells in the mastoid bone, typically resulting from middle ear infection in children and presenting with acute ear pain and postauricular tenderness. Transient hearing loss may occur and vestibular dysfunction .... r ~ -- - -, - - -- - - - - - - - - -- - -- - - - -- - - - - - r,

Acoustic neuromas can cause ipsilateral hearing loss and positional dizziness and, if compressing the facial nerve, can lead to facial nerve palsy. .,.

vignette.presentation:
26. A previous ly healthy 4 ?-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of progressively severe bifrontal headache. He has a
scant beard and a sallow, waxy complexion. Examination shows bilateral temporal hemianopia. Visual acuity is normal. Which of the following is
the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Occipital neuralgia K) Temporomandibular joint syndrome

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's findings of headache and bitemporal hemianopsia are consistent with a diagnosis of pituitary adenoma. Benign adenomas are the most common neoplasms identified in the pituitary gland, and may secrete hormones, such as prolactin or growth hormone, causing symptoms of hyperpituitarism. More common ly, pituitary mass lesions do not cause hyperpituitarism but instead cause compression of normal pituitary neurons, leading to hypopituitarism and dysfunction of multiple endocrine axes. The pituitary gland rests in the bony sella turcica, just inferior to the optic chiasm. Retinal ganglion cell fibers from the nasal retina, which supply the temporal visual fields, decussate at the chiasm, and are vulnerable to compression by pituitary mass lesions. Since the decussating nasal retinal fibers carry information from the temporal visual fields, the resultant visual field deficit is most commonly a bitemporal hemianopsia, a finding suggestive of a pituitary mass.
explanation.educational_objective: Pituitary adenomas are benign lesions of the pituitary gland and present with headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, and either hypopituitarism or hyperpituitarism. Retinal ganglion cell fibers from the nasal retina, which supply the temporal visual fields, decussate at the optic chiasm, and are vulnerable to compression by pituitary mass lesions.

27. A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of worsening excessive daytime sleepiness, even during important
events such as meetings at work. She says she has trouble sustaining her attention and that her symptoms are beginning to impair her work
productivity. She also reports occasional episodes in which her muscles go limp and she falls suddenly. She has injured herself during two of these
episodes. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 59 kg (130 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Her pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood
pressure is 120/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnorma lities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in
management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder characterized by daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis that responds to modafinil therapy. Narcolepsy arises from deficient production of orexins in the hypothalamus, which may result from genetic or autoimmune causes. Orexins typically induce the secretion of monoamines such as norepinephrine throughout the brain to promote wakefulness. As a result, patients suddenly and inappropriate ly transition into sleep during the day. Further, rapid-eye movement (REM) sleep features (eg, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis) occur during wakefulness. Cataplexy refers to a sudden loss of muscle tone and usually occurs in response to positive emotion. The clinical diagnosis should be confirmed by a polysomnography (to confirm the rapid transition into REM sleep and rule out other causes of daytime sleepiness) and a multiple sleep latency test (to confirm decreased sleep latency). Treatment includes a regular sleep schedule, avoidance of daytime naps, and, in patients with severe daytime sleepiness, modafinil. Modafinil has an unclear mechanism of action that involves increasing orexin and monoamine availability.

distractor_explanations.A: , continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) (
distractor_explanations.B: , and uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (
distractor_explanations.F: all target obstructive sleep apnea. Obstructive sleep apnea features repetitive obstruction of the pharyngeal airway during sleep and typically occurs in older, male patients with obesity as a result of a combination of structural, vascular, and neuromuscular factors. Patients become hypoxemic several times nightly and experience fragmented sleep, leading to daytime sleepiness. REM sleep phenomena during wakefulness is instead consistent with narcolepsy. In patients with suspected narcolepsy, comorbid obstructive slee a nea should be ruled out with ol somno ra h .

explanation.educational_objective: Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder that involves deficient orexin secretion, leading to the intrusion of sleep phenomena (eg, sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis) into times of wakefulness. Modafinil therapy, which likely increases orexin secretion, is the first-line medication for patients with severe daytime sleepiness. .,.

vignette.presentation:
28. A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a spinning sensation. She reports feeling as though the room is
spinning particularly when she tries to turn over in bed; the feeling usually resolves within 1 minute. She has no vomiting with an episode but does
feel a little queasy. Examination shows normal hearing. Ocular movements are full when the patient is sitting, but when her head is allowed to
hang off the examination table, she develops a coarse, rotatory nystagmus beating to one side. The remainder of the examination shows no
abnormalities. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is an abnormality at which of the following sites?

question_stem: The most likely cause of this patient's condition is an abnormality at which of the following sites?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a common cause of vertigo that occurs as a result of a calcium carbonate particle (otoconium) that gets displaced from the otolith organs into the adjacent semicircu lar canals. The otolith organs and semicircular canals are located in the inner ear and sense movement of the head. Normally, otoconia are contained within the matrix of the otolith organs, adding weight to the organs so that the organs shift in position when head position changes. When otoconia become dislodged, they cause abnormal movement of the endolymph within the semicircular canals and the subsequent sensation of head movement. Consequently, patients present with minutes-long, abrupt episodes of vertigo that may be accompanied by nausea, which resolve when holding still. The cochlear apparatus is intact, resulting in normal hearing. Symptom resolution with particle repositioning maneuvers such as the Epley maneuver serves to both diagnose and treat BPPV. Vertigo is the sensation that the surroundings are moving and is associated with lesions of the peripheral or central vestibular system. Peripheral vertigo is typically short-lived and sudden in onset, whereas central vertigo is insidious in onset and may cause constant and sustained vertigo. Peripheral causes of vertigo such as BPPV may also present with uni- or multidirectional nystagmus and may decrease as patients focus their gaze, while central causes of vertigo such as brainstem tumors or strokes typically lead to purely unidirectional nystagmus that does not improve with primary gaze.

distractor_explanations.A: , located in the temporal lobe, result in impairment of the conscious perception of auditory sensations. The vestibular cortices are instead distributed across the parietal and temporal cortices. A brain stem (
distractor_explanations.B: mass of the cerebellopontine angle (eg, acoustic neuroma, meningioma, glioma) typically affects the vestibulocochlear nerve and may also affect other cranial nerves (eg, trigeminal, abducens, facial nerves). The resulting vertigo would likely be insidious in onset and constant (rather than episodic); also likely to be accompanied by hearing loss. explanation.educational_objective: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is a common cause of vertigo that occurs as a result of a calcium carbonate particle (otoconium) that gets displaced from the otolith organs into the adjacent semicircular canals, leading to the erroneous sensation of position change. Patients typically present with episodic vertigo with nystagmus, nausea, and normal hearing. Particle repositioning maneuvers are key for diagnosis and treatment.

vignette.presentation:
29. A 10-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents after the Thanksgiving holiday break because of a 4-day history of rapid, irregular
involuntary movements of her face, trunk, and extremities. Her parents say that during this period, she has been anxious and irritable and has had
headaches. She seems to be worrying obsessively about things that formerly would not have worried her. She has no history of serious illness
except for migratory joint pain that occurred in the early fall. Examination shows restless-appearing, generalized involuntary movements of the
face, trunk, and extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Autoimmune disorder of the basal ganglia

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient likely has Sydenham chorea, which is a manifestation of an autoimmune disorder of the basal ganglia. The combination of choreiform movements and migratory joint pain suggest a diagnosis of rheumatic fever, a complication of Streptococcus pyogenes (group A) infection. Though arthritis is typically an early manifestation of acute rheumatic fever, Sydenham chorea is a latent manifestation and may occur months after the initial streptococcal infection. In acute rheumatic fever, streptococca l infection causes immune cross-reactivity with neuronal and cardiac cell membrane proteins and the deposition of immune complexes in the joints and soft tissues. The binding of antibodies to basal ganglia neurons results in choreiform movements (involuntary, random, irregular movements) of the face, trunk, and extremities that may be more prominent on one side of the body. Neuropsychiatric symptoms such as emotional !ability and obsessive-compulsive disorder (a disorder associated with basal ganglia pathology) may also occur. Sydenham chorea may occur as an isolated manifestation of acute rheumatic fever or in conjunction with arthritis, carditis, erythema marginatum, and/or subcutaneous nodules. As such, patients with Sydenham chorea should receive an echocardiography to evaluate for carditis. The treatment of acute rheumatic fever involves nonsteroida l anti-inflammatory drugs and penicillin to ensure the eradication of Streptococcus pyogenes (group A). Sydenham chorea is typically self-limited, but severe and impairing neuropsychiatric symptoms may be managed with antipsychotic or anticonvulsant medication.

distractor_explanations.B: , or functional neurologic disorder, involves acute neurologic symptoms such as sensory or motor dysfunction that are not fully explained by objective findings on physical examination or imaging. This patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are instead consistent with a known disease. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Group A streptococcal pharyngitis can be complicated with acute rheumatic fever, which may present with arthritis, Sydenham chorea, carditis, erythema marginatum, or subcutaneous nodules as a result of immune cross-reactivity. The binding of antibodies to basal ganglia neurons results in choreiform movements (involuntary, random, irregular movements) of the face, trunk, and extremities, and may also lead to mood !ability and obsessive-compulsive disorder.

vignette.presentation:
30. A 32-year-old woman with breast cancer metastatic to bone is brought to the emergency department because of a 12-hour history of severe pelvic
pain and numbness. She has not urinated for more than 24 hours. Her only medication is hydrocodone. On arrival, her temperature is
37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 152/70 mm Hg. Rectal examination shows decreased rectal
sphincter tone. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the lower extremities. Sensation to light touch is decreased in a saddle distribution. Abdominal
examination shows suprapubic fullness. Placement of a urinary catheter yields 800 ml of clear yellow urine and resolves the pelvic pain but not
the numbness. An MRI of the spine shows a tumor pushing into the L4-S 1 intrathecal space. Which of the following is the most appropriate
immediate next step in management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate
immediate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cauda equina syndrome occurs because of compression of the spinal nerve roots comprising the cauda equina. Often, such compression occurs as a result of malignancy, trauma (eg, compression fractures with fragment retropulsion), disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal epidural abscess, or spinal epidural or subdural hematoma. Symptoms include lower extremity numbness, weakness, paralysis, hyporeflexia, perinea! anesthesia, fecal incontinence with poor rectal tone, and overflow incontinence marked by inability to void and urinary retention. Emergent MRI of the lumbosacral spine is indicated to investigate the cause of cauda equina syndrome, and to determine the necessity of surgical decompression. Initial treatment for patients with epidural spinal cord compression and neurologic deficits include symptomatic treatment, pain control, and glucocorticoid therapy prior to operative therapy. High-dose glucocorticoid therapy (eg, dexamethasone) is helpful as a bridge to definitive therapy, can help control pain, and may transiently improve neurologic function secondary to decreasing edema at the site of cord compression.

distractor_explanations.A: may be helpful for pain control, but many patients may require opioid analgesics to control severe pain. In a patient who takes hydrocodone and is opiate-tolerant, pain control will likely require opioid analgesics. Intravenous or intrathecal administration of chemotherapy (Choices C and
distractor_explanations.D: or radiation therapy (
distractor_explanations.E: may all be helpful for definitive treatment of the tumor, but glucocorticoids are the

explanation.educational_objective: In patients with cauda equina syndrome, high-dose glucocorticoid therapy is helpful as a bridge to definitive therapy, can help control pain, and may transiently improve neurologic function secondary to decreasing edema at the site of cord compression. .,.

vignette.presentation:
31. A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband after he found her in a confused state when he returned home from
a 3-day fishing trip. She has a long-standing relapsing psychiatric condition controlled with lithium carbonate, haloperidol, and clonazepam. She
does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She appears drowsy. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 16/min, and
blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. The pupils are 2 mm and reactive. There is a coarse tremor of the upper extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are
increased throughout. She responds only to vigorous stimulation. On mental status examination, her speech is slow and slurred. She appears
perplexed and sleepy and does not respond to questions. Laboratory studies show:
Leukocyte count 14,000/mm3
Serum
Urea nitrogen 60 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.5 mg/dL
Lithium 3.5 mEq/dL (therapeutic range=0.6-1.2)
In addition to discontinuing lithium carbonate, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient presents with signs and symptoms of lithium toxicity including confusion, neuromuscular excitability, coarse tremors, and myoclonic jerks. Severe lithium toxicity can cause seizures, status epilepticus, and encephalopathy. Lithium is also associated with kidney toxicity and end-stage kidney disease. Lithium is filtered in the glomerulus and is reabsorbed in the proximal tubules. Increased lithium reabsorption can occur in states of volume depletion and decreased lithium clearance can occur in kidney impairment. Management of lithium toxicity includes intravenous fluid resuscitation to maximize lithium clearance. Hemodialysis may be necessary in patients with severe lithium toxicity, seizures, altered mental status, or end-stage kidney disease resulting in impaired ability to excrete lithium.

distractor_explanations.A: would be inappropriate in this patient with severe lithium toxicity. Lithium is primarily excreted in the urine, which would be impaired in this patient with acute kidney injury. Therefore, in this case, lithium should be cleared by hemodialysis. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Hemodialysis may be necessary in patients with severe lithium toxicity, seizures, altered mental status, or end stage kidney disease resulting in the impaired ability to excrete lithium. .,.
explanation.concept: Hemodialysis may be necessary in patients with severe lithium toxicity, seizures, altered mental status, or end stage kidney disease resulting in the impaired ability to excrete lithium. .,.

vignette.presentation:
32. A previously healthy 62-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of intermittent drooping of his left eyelid and episodes of
double vision. Neurologic examinat ion shows bilateral ptosis, more prominent on the left. There is weakness of left eye abduction and adduction
and weakness of right eye abduction. Pupillary reflexes are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is at
greatest risk for which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting findings of intermittent ptosis, diplopia, and reduction of extraocular movements are suggestive of myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis is a B lymphocyte-driven autoimmune disorder characterized by the formation of inhibitory anti-acetylcholine receptor autoantibodies. Patients typically experience muscular weakness and fatigue that worsens toward the end of the day, as well as ocular symptoms of drooping eyelids and diplopia. Many patients present with ocular findings and later develop generalized symptoms involving the proximal muscles. In severe exacerbations (myasthenic crises), patients may develop weakness of the muscles of the throat, diaphragm, and chest wall, leading to dysphagia and acute respiratory failure. Myasthenia gravis is diagnosed with the detection of serum autoantibodies. A chest x-ray is useful for detecting the presence of thymoma, which frequently produces myasthenia gravis as a paraneoplastic phenomenon. Some patients experience resolution of symptoms after surgical resection of a thymoma, although most patients require treatment with corticosteroids and acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (eg, pyridostigmine). Myasthenic crisis is treated with intravenous immune globulin, plasmapheresis, intubation, and mechanical ventilation.

distractor_explanations.A: is common in elderly patients, but rarely produces orbital metastases. Colon cancer more frequent ly metastasizes to the liver. While colon cancer may produce paraneoplastic findings, such as the Leser-Trelat sign, characterized by the sudden appearance of numerous seborrheic keratosis on the back and trunk, it does not typically cause myasthenia gravis. Lymphoma (
distractor_explanations.B: may occur in the orbit, typically involving the conjunctiva or the orbital adnexal tissues such as the lacrimal gland, extraocular muscles, and eyelids. Patients typically present with unilateral proptosis and may present with ptosis or diplopia. However, these symptoms would be progressive and unremitting, rather than intermittent. Prostate cancer (
distractor_explanations.C: is common in elderly males and may rarely cause paraneoplastic syndromes. However, it does not typically .... r ~ -- - - , -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - -- - r,

explanation.educational_objective: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by the formation of inhibitory anti acetylcholine receptor autoantibodies. Common symptoms include muscular weakness, fatigue, diplopia, and ptosis that worsens toward the end of the day, along with dysphagia and potential respiratory distress. Patients may present with an associated thymoma.

vignette.presentation:
33. Over the past 3 months, a 60-year-o ld woman has had 2-minute episodes characterized by a rising sensation in the abdomen followed by loss of
awareness. During an episode, she stares, makes chewing movements, and makes fumbling moveme nts with her hands; afterwards, she is
confused for a few minutes. Visual fields are shown. Neurologic examination shows no other abnormalities. The most likely diagnosis is a lesion at
which of the following locations?

question_stem:
The most likely diagnosis is a lesion at
which of the following locations?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's visual fields demonstrate a left superior field quadrantanopia. In conjunction with her symptoms of seizures, characterized by staring, chewing movements, automatisms of the hands, and postictal confusion, a left superior field quadrantanopia raises concern for a lesion of the right tempora l lobe, such as an astrocytoma. After decussating at the optic chiasm, retinal ganglion cell axons carrying information from the left visual field traverse the optic radiations and synapse at the lateral geniculate nucleus. Neurons from the lateral geniculate nucleus travel to the primary visual cortex via the optic radiations, which divide into superior and inferior divisions.

distractor_explanations.A: contains the frontal eye fields, which are important in the generation of eye movements. Lesions affecting the frontal eye fields can produce an ipsilateral conjugate gaze preference but do not produce visual field deficits. The occipital lobe (
distractor_explanations.B: is the location of the primary visual cortex. Lesions of the occipital lobe produce homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. The optic nerve (
distractor_explanations.C: carries all the visual information from the retina of its respective eye. A lesion of the optic nerve, such as in the setting of glioma, demyelinating optic neuritis, or trauma, produces a complete visual field defect of one eye. The parietal lobe (
distractor_explanations.D: contains the superior division of the optic radiation, which carries information from the inferior visual fields. A unilateral lesion of the parietal lobe may produce a contralateral inferior visual field quadrantanopia.

explanation.educational_objective: Temporal lobe lesions that interrupt the Meyer loop of the inferior division of the optic radiation produce a characteristic contralateral superior visual field quadrantanopia. Superior visual field quadrantanopia in conjunction with symptoms of seizures should raise suspicion for a mass of the temporal lobe, such as an astrocytoma. .,.
explanation.concept: Temporal lobe lesions that interrupt the Meyer loop of the inferior division of the optic radiation produce a characteristic contralateral superior visual field quadrantanopia. Superior visual field q

vignette.presentation:
34. A previously healthy 57-year-old man comes for a follow-up examination because of progressive weakness of his arms and legs. Six months ago,
examination showed no abnormalities except for 4/5 muscle strength in all extremities. Current examination shows fasciculations in the hands and
right lower extremity and pseudobulbar palsy. Sensation is normal and cranial nerves are intact. He is oriented, and affect is appropriate. An MRI of
the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's disease?

question_stem: the most likely mechanism of this patient's disease?

choices.text: Neoplastic infiltration of the central nervous system
Neuronal loss in the substantia nigra

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder arising in midlife that affects both lower motor neurons arising from the anterior horn and upper motor neurons of the lateral corticospinal tract within the brain and spinal cord. Neurons degenerate because of an unknown etiology that may involve RNA processing and/or excitotoxicity, and gliosis results. Patient presentations are variable, though typically feature a combination of upper motor neuron (eg, increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron findings (eg, decreased muscle tone, hyporeflexia, early muscle atrophy) in an asymmetric distribution that may include the bulbar muscles. Some patients may experience cognitive or behavioral changes, though other patients are cognitively normal. The diagnosis is primarily clinical but may be supported by electromyographic findings of acute and chronic denervation and reinnervation. MRI of the brain and spine should be performed to rule out other diseases. Treatment should include riluzole, which may modestly improve survival but does not cure the disease.

distractor_explanations.A: occurs in Alzheimer disease. Alzheimer disease may feature apraxia (potentially related to parietal cortex damage) but does not typically lead to upper neuron or lower motor neuron dysfunction. Demyelination (
distractor_explanations.B: occurs in acute conditions such as pontine myelinolysis and chronic autoimmune disorders such as multiple sclerosis. Demyelination can affect the white matter of the corticospinal tract but would not affect the anterior horns (gray matter). Neoplastic infiltration of the central nervous system (
distractor_explanations.D: may lead to localized upper motor neuron dysfunction because of mass effect. However, generalized dysfunction in both an upper and lower motor neuron pattern is more consistent with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder arising in midlife that affects both lower motor neurons arising from the anterior horn and upper motor neurons of the lateral corticospina l tract within the brain and spinal cord. Patients typically present with dysfunction of both upper motor neurons (eg, increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign) and lower motor neurons (eg, decreased muscle tone, hyporeflexia, early muscle atrophy) in an asymmetric distribution.

vignette.presentation:
35. A 62-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of a 3-year history of progressive forgetfulness. He has difficulty remembering
names, especially of people he has recently met. He retired from his profession as a retail clerk 12 weeks ago because he had been forgetting the
names of customers and new products and could no longer effectively perform his job. He also has had progressive difficulty with activities of daily
living; his wife now chooses his clothes for him. He has no history o1f head trauma. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications.
He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he has an indifferent
mood and affect. He is oriented to person, place, and time but takes a few minutes before he correctly names the date. His Mini-Mental State
Examination score is 22/30. There is no evidence of auditory or visual hallucinations. Results of laboratory studies are within the reference ranges.
Administration of a drug from which of the following classes is most appropriate for this patient?

question_stem: most appropriate for this patient?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Alzheimer dementia (AD) results from decreased cholinergic signaling and is treated with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. Cholinergic neurons-which primarily originate from the locus coeruleus and basal forebrain and project widely to areas including the cortex mediate attention, learning, and memory. AD is the most prevalent dementia, presenting with progressive cognitive decline that begins with short-term memory impairment and decline in visuospatial abilities and progresses to apraxia, language abnormalities, and dysexecutive syndrome (resulting in the inability to pick out clothes in this patient). The disease culminates in behavioral and personality changes that prevent the patient from performing basic activities of daily living, such as bathing. Acetylcholinesterase normally hydrolyzes acetylcholine in synaptic clefts. Donepezil and other cholinesterase inhibitors non-competitively and reversibly inhibit acetylcholinesterase activity and thereby increase the amount of synaptic acetylcholine available for neurotransmission. Though donepezil may slow the rate of cognitive decline and modestly improve functiona lity, donepezil and the other cholinesterase inhibitors are not curative.

distractor_explanations.B: increase dopamine signaling and therefore relieve parkinsonism. This patient does not demonstrate motor findings typical of Parkinson disease such as tremor, bradykinesia, or postural instability. NMDA receptor agonists (
distractor_explanations.C: , such as endogenous glutamate, mediate activity-dependent synaptic changes of learning and memory. However, NMDA agonism is not a known drug mechanism because of the risk for excitotoxicity. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Alzheimer dementia results from decreased cholinergic signaling in the cortex and basal forebrain. Alzheimer dementia is the most prevalent dementia, presenting with progressive cognitive decline that culminates in the inability to perform basic activities of daily living. Cholinesterase inhibitors, such as donepezil, are the first-line treatment. .,.
explanation.concept: Alzheimer dementia results from decreased cholinergic signaling in the cortex and basal forebrain. Alzheimer dementia is the most prevalent dementia, presenting with progressive cognitive decline that

vignette.presentation:
36. A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 20 minutes after he was found by a janitor on the floor of a restroom at
a bus station. At the scene, he was having continuous, generalized tonic-clonic seizures. An endotracheal tube was placed, and supplementa l
oxygen was administered. On arrival to the emergency department, he is flushed and diaphoretic. There are no external signs of trauma. His
temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. The pupils are 4 mm and reactive to
light. Examination shows tonic stiffening of the trunk and synchronous clonic jerking of the extremities. In addition to intravenous administration of
dextrose, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in treatment?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Status epilepticus is defined as continuous epileptic activity for at least five minutes, or at least two discrete seizures with incomplete interval recovery of consciousness. Status epilepticus is a neurologic emergency that portends increased morbidity and requires prompt evaluation and treatment. The first-line treatment for convulsive status epilepticus involves benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam, midazolam, or diazepam), which have been shown to control seizures rapidly. Benzodiazepines bind the GABAA receptor, a chloride channel, and increase the frequency of its opening. y-Aminobutyric acid (GABA) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that counterbalances neuronal excitation, making benzodiazepines an effective treatment for seizure cessation.

distractor_explanations.A: blocks sodium channels and is typically a second-line choice in the treatment of status epilepticus. Benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment of convulsive status epilepticus. Naloxone (
distractor_explanations.C: is an opioid receptor antagonist used in the treatment of opiate or opioid overdoses, which classically present with bradypnea and pinpoint pupils. Naloxone has also been used to treat clonidine overdose. Phenobarbital (
distractor_explanations.D: can be effective for controlling seizures, however it is not the first-line pharmacotherapy as a result of slow administration and adverse effects of prolonged sedation and hypotension. Valproic acid (
distractor_explanations.E: increases sodium channel inactivation and increases GABA concentration. It is typically second-line in the treatment of status epilepticus. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment of convulsive status epilepticus. .,.
explanation.concept: Benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment of convulsive status epilepticus. .,.

vignette.presentation:
37. A previously healthy 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 10-day history of increasingly severe headaches. The
pain has been unremitting for the past 18 hours; he describes it as severe and pounding. His pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood
pressure is 142/90 mm Hg. Examination of the face and neck shows mild swelling and a dusky reddish-purple skin color with venous distention
over the head and neck; the skin color below the neck is normal. Examinat ion of the optic fundi shows papilledema. Neurologic examination shows
no focal findings. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's increased intracranial pressure?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's increased intracranial pressure?

choices.text: Obstruction of cerebrospina l fluid flow
Obstruction of venous return to the heart
Obstruction of venous return to the heart

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Obstruction of venous return to the heart through the superior vena cava (SVC) leads to superior vena cava syndrome, which presents with facial swelling, headaches, and occasionally altered mental status or respiratory distress. Superior vena cava syndrome is most commonly caused by extrinsic compression of the SVC by an intrathoracic malignancy, such as lung cancer or lymphoma. Physical examination typically shows facial plethora, venous distension over the head and neck, and papilledema, as in this patient. While a chest x-ray may be abnormal, CT venography is typically diagnostic. Stent placement and radiation therapy are used to treat symptoms, but superior vena cava syndrome is classically associated with a poor prognosis.

distractor_explanations.A: is associated with the development of migraine headaches, which present with unilateral, pounding-type headaches that are associated with photophobia and phonophobia. They typically last for less than 48 to 72 hours and may have a preceding aura. They do not cause facial plethora and venous distension. An intracranial mass lesion (
distractor_explanations.B: classically presents with focal neurologic deficits, such as hemiplegia, altered mental status, and signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as headache and nausea. Physical examination may demonstrate papilledema. However, it would not be expected to cause discoloration of the face or venous distension of the head and neck. Obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid flow (
distractor_explanations.C: and overproduction of cerebrospinal fluid (
distractor_explanations.E: can both lead to hydrocephalus. Hydrocephalus commonly presents with headache, altered mental status or behavior, and nausea or vomiting because of increased intracranial pressure. While papilledema may be present, venous distension would not be. - .... r ~- - - ,- - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - - - -- - - -- - - - - -- -- - - -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - - - - - r - - - -, - - - - - - - -

explanation.educational_objective: Superior vena cava syndrome is most common ly caused by an intrathoracic malignancy, such as lung cancer or lymphoma, that causes extrinsic compression of the SVC. This leads to increased intracranial pressure with headaches, nausea, and papilledema, as well as facial plethora and venous congestion of the head and neck. .,.
explanation.concept: Superior vena cava syndrome is most common ly caused by an intrathoracic malignancy, such as lung cancer or lymphoma, that causes extrinsic compression of the SVC. This leads to increased intracranial

vignette.presentation:
38. Five days after a left hemicolectomy for colon cancer, a 62-year-old man is transferred to the intensive care unit because of temperatures to
40.6°C (105°F), lethargy, diaphoresis, and labile blood pressure for 3 hours. His postoperative course had been complicated by temperatures to
37.8°C (100°F) and nocturnal agitation since day 2; he has required haloperidol therapy (2 mg nightly). He has a history of bipolar disorder.
Medications include morphine by patient-controlled analgesia pump, lithium carbonate, and clonazepam. He is lying expressionless in a pool of
sweat and is drooling. His temperature is 40.6°C (105°F), pulse is 140/min, and blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. Examination shows wet skin
and dry mucosa. There is a herpetic lesion on his lower lip. The neck is supple and the intravenous catheter insertion site is nontender with no

NMS is a life-threatening condition associated with the antagonism of dopamine that presents with altered mental status, muscle rigidity or tremor, hyperthermia, and autonomic dysfunction. Common causative agents are antipsychotics (especia lly high-potency antipsychotics

usual migraines that have improved since she started treatment with propranolol. Funduscopic examination shows no abnorma lities of the right
eye, but the patient cannot read and can barely count fingers with the right eye. Visual acuity in the left eye is normal. A CT scan of the head

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Optic neuritis results from autoimmune demyelinating inflammation of the optic nerve and presents in young, often female, patients with unilatera l vision loss and pain that is exacerbated with extraocular movements. Ocular examination demonstrates reduced visual acuity and color vision, a relative afferent pupillary defect, and may demonstrate optic disc edema. Diagnosis is confirmed with MRI demonstrating hyperintensity of the optic nerve. Patients with optic neuritis are at increased risk for multiple sclerosis (MS), and optic neuritis is a common initial finding in patients with MS. Recently, autoantibodies against myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) and aquaporin-4 (AQP4) have been identified as causative of some cases of optic neuritis. Patients who develop optic neuritis as a result of antibodies against MOG and AQP4 often have severe presentations but also have decreased risk for subsequent MS compared to patients with optic neuritis who lack these autoantibodies. The Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial demonstrated that a short course of treatment with high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone speeds the rate of visual recovery and delays the onset of MS, although it does not impact final visual acuity, and demonstrated that the presence and quantity of periventricular white matter lesions on MRI is the most important prognostic risk factor for the subsequent development of MS.

distractor_explanations.A: results from microvascular damage to retinal capillaries and is characterized by the presence of microaneurysms, intraretinal hemorrhages, and retinal nerve fiber layer infarctions. Diabetic retinopathy is usually symmetric between both eyes and is not painful. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Optic neuritis is an autoimmune, inflammatory disorder of the optic nerve that presents with acute onset vision loss and ocular pain that is exacerbated with extraocular movements. Patients typically present with profoundly decreased visual acuity and color vision, along with a relative afferent pupillary defect. Diagnosis is confirmed with MRI and with testing for serum autoantibodies. MRI provides important prognostic information regarding the subsequent risk for developing multiple sclerosis, which commonly occurs in association with optic neuritis. Treatment with high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone speeds visual recovery and delays the onset of multiple sclerosis.

and opening jars. He has not had pain or tingling. He has had constipation but no changes in bladder or sexual function. He has not had any
recent infections or vaccinations. He takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He drinks three to four beers
daily; for the past 6 weeks he has been drinking home-distilled whiskey. Examination shows atrophy of the intrinsic muscles of the hands and feet.
Muscle strength is 4/5 in the wrist and finger extensors, interosseous, iliopsoas, and hamstring muscles and 3/5 in the anterior tibialis, peronei, and
posterior tibial is muscles. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ diffusely. Babinski sign is absent. Sensory examination shows no abnorma lities. Laboratory
studies show microcytic anemia and hyperuricemia . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's neurologic symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Symptoms of acute lead poisoning occur within days or weeks of exposure and include abdominal pain, constipation, arthralgia, myalgias, muscle weakness, excessive fatigue, headache, and difficulty concent rating. With prolonged exposure, chronic neurologic symptoms such as decline in cognition, depression, distal motor neuropathy, decreased hearing, tremor, and decreased brain volume on imaging may be present. The distal motor neuropathy causes lower motor neuron signs such as atrophy of muscles and hyporeflexia, as shown in this patient. Microcytic anemia is also common, since lead inhibits the enzymes ferrochelatase and o-ALA dehydratase, resulting in decreased heme synthesis. In adults, exposure to lead primarily comes through occupation and/or hobbies. Individuals working with batteries, mining, construction , or ammunition are at higher risk. Illegally distilling alcohol has a risk for lead toxicity because of the leaching of lead from solder in the still, which is likely where this patient received exposure. Diagnosis is suspected based on exposure and symptoms and confirmed with increased serum lead concentration. Management of lead poisoning depends on the blood lead concentration and presence of symptoms, and includes chelation with dimercaprol, ethylene diamine tetraacetate, or succimer. Sources of lead should be investigated and eliminated.

distractor_explanations.A: is an autosoma l dominant disorder caused by inactivating mutations of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase, resulting in deficient synthesis of heme and accumulation of porphobilinogen. Patients typically present during an acute attack with psychosis, abdominal pain, muscle weakness, neuropathy, and burgundy-colored urine. This patient's subacute presentation in the context of alcohol distillation is more consistent with lead poisoning. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Neurologic manifestations of lead poisoning include cognitive dysfunction, encephalopathy, hearing loss, and peripheral neuropathy. Distal motor neuropathy causes lower motor neuron signs including weakness, atrophy, hypotonia, and hyporeflexia. Other manifestations of lead poisoning include renal tubular dysfunction, vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, and anemia.

show a fracture dislocation of T10. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's urinary incontinence?

choices.text: Compression of the S3-4 nerve roots

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: An injury at the level of the thoracic spinal cord would affect the thoracic cord and may also affect segments distal to the level of the injury, including the lumbosacral segments that innervate lower extremity musculature and sensation. An injury at the level of T10 can affect sympathetic efferent fibers that provide inhibitory input to the bladder and urethra via the hypogastric nerve. Sympathetic stimulation through these fibers usually causes relaxation of bladder musculature and contraction of urethral sphincter, resulting in urinary retention. Injury to these fibers will cause urinary incontinence as a result of impaired inhibition of bladder contraction. Spinal cord pathologies that result in urinary incontinence result in complex interactions between signals from the parasympathetic, sympathetic, and somatic nervous systems and may present with urge or overflow incontinence, altogether termed neurogenic bladder.

distractor_explanations.A: often occurs at the level of L2. It can also present with sphincter dysfunction, spastic or flaccid paralysis, as well as saddle anesthesia. An injury at T10 would be unlikely to affect the conus medullaris. Compression of the S3-4 nerve roots (

distractor_explanations.C: would result in a thoracic radiculopathy in a dermatomal distribution resulting in pain and numbness around the umbilicus. Rupture of the bladder neck (
distractor_explanations.E: would present with hematuria, pelvic pain, lower abdominal pain, and difficulty voiding. It would be unlikely to be the cause of the patient's urinary incontinence and would not present with lower extremity neurologic symptoms.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: An epidural abscess is a localized collection of pus in the epidural space between the dura mater and periosteum. It most commonly occurs in the spine but may occur in the brain. Most patients are elderly and have a history of concomitant infection and often have a history of immunocompromise (eg, diabetes mellitus, HIV infection, alcohol use disorder). Epidural abscess is more common in patients with a history of intravenous drug use. Infectious organisms usually spread to the epidural space hematogenously, from spinal surgery, or from adjacent osteomyelitis. Staphylococcus aureus is a frequent causative organism, but fungal infections also occur. Patients present with signs and symptoms of fever, altered mental status, meningismus, localized back pain and tenderness to palpation, and weakness, numbness, and paralysis below the affected spinal level. Treatment is with broad spectrum antibiotics and surgical drainage of the abscess.

distractor_explanations.D: may result from meningeal bacterial, viral, or fungal infection, and presents with fever, meningismus and altered mental status. It is less likely to produce focal neurologic defects such as the lower extremity weakness and reduced pinprick noted in .... r ~- - - , - - - r,

It presents with fever, altered mental status, meningismus, localized back pain, and tenderness to palpation, along with weakness, numbness, and paralysis below the affected spinal level. Treatment is with broad spectrum antibiotics and surgical drainage of the abscess. .,.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Electrophysiological studies are utilized to diagnose ulnar neuropathy. Ulnar neuropathy typically arises from ulnar nerve entrapment at the elbow or wrist, which may occur idiopathically or because of trauma, compression, or elbow joint pathology. While ulnar nerve entrapment at the elbow typically results in numbness and paresthesia of the medial hand and wrist, ulnar nerve entrapment at the wrist typically leads to weakness of the intrinsic hand muscles and the consequent loss of hand dexterity. The ulnar nerve innervates the palmaris brevis, hypothenar, lumbrical, interossei, and adductor pollicis muscles. As a result of adductor pollicis dysfunction, patients illustrate a decreased ability to pinch the first two digits together. As a result of interossei muscle dysfunction, this patient is unable to fully abduct or adduct the digits. Sensory dysfunction in the ulnar distribution may result from ulnar entrapment at the wrist as well. Electrophysiological studies (eg, nerve conduction studies or electromyography) confirm the clinical diagnosis. Management begins with conservative methods (eg, activity modification) but may include surgical decompression for severe or refractory symptoms.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Bacterial meningitis presents with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status, typically following a prodrome of upper respiratory tract infection symptoms, although it can also be concomitant with another infection. Physical examination may disclose a present Kernig or Brudzinski sign, indicative of meningeal irritation, and can also demonstrate focal neurologica l symptoms or signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as hemiparesis or abducens nerve palsy. Petechiae may be present. Laboratory evaluation will show leukocytosis, and coagulation studies can show signs of disseminated intravascular coagulopathy with thrombocytopenia, decreased fibrinogen, and increased d-dimer, depending on the specific pathogen. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) evaluation is the initial diagnostic step and will reveal an increased opening pressure, increased leukocyte count with prominent neutrophils, increased protein concentration, and decreased glucose concentration. Culture of the CSF is utilized to diagnose the specific bacterial cause and to distinguish between viral and fungal meningitides, or alternative diagnoses. The most common causes of bacterial meningitis in patients with asplenia, whether functiona l or operative, are Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis. Treatment involves immediate antibiotic therapy, accompanied by glucocorticoids.

She is mildly hypotensive, and administration of intravenous fluids and antibiotics is the most important immediate therapy. Norepinephrine is a more appropriate initial vasopressor used to treat septic shock. CT scan of the head (
distractor_explanations.C: may be utilized in the evaluation of bacterial meningitis. It is commonly done prior to a lumbar puncture for CSF analysis in patients with signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as seizure, decreased level of consciousness, focal neurologic deficits, or papilledema. It is done to rule out a central nervous system mass or increased intracranial pressure that may lead t h . t' • I b • t I b t . I . •' t' h t I' t . d • d t th d . . t t' f I t' b. t'

Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis are the most common causes in asplenic patients.

chair and climbing stairs; he finds it easier to arise from a chair if he rocks back and forth first. During this time, he has also had a persistent cough,
a 14-kg (30-lb) weight loss, and a dry mouth. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Examination shows weakness of hip
flexion and knee extens ion. There is no muscle tenderness . All reflexes are absent. Babinski sign is absent. Sensory examination shows no
abnorma lities. His erythrocyte sedimentat ion rate is 95 mm/h, and serum creatine kinase activity is 25 U/L. An x-ray of the chest shows a right
upper lobe mass. Which of the following is the most likely location of the abnorma lity?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome is an uncommon neurologic condition that affects neuromuscu lar junction transmission. Normally, action potentials lead to depolarization in the termina l bouton of the axon. Voltage-gated calcium channels consequently open and allow calcium influx, which triggers the exocytosis of neurotransmitter-fil led vesicles into the synaptic cleft. Patients with myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome possess antibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels on presynaptic lower motor neurons, which decreases calcium influx and acetylcholine release to postsynaptic skeletal muscle cells. This patient with a smoking history, persistent cough, weight loss, and increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate likely has small cell lung cancer and paraneoplastic autoantibody production against voltage-gated calcium channels, causing myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome. Patients consequent ly demonstrate progressive proxima l muscle weakness with depressed or absent deep tendon reflexes. The muscle weakness typically improves with exercise as small amounts of acetylcholine accumulate in the synaptic cleft over time, increasing the frequency of postsynaptic action potentials in skeletal muscle cells. Autonomic symptoms such as decreased salivation (and consequent dry mouth) may also occur. The diagnosis may be confirmed with nerve conduction studies and electromyography with exercise testing.

distractor_explanations.A: degeneration can be caused by poliovirus infection, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or spinal muscular atrophy (a congenital disease presenting with progressive anterior horn disease). Patients would present with a lower-motor neuron pattern of weakness with decreased reflexes. However, anterior horn cell disease is not associated with lung cancer. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Patients with myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome possess antibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels on presynaptic lower motor neurons, which decrease calcium influx and acetylcholine release to postsynaptic skeletal muscle cells. In some patients, tumors are associated with these antibodies, resulting in paraneoplastic myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome. Patients present with progressive proximal muscle weakness that improves with exercise and demonstrate a creatine kinase concentration within normal reference ranges.

with his antiretroviral medication regimen and has had a 16-kg (35-lb) weight loss. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 46 kg (101 lb); BMI is
15 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows
thrush. On mental status examination, he has a labile affect. He recalls zero of three objects after 5 minutes. A CT scan of the head shows

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a life-threatening demyelinating disease that occurs as a result of the reactivation of human polyomavirus 2 (formerly JC virus) in patients who are immunocompromised. Most people experience an asymptomatic infection with human polyomavirus 2 during childhood, at which point the virus becomes latent. In severely immunocompromised patients, human polyomavirus 2 can reactivate and infect oligodendrocytes, leading to demyelination. Patients typically present with the subacute onset of focal neurologic deficits related to the affected brain area and cognitive impairment. Patients who are immunocompromised enough to have PML may also present with symptoms of other opportunistic infections. This patient's thrush and potential Mycobacterium avium complex infection (which likely explains his fever, diarrhea, and weight loss) indicate severe immune compromise in the setting of decreased adherence to antiretroviral therapy. MRI may demonstrate unilateral or bilateral white matter lesions without mass effect indicative of demyelination, which may progress to cortical atrophy. Lumbar puncture and cerebrospina l fluid analysis confirm the diagnosis. Treatment requires restarting antiretroviral therapy.

distractor_explanations.A: , or primary CNS lymphoma, is a rare variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs most commonly in immunocompromised patients. Typical presentation includes focal neurological deficits, neuropsychiatric symptoms, or signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, positional headache, nausea, vomiting). MRI typically demonstrates a solitary mass lesion but can reveal multiple periventricular white matter mass lesions. Primary CNS lymphoma lesions do not involve demyelination and are more likely to produce a mass effect than PML lesions. Dementia, Alzheimer type (

Patients typically present with the subacute onset of focal neurologic deficits and cognitive impairment. MRI of the brain may demonstrate unilateral or bilateral white matter lesions indicative of demyelination and cortical atrophy.

48. A 77-year-o ld woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of a 3-day history of visual difficulties. He says she seems a little
"off balance." She agreed to come in after denting the car on the left side while parking it in the garage. She has not had any headaches or noticed
any difficulty using either side of her body. She has not fallen recently. She has a 2-year history of atrial fibrillation treated with aspirin. She is
sitting comfortab ly in a chair. Her temperatu re is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg.
Examination shows a left homonymous hemianopia. Muscle strength, muscle tone, and sensation are intact bilaterally. Speech is normal. She is
alert and oriented to person, place, and time. When asked to read, she only reads the words on the right side of the page. A CT scan of the head is
most likely to show an infarct in the territory of which of the following cerebral arteries?

question_stem: most likely to show an infarct in the territory of which of the following cerebral arteries?

choices.text: Aspirin therapy now and temporal artery biopsy within 24 hours
Corticosteroid therapy now and temporal artery biopsy within 3 days
Temporal artery biopsy now with therapy determined by pathology

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Occlusion of the right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) explains this patient's deficits. The PCA supplies much of the occipital lobes as well as the inferomedial temporal lobe, posteromedial parietal lobe, thalamus, and parts of the brainstem. Visual symptoms are a prominent feature of a PCA territory infarction and include cortical blindness, contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, visual agnosia, and prosopagnosia. Occlusion of the right PCA typically leads to left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing (caused by damage of the right primary visual cortex) and may lead to left hemineglect (caused by damage of the right parietal cortex). Left homonymous hemianopia likely explains this patient's car accident and may lead to mild balance difficulties. Occlusion of the right PCA may also result in left hemisensory deficit (caused by thalamus damage) and left hemiparesis (caused by damage to the cerebral peduncles in the midbrain). Cerebral infarctions, also known as strokes, occur as a result of ischemic or hemorrhagic loss of blood supply to the brain. Approximately 80% to 85% of strokes are ischemic, commonly arising from thromboembolic disease (eg, middle cerebral artery occlusion from a thrombus), whereas 15% to 20% of strokes are hemorrhagic because of blood vessel rupture (eg, hypertension-related intraparenchymal hemorrhage from a perforating artery). Risk factors for stroke include smoking, hypertension, diabetes, carotid or intracranial atherosclerotic disease, history of hypercoagulabi lity, atrial fibrillation, and advanced age. Classically, strokes manifest as a neurologic deficit related to the affected part of the brain.

distractor_explanations.D: supply the medial frontal lobes (primary motor and sensory cortices), which control the motor and sensor functions of the lower extremities. Occlusion of the anterior cerebral arter leads to contralateral

explanation.educational_objective: The posterior cerebral arteries (PCAs) supply the posterior parietal and occipital lobes (including the primary visual cortex) along with the thalamus and midbrain. Occlusion of the right PCA typically leads to left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing (caused by damage of the right primary visual cortex) and left contralateral hemineglect (caused by damage of the right parietal cortex).

Examination and laboratory studies show no other abnormalities. Toxicology

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neurocysticercosis is a central nervous system (CNS) infection caused by the pork tapeworm Taenia so/ium that occurs most commonly in endemic rural regions of Latin America, Asia, and Africa. Symptoms include headache, seizures, signs of increased intracranial pressure, and, rarely, altered vision. Certain patients are asymptomatic, and other patients present with muscle or subcutaneous nodules. Typical manifestations on CT or MRI include cystic, ring-enhancing, calcified lesions in the brain parenchyma, meninges, ventricles, spinal cord, or orbit. A scolex (larval head) may also be demonstrated on imaging. Treatment may include symptomatic management of increased intracranial pressure and seizures, antiparasitic therapy, or steroids.

1. A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of severe muscle cramping and weakness immediately following calisthenics
or after jogging a short distance. The cramping and weakness resolve within 24 hours. He also has dark urine during these episodes. Neurologic
examination, performed while he is asymptomatic, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Muscle phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle disease) is a glycogen storage disease that affects the muscles. It is characterized by the inability of myocytes to break down glycogen as a result of the absence of muscular glycogen phosphorylase, which causes exercise intolerance with fatigue, cramping, and muscle weakness. Muscle cramping may resolve with rest or be permanent. Occasionally, a "second wind" phenomenon may be seen when blood flow to the muscles increases after approximate ly 10 minutes of exercise, delivering fatty acids as fuel and relieving the need for glycogen breakdown. Patients may also have episodes of rhabdomyolysis, accompanied by red or brown urine and urinalysis positive for blood resulting from the presence of myoglobinuria without microscopic evidence of red blood cells. A complication of McArdle disease is acute kidney injury and acute tubular necrosis secondary to the release of nephrotoxic myoglobin and heme pigments in rhabdomyolysis. Treatment involves avoiding low-carbohydrate diets and improving cardiovascular fitness with regular, mild aerobic exercise.

distractor_explanations.A: refers to muscle breakdown induced by excessive alcohol consumption. Rhabdomyolysis is characterized by a triad of muscle pain, weakness, and dark urine. It may also be brought on by episodes of strenuous exercise, though jogging a short distance would not be expected to cause it. Hypokalemic periodic paralysis (
distractor_explanations.B: is characterized by episodes of painless muscle weakness brought on by heavy exercise. Episodes occur in association with low serum potassium concentration. Exercise intolerance with muscle cramping and myoglobinuria is more suggestive of a metabolic myopathy, like McArdle disease. Myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome (
distractor_explanations.D: is a paraneoplastic syndrome often caused by small cell carcinoma of the lung. Presynaptic calcium channel antibody production causes the proximal extremity weakness. A characteristic physical examination feature is the augmentation of strength with repetitive action, which is caused by progressive increases in calcium concentration. .... ~, r,

2. A 77-year-old woman with mild dementia, Alzheimer type, is brought to the emergency department by her daughter 3 hours after the sudden onset
of fearfulness and combativeness. The patient lives with her daughter and son-in-law. She attempted to smash their television screen with her
walker and struck her son-in-law when he tried to stop her. She has hypertension, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and diverticulosis. Her
medications are metoprolol, omeprazole, triamterene-hydrochlorothiazide, and donepezil. On arrival, she is hostile and accuses the physician of
trying to steal her money. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 144/82 mm Hg.
Physical examination shows restless movements. Mental status examination initially shows hypervigilance; the patient later appears drowsy. She
mutters under her breath as if responding to internal stimuli and picks at the air. Her Mini-Mental State Examination score is 10/30. Results of which
of the following diagnostic studies are most likely to be abnormal in this patient?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Urinalysis is likely to be abnormal in this patient with delirium, which is defined by an acute-onset alteration of consciousness and cognition, with symptoms that wax and wane throughout the day. In elderly patients, especially those with underlying dementia, systemic infection can rapidly lead to the development of delirium. Other common causes of delirium include intoxication and adverse effects from medications such as anticholinergics, benzodiazepines, or opiates. All patients with delirium should be evaluated for evidence of systemic infection with urinalysis and culture, chest x-ray, and occasional ly with blood cultures, if indicated. Treatment of delirium should focus on treatment of the underlying infection if one is detected, frequent reorientation, maintenance of normal sleep wake cycles, and placement of the patient in a calm and soothing environment.

This patient has no other evidence of either acute or chronic liver failure on examination; evaluation for an underlying infection is more appropriate. vignette.presentation:
3. A 77-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because she recently has become unable to take care of herself or walk independently.
Her son says that her ability to function has declined during the past 4 months, but she has not had any specific complaints. She has hypertension
treated with atenolol and enalapril. Her only other medication is 81-mg aspirin. Six years ago, she had a myocardial infarction. On examination, her
speech is confused. Her pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 145/86 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse muscle weakness. Gait testing shows an
inability to ambulate. She can recall one of three objects after 2 minutes. Results of laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. An MRI of
the brain shows multiple small infarctions throughout both cortices and a few in the thalamus. In addition to adjustments to her antihypertensive
medications , administration of which of the following is the most appropriate management?

question_stem: the most appropriate management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Multi-infarct (vascular) dementia refers to cognitive impairment that results from acute cerebral infarctions secondary to underlying cerebrovascular or thromboembolic disease. Patients with vascular dementia typically possess a history of clinical strokes with consequent focal neurologic deficits and a stepwise decline in function. Some patients alternatively demonstrate silent cerebrovascular disease, characterized by progressive neurologic decline and multiple small infarcts on neuroimaging, as in this patient. This patient possesses risk factors for cerebrovascular disease such as hypertens ion and atherosclerotic disease (as evidenced by a prior myocardial infarction). Diagnosis requires evidence of cerebrovascular disease (eg, clinical history of stroke or neuroimaging evidence of infarct) and cognitive impairment. Management requires secondary prevention of stroke via blood pressure control. In all patients with a stroke history and many patients with silent cerebrovascular disease, antiplatelet therapy with aspirin is required. However, this patient is already on aspirin for the secondary prevention of myocardial infarction, thus no additional medication is indicated.

This patient does not possess a history of acute ischemic stroke (eg, an abrupt neurologic change) but instead presents with silent cerebrovascular disease, and she does not demonstrate evidence of cardiac indications for chronic anticoagulation. Supplementation of vitamin E (
distractor_explanations.C: , an antioxidant, has not proven effective for the primary or secondary prevention of cardiovascular or cerebrovascular disease. ....

Patients typically present with stepwise cognitive decline and focal neurologic deficits, though patients with silent cerebrovascular disease may instead present with progressive neurologic decline. Management requires secondary prevention with antihypertensive and antiplatelet therapy. .,.

vignette.presentation:
4. A 62-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after the onset of double vision and left eye pain that she first noted when
she awoke. She describes a horizontal separation of images , which is worse for distant as opposed to near vision. She has an 18-year history of
type 2 diabetes mellitus. Examination of the left eye shows mild adduction on primary gaze with severe weakness of abduction with conjugate gaze
to the left. The remainder of the neurologic examination shows no abnormalities.
Correct Answer: E.
Microvascular damage resulting from diabetes mellitus can produce neuropathy, such as distal polyneuropathy, radiculopathy or, as in this case,
cranial nerve palsy. Common ly affected nerves include the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI), which presents with esotropia, unilateral abduction
deficit, and diplopia in horizonta l gaze, and the oculomotor nerve (crania l nerve Ill), which presents with unilateral ptosis, exotropia, and hypotropia.
Patients may experience associated ocular or periocular pain. It is important to exclude other possible causes of cranial nerve palsy, such as stroke,
increased intracranial pressure, vasculitis, or optic neuropathy. Most patients with microvascular abducens nerve palsy experience resolution of
symptoms over several months following treatment of the underlying cause.
Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, F, G, H, and I.
The cerebellum (Choice A) contains a variety of structures, including the vermis, flocculus, and paraflocculus, which are important for the
coordination of ocular saccades, pursuit movements, and gaze holding. Cerebellar lesions do not produce esotropia.

Exam Section: Item 4 of 50 National Board of Medical Examiners
Mark Clinical Neurology Self-Assessment Please Walt
...
Microvascular damage resulting from diabetes mellitus can produce neuropathy, such as distal polyneuropathy, radiculopathy or, as in this case,
cranial nerve palsy. Commonly affected nerves include the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI), which presents with esotropia, unilateral abduction
deficit, and diplopia in horizontal gaze, and the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve Ill), which presents with unilateral ptosis, exotropia, and hypotropia.
Patients may experience associated ocular or periocular pain. It is important to exclude other possible causes of cranial nerve palsy, such as stroke,
increased intracranial pressure, vasculitis, or optic neuropathy. Most patients with microvascular abducens nerve palsy experience resolution of
symptoms over several months following treatment of the underlying cause.
Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, F, G, H, and I.
The cerebellum (Choice A) contains a variety of structures, including the vermis, flocculus, and paraflocculus, which are important for the
coordination of ocular saccades, pursuit movements, and gaze holding. Cerebellar lesions do not produce esotropia.
Cranial nerve II (Choice B), the optic nerve, carries visual sensory information from the retina to the primary visual cortex via the lateral geniculate
nucleus. Optic nerve defects can be caused by demyelination or trauma and present with monocular vision loss.
Cranial nerve Ill (Choice C), the oculomotor nerve, is responsible for motor innervation of the levator palpebrae superioris, the superior, medial, and
inferior rectus muscles, as well as the inferior oblique muscle. Deficits of the oculomotor nerve present with ptosis, exotropia, and hypotropia.
Cranial nerve IV (Choice D), the trochlear nerve, is responsible for motor innervation of the superior oblique muscle. Deficits of the trochlear nerve
present with diplopia, hypertropia, and compensatory head tilt.
Extraocular muscles (Choice F) may cause diplopia in thyroid ophthalmopathy, orbital mass lesions, or entrapment within a fractured orbital bone.
This patient's history of diabetes mellitus suggests microvascular ischemia as a more likely cause of her diplopia.
Lesions of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) (Choice G) cause internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), which presents with an ipsilateral
adduction deficit, characterized by an inability of the affected eye to cross midline, and an associated contralatera l abduction saccade (as the
contralateral eye undergoes more rapid nerve firing to attempt to pull the ipsilateral eye across the midline).
Defects of the neuromuscular junction (Choice H) occur in myasthenia gravis, which presents with diplopia and ptosis that worsens towards the end
of the day.
Defects of the retina (Choice I) may produce visual disturbances but do not cause acute onset diplopia or deficits of extraocular movements.
Educational Objective: Diabetes mellitus causes microvascular damage to a variety of tissues, including nerves, and can cause cranial nerve palsy.
Microvascular abducens nerve palsy presents with esotropia, unilateral abduction deficit, and diplopia in horizontal gaze. Most patients experience
spontaneous recovery over several months following treatment of the underlying cause.
