vignette.presentation:
36. A 57-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of constant fatigue for 2 weeks. He has consumed 1 pint of vodka daily for
30 years. He appears drowsy. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg.
Cardiopulmona ry examination shows no abnormalities. Abdominal exami nation shows severe distention with a fluid wave. Rectal examination
shows hemorrhoids. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. On mental status examination, he responds to questions slowly. When asked to
write his name, it is an unintelligible scribble compared with a clear signature on his medical chart from 1 year ago. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglob in 12.5 g/dL
Hematoc rit 39%
Leukocyte count 7000/mm3 with a normal differential
Platelet count 200,000 /mm3
Prothrombin time 18 sec (INR=2)
Partial thrombop lastin time 40 sec
Serum
Urea nitrogen 6 mg/dL
Creatinine 0.6 mg/dL
AST 8 U/L
ALT 8 U/L
Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's mental status?

question_stem: most likely to improve this patient's mental status?

choices.text: Transfus ion of packed red blood cells

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Administration of oral lactulose is the intervention that is most likely to improve this patient's altered mental status (AMS). AMS occurs frequently in patients with decompensated cirrhosis. While the differential diagnosis is broad and includes systemic infection (eg, urinary tract infection, pneumonia, bacterial peritonitis), intoxication, hypoxemia or hypercapnia, among others, AMS is frequent ly the result of hepatic encepha lopathy (HE). HE is postulated to result from increased gut generation of ammonia by Gram-negative organisms coupled with inadequate clearance by the cirrhotic liver. Other clinical findings that suggest hepatic encepha lopathy include the presence of asterixis. Lactulose is an oral medication given for the treatment and prevention of HE. It is degraded by colonic

distractor_explanations.A: would not resolve this patient's HE. While diets for patients with cirrhosis often include high protein intake and low salt intake, diet alone would not treat HE. Infusion of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) (
distractor_explanations.C: would be appropriate for patients with coagulopathy and profound bleeding, as it includes all the clotting factors in addition to von Willebrand factor and fibrinogen. This patient's guaiac positive stool likely represents gastritis or ulcers, but his clinical presentation is not consistent with severe bleeding. Additionally, FFP is high volume and can worsen edema and ascites in cirrhotic patients. Transfusion of packed red blood cells (
distractor_explanations.D: is appropriate for patients with cirrhosis and massive bleeding from esophageal varices, or in cases of chronic bleeding when the hemoglobin drops below 7 g/dl. This patient does not meet criteria for transfusion. Hemodialysis (
distractor_explanations.E: is indicated for refractory hypervolemia, acidosis, electrolyte disturbances including severe hyperkalemia or hypercalcemia, after ingestion of certain alcohols, or for symptomatic uremia. Dialysis would not improve this patient's encephalopathy. Paracentesis (
distractor_explanations.F: should be performed on all patients with ascites and associated fever or abdominal pain who are admitted to the hospital to rule out spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), but it does not have a role in treating underlying hepatic encephalopathy. If SBP is discovered, then antibiotics are administered. Additionally, large volume paracentesis can be useful in patients with tense ascites or volume overload.

explanation.educational_objective: Patients with decompensated cirrhosis who present with altered mental status frequently have hepatic encephalopathy, which occurs as the result of accumulation of ammonia produced by colonic bacteria. While other causes of encephalopathy such as infection should be simultaneously evaluated, initiating treatment with oral lactulose is warranted. Lactulose is degraded by colonic bacteria to create an acidic environment, thereby converting ammonia to ammonium, which cannot be readily absorbed across the gut wall. One consequence of lactulose therapy is diarrhea, and dosing is often titrated to three or four bowel movements per day.
explanation.concept: Patients with decompensated cirrhosis who present with altered mental status frequently have hepatic encephalopathy, which occurs as the result of accumulation of ammonia produced by colonic bacteria.

vignette.presentation:
37. A 32-year-o ld woman comes to the physician because of weakness of her right arm and leg that began 1 week ago when she awoke in the
morning. Six days ago, when she took a bath, she noticed that she was unable to feel the heat of the water on the left side of her body. She had a
mild upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago. Cranial nerves are intact. There is mild weakness of the right upper and lower extremities.
Sensation to pinprick and temperature is decreased over the left trunk and left upper and lower extremities; sensation to vibration is decreased
over the right foot. Reflexes in the upper and lower extremities are more brisk on the right than the left. Babinski sign is present on the right. Which
of the following is the most likely location of this patient's lesion?

question_stem: the most likely location of this patient's lesion?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Brown-Sequard syndrome refers to hemisection of the spinal cord, which damages the anterior and dorsal horns along with the three major spinal cord tracts: the corticospina l tract (carrying motor fibers), dorsal column-medial lemniscus tract (carrying sensory fibers that mediate fine touch, pressure, vibration, and proprioception), and spinothalamic tract (carrying sensory fibers that mediate pain and temperature). The corticospinal tract and dorsal-column medial meniscus tract decussate in the medulla, while the spinotha lamic tract decussates near the spinal cord level of the peripheral sensory nerve. Consequent ly, hemisection of the spinal cord leads to an ipsilateral lower motoneuron pattern of dysfunction at the level of the lesion and an ipsilateral upper motoneuron pattern of dysfunction inferior to the lesion. Further, hemisection of the spinal cord results in an ipsilateral impairment of sensation of fine touch, pressure, vibration, and proprioception, and a contralatera l impairment of sensation of pain and temperature. This patient's lesion is likely at the cervical spinal cord level given the dysfunction of both lower and upper extremities. Brown-Sequard syndrome is most common ly caused by penetrating trauma but may also be caused by disc herniation, hematoma, or tumor. Treatment depends on the underlying cause, though it is typically focused on physical rehabilitation.

distractor_explanations.A: and cerebral hemisphere (
distractor_explanations.C: lesions affecting the three major sensory and motor tracts present with contralateral hemisensory deficits and hemiparesis caused by the decussation of all three tracts inferior to the lesion. Brainstem lesions also typically cause ipsilateral cranial nerve dysfunction. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Brown-Sequard syndrome refers to hemisection of the spinal cord, which damages the anterior and dorsal horns along with the three major spinal cord tracts: the corticospina l tract, dorsal column-medial lemniscus tract, and spinothalamic tract. This leads to an ipsilateral lower motoneuron pattern of dysfunction at the level of the lesion and an ipsilateral upper motoneuron pattern of dysfunction inferior to the lesion. Further, hemisection of the spinal cord results in an ipsilateral impairment of sensation of fine touch, pressure, vibration, and proprioception, and a contralateral impairment of sensation of pain and temperature.

vignette.presentation:
38. A 72-year-o ld man with a 3-year history of Parkinson disease is brought to the physician by his wife for a follow-up examination. Three weeks ago,
his dosage of carbidopa-levodopa was increased. Since then, he has reported seeing people spying on him from across the street. He has no
other history of serious medical or psychiatric illness and takes no other medications. Physical examination shows a resting tremor. There is
cogwhee l rigidity and increased muscle tone. On mental status examination, he reports seeing people spying on him and says his wife is "one of
them." Addition of which of the following medications is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Carbidopa-levodopa increases dopamine concentrations in several brain areas. In the basal ganglia, an increased dopamine concentration leads to improvement in Parkinson symptoms. In the limbic system, an increased dopamine concentration leads to psychotic symptoms such as paranoid delusions or hallucinations. Distressing psychotic symptoms in Parkinson disease are typically managed with antipsychotic medication or a decreased dose of carbidopa-levodopa. This patient demonstrates residual Parkinson symptoms that would likely worsen with a decreased dose of carbidopa-levodopa, so antipsychotic medication should be given. Typical antipsychotics (eg, haloperido l) potently antagonize the dopamine receptor non-selectively across several brain areas, which could lead to worsened Parkinson symptoms. Atypical antipsychotics, especially quetiapine and clozapine, less potently antagonize dopamine receptors and modulate other neurotransmitters such as serotonin (which assist in regulating dopamine signaling in the limbic system and thus indirectly address psychotic symptoms). Consequently, atypical antipsychotics improve psychotic symptoms without significantly exacerbating Parkinson symptoms.

distractor_explanations.A: is a typical antipsychotic that potently antagonizes dopamine receptors in both the basal ganglia and limbic system. Haloperidol would improve psychotic symptoms but would potentially exacerbate the patient's Parkinson symptoms. Lorazepam (
distractor_explanations.B: is a benzodiazepine utilized for acute anxiety. Paroxetine (
distractor_explanations.C: is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor that treats major depressive disorder and anxiety disorders. Valproic acid (
distractor_explanations.E: is a mood stabilizer utilized for bipolar disorder. These medications do not address psychotic symptoms. . .

explanation.educational_objective: Carbidopa-levodopa non-selectively increases dopamine concentrations in the basal ganglia and limbic system,
explanation.concept: Carbidopa-levodopa non-selectively increases dopamine concentrations in the basal ganglia and limbic system,

vignette.presentation:
39. A 72-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son because of a 1-month history of progressive forgetfulness. During this period, she has
misplaced her keys and checkbook , and she forgot that she was supposed to meet him for lunch last week. The patient says that she has had
progressive fatigue because of recent difficulty staying asleep at night. She often awakens at 4 or 5 am and is unable to fall back asleep. She
takes zolpidem once or twice weekly to help her sleep, but she has taken it nightly for the past 2 weeks. She also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight
loss and says that nothing tastes good anymore. She has a 10-year history of esophagea l reflux disease treated with lansoprazole and a 2-year
history of arthritis treated with acetaminophen. She was an English professor at a prominent university until 1 year ago when she was required to
retire by university regulations. She maintained an active schedule of lecturing and writing until 2 months ago. Her hair is unwashed, and she has a
mild body odor. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lib); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Her pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg.
On mental status examination, she appears distracted and worried. She says that her mood is "okay." Her speech is slow and monotone, and she
answers with single words. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her digit span is 6 forward and 2 backward. She can recall zero of
three objects after 5 minutes. She refuses to perform simple change calculations or name past presidents. Which of the following is the most likely
diagnosis?

question_stem:
the most likely
diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Major depressive disorder (MOD) explains this patient's fatigue, poor sleep, poor appetite, anhedonia (evidenced by food not tasting good), poor concentration (evidenced by a decreased digit span and distracted appearance), and psychomotor retardation (evidenced by slow speech). Symptoms of MOD include 2 or more weeks of depressed mood, anhedonia, feelings of guilt or worthlessness, difficulty concentrating, suicidal thoughts, and/or neurovegetative symptoms (decreased energy, sleep disturbance, appetite disturbance). These symptoms disrupt everyday functioning, as evidenced by this patient's poor personal hygiene. Elderly patients may view their neurovegetative symptoms as a manifestation of normal aging or a comorbid medical condition rather than depression. Consequently, depressed elderly patients may struggle to express their depressed mood, though MOD should be suspected in this patient with many other depressive symptoms. MOD in elderly patients can cause pseudodementia, which refers to cognitive impairment secondary to depression, manifesting as this patient's short-term memory difficulties and decreased effort on a brief cognitive screening. Physicians should always inquire about suicida l ideation in patients with MOD. Mood and cognition typically improve with antidepressant medication.

distractor_explanations.A: refers to depressive symptoms beginning within three months of a stressor and associated with a significant impairment in functioning. Dysthymic disorder (
distractor_explanations.D: , commonly known as persistent depressive disorder, refers to depressive symptoms lasting longer than two years. Both disorders may include energy, sleep, and appetite changes without meeting the criteria of MOD. Delirium (
distractor_explanations.B: is an acute confusional state typically associated with medical illness in older patients. Delirium presents with acute disturbances in awareness, attention, and baseline cognition that fluctuate in severity over the course of the day. This patient does not show evidence of an acute medical condition or fluctuating cognitive symptoms, rather the patient demonstrates 1 month of progressive cognitive decline. Dementia, Alzheimer type (
distractor_explanations.C: is the most prevalent dementia, presenting with progressive cognitive decline that begins with short-term memory impairment, progresses to apraxia and language abnorma lities, and culminates in behavioral and personality changes preventing the patient from performing basic activities of daily living. Dementia, Alzheimer type, would not present with this patient's constellation of neurovegetative symptoms or this degree of functional impairment after only one month of symptoms. Parkinson disease (
distractor_explanations.F: presents with dysfunction of voluntary movements in the form of bradykinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, and postural instability. Dementia may occur late in the disease course and would not be expected after only 1 month of symptoms. Substance-induced persisting amnestic disorder (
distractor_explanations.G: refers to anterograde or retrograde memory impairment that persists beyond the expected period of intoxication or withdrawal. This patient illustrates deficits in cognitive domains (eg, attention) along with symptoms of depression, making MOD the most likely diagnosis.

explanation.educational_objective: Major depressive disorder typically features depressed mood, anhedonia, difficulty concentrating, suicidal thoughts, and/or neurovegetative symptoms (decreased energy, sleep disturbance, appetite disturbance). Elderly patients may demonstrate pseudodementia, which refers to cognitive impairment arising from depression. Elderly patients are less likely to endorse a depressed mood than younger adults.
explanation.concept: Major depressive disorder typically features depressed mood, anhedonia, difficulty concentrating, suicidal thoughts, and/or neurovegetative symptoms (decreased energy, sleep disturbance, appetite dist

40. A 77-year-old man with Parkinson disease is brought to the physician by his wife because of a 3-month history of unusual behavior at night. She
says that he yells in his sleep and waves his arms as if defending himself. Two nights ago, he bit her and tried to push her out of the bed. Current
medications include carbidopa-levodopa. Examination shows little facial expression, a pill-rolling tremor of both hands, and muscle rigidity. Which
of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Polysomnography assists in diagnosing rapid-eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder. In typical REM sleep, several neural circuits terminate on spinal cord motoneurons to cause sleep atonia. When this muscle atonia is lost, patients can violently act out their dreams. They typically remember the dreams. REM sleep behavior disorder most commonly occurs in adult males and can be idiopathic or related to underlying a-synuclein deposition (eg, Parkinson disease, multiple system atrophy, or Lewy body dementia). Polysomnography tracks several sleep-related parameters (eg, brain waves, eye movements, muscle tone, and breathing patterns). Polysomnography showing absent atonia during REM sleep confirms the diagnosis. Treatment includes creating a safe sleep environment and, if the behavior is severe, initiating melatonin or clonazepam. Patients with idiopathic REM sleep behavior disorder should be closely monitored because of the high rate of developing a neurodegenerative disease.

distractor_explanations.A: tracks the amount of time it takes a patient to enter the REM stage. A decreased REM sleep latency indicates narcolepsy. The timing of REM sleep is relatively unaffected in patients with REM sleep behavior disorder. Overnight pulse oximetry testing (
distractor_explanations.B: can assist in the diagnosis of sleep apnea. In sleep apnea, patients become hypoxemic several times during the night because of pharyngeal obstruction or disordered breathing. Oxygenation is typically normal in REM sleep behavior disorder. Sleeping and waking EEG (
distractor_explanations.D: may disclose slight abnormalities of slow-wave sleep in patients with REM sleep behavior disorder. However, these abnormalities have not yet been characterized sufficiently to assist in diagnosis. Wrist actigraphy (
distractor_explanations.E: involves recording movements during sleep with a wrist device. Wrist actigraphy is being investigated as a ....  - - - - - - - - - - • I. ' - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - • ' - - - -

vignette.presentation:
41. A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her girlfriend 15 minutes after several episodes of staring and blinking while
eating dinner. The patient has a history of bipolar disorder well controlled with daily bupropion and lithium carbonate for the past 5 years. She
started taking terbinafine 2 weeks ago for chronic toenail fungus. During the examination , she is conversant. Her pulse is 64/min, respirations are
16/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. A normal rhythm is heard on cardiac examination. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings.
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Bupropion is an antidepressant medication, sometimes utilized in bipolar disorder for incomplete response to mood stabilizer therapy, that decreases the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine. By an unknown mechanism, bupropion decreases the seizure threshold. Bupropion is a cytochrome P450 (CYP)-2D6 substrate, while terbinafine (an oral antifungal medication utilized for onychomycosis) is a CYP-2D6 inhibitor. Consequent ly, this patient's bupropion serum concentrations were likely increased by the initiation of terbinafine. Most medication-induced seizures are generalized tonic-clonic seizures, but some are absence seizures. Absence seizures are generalized seizures that cause transient staring episodes with impaired consciousness during the seizure. Management involves switching to a topical onychomycosis agent or a different antidepressant medication that does not decrease the seizure threshold.

distractor_explanations.A: is a neurobehavioral syndrome marked by the inability to move or speak, or the inability to stop moving or speaking repetitively, that typically arises from an exacerbation of a psychiatric disorder. Catatonic episodes typically last days rather than seconds to minutes. Glioblastoma multiforme (
distractor_explanations.B: is an aggressive primary brain astrocytoma, which carries a poor prognosis. Seizures are a common presenting symptom, as are headaches and focal neurologic deficits. However, seizures related to brain tumors are typically focal rather than generalized, and this patient's recent history of medication changes makes a medication-induced seizure more likely. Rapid cycling bipolar disorder (
distractor_explanations.C: is defined as at least four mood episodes (manic or depressive episodes) in a 12-month period. Staring episodes are not a typical feature of mood episodes. .... r ~- - - , - - - - - - -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - r - - - , - - - - - - - -- -

explanation.educational_objective: Bupropion is an antidepressant medication that decreases the seizure threshold. Terbinafine is a CYP-2D6 inhibitor, which may increase the serum concentration of bupropion and increase the risk for developing generalized seizures. .,.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) refers to bleeding into the subarachnoid space and can be the result of a variety of causes, most common ly trauma or a ruptured intracrania l aneurysm in a nontraumatic setting. Patients typically present with an acute, severe headache, often described as the worst headache of their life, along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases. Fever can be associated with SAH and is associated with worse outcomes. CT scan of the head typically shows hyperdense blood products in the cerebral sulci and basal cisterns. However, sensitivity of CT for SAH can be reduced with small volume bleeding or delayed presentation. If there is continued strong suspicion for SAH following a normal CT scan of the head, a lumbar puncture can be performed, which can show red blood cells or xanthochromia (hemoglobin degradation products). As the blood products circulate within the subarachnoid space, complications include the development of communicating and/or obstructive hydrocephalus in the acute stage, along with the potential for re-bleeding and vasospasm in the days following the initial bleed. It is a neurosurgical emergency that may be fatal if progressive or untreated.

distractor_explanations.A: is caused by meningeal infection with Cryptococcus neoformans, which is an encapsulated, nondimorphic yeast and common opportunistic pathogen in immunocompromised patients. In cryptococca l meningitis, lumbar puncture classically detects an increased opening pressure, increased cerebrospinal fluid (CS

distractor_explanations.B: can cause a viral meningitis, which can present with fever, headache, and meningismus. Evaluation of CSF would disclose an increased leukocyte count with a lymphocytic predominance and normal glucose concentration. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (
distractor_explanations.C: or pseudotumor cerebri refers to an idiopathic increase in intracranial pressure (ICP) that typically occurs in obese women of childbearing age. It typically presents with headaches (that may be postural), transient visual deficits caused by pressure on the optic nerve, along with nausea and vomiting (symptoms of increased ICP). West Nile virus (
distractor_explanations.E: is a flavivirus transmitted via the bite of an infected mosquito and may cause West Nile fever with progression to meningoencephalitis. West Nile fever presents with headache, myalgias, nausea, vomiting, and a nonspecific maculopapular rash distributed symmetrically on the extremities and trunk. Meningoencephalitis is associated with acute flaccid paralysis, myoclonus, ataxia, and seizures.

44. A 62-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer is brought to the emergency department because of urinary incontinence for 24 hours. She
has metastases to the skull, multiple vertebral bodies, ribs, liver, and para-aortic lymph nodes. Medications include tamoxifen, sustained-re lease
morphine, stool softeners, and fluoxetine. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1 °F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is
128/76 mm Hg. Examination shows a large suprapubic mass. There is significant pain over the entire lumbar spine on fist percussion. Rectal
examination shows decreased sphincter tone. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the incontinence?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cauda equina syndrome occurs because of compression of the spinal nerve roots comprising the cauda equina. Often, such compression occurs as a result of metastases to the cauda equina, adjacent malignancy, trauma (eg, compression fractures with fragment retropulsion), disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal epidural abscess, or spinal epidural/subdural hematoma. Symptoms include lower extremity numbness, weakness, paralysis, hyporeflexia, perinea! anesthesia, fecal incontinence with poor rectal tone, and overflow incontinence marked by the inability to appropriately void and associated urinary retention. Emergent MRI of the lumbosacral spine is indicated to investigate the cause of cauda equina syndrome, and to determine the necessity of surgical decompression. Initial treatment for patients with epidural spinal cord compression and neurologic deficits include symptomatic treatment, pain control, and glucocorticoid therapy prior to definitive medical or surgical therapy. High-dose glucocorticoid therapy is helpful as a bridge to definitive therapy, as it may transiently improve neurologic function in patients by decreasing edema at the site of cord compression.

distractor_explanations.A: could also cause urinary retention but would not explain pain at the lumbar spine or decreased sphincter tone. Anticholinergic adverse effects can antagonize muscarinic receptors in the bladder wall, resulting in impaired urinary bladder contractility leading to urinary retention. Other anticholinergic effects can include dry mouth, sedation, constipation, hallucinations, delirium, ataxia, flushed skin, and visual disturbances (cycloplegia). Such effects are uncommon with fluoxetine, and malignant compression is much more likely in this case. Hypercalcemia (
distractor_explanations.B: can occur with bony metastases, but patients with severe hypercalcemia would present with nephrolithiasis, abdominal discomfort, confusion, constipation, and psychiatric disturbances. It would be unlikely to cause urinary retention and overflow incontinence. ....

Symptoms include lower extremity numbness, weakness, paralysis, hyporeflexia, perinea! anesthesia, fecal incontinence with poor rectal tone, and overflow incontinence marked by the inability to void and associated urinary retention. .,.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neonatal sepsis is a potentially life-threatening syndrome characterized by severe systemic manifestations of infection in infants less than 28 days of age. The culprit pathogen is most commonly acquired by vertical transmission during transit of the birth canal or horizontal transmission from contact with the healthcare environment. It is considered early-onset neonatal sepsis if the condition develops within the first week of life and late-onset if it occurs after. Early-onset neonatal sepsis is typically caused by Streptococcus agalactiae (group B) or Escherichia coli. Common organisms implicated in late-onset neonatal sepsis include S. agalactiae (group B), E. coli, Staphylococcus species (especially S. aureus), Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Candida albicans. Initial empiric antimicrobial therapy should cover these bacterial organisms. Lumbar puncture is indicated in the evaluation of neonatal sepsis as infants do not display typical symptoms of meningitis as associated with adult patients. Empiric coverage for herpes simplex virus (HSV) meningoencepha litis with acyclovir should be added to the regimen if the cerebrospinal fluid displays an increased erythrocyte count or if the patient presents with characteristic herpetic lesions.

distractor_explanations.B: may be used as an adjuvant therapy in the treatment of bacterial meningitis to decrease the risk for neurologic complications and mortality, especially in adults with meningitis caused by S. pneumoniae. The benefit is less clear in neonates and is not routinely recommended. Ganciclovir (
distractor_explanations.C: is an antiviral agent with activity against cytomegalovirus (CMV). Congenital CMV infection can present with developmental delay, cognitive defects, hearing loss, seizures, and a petechial rash. CMV does not typically cause neonatal sepsis. Ribavirin (
distractor_explanations.D: is an antiviral agent used in the treatment of hepatitis C virus (HCV) and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). It inhibits guanine nucleotide synthesis. Complications include hemolytic anemia. Ribavirin is a severe teratogen and should be avoided during pregnancy. Zidovudine (
distractor_explanations.E: is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRT
distractor_explanations.I: used in the treatment of HIV infection. It is commonly utilized for known exposure of an infant to HIV in utero to reduce the risk for vertical transmission. Infants are started on a course immediately after birth. If exposure risk is unknown, the mother and infant may be tested for the presence of HIV antibodies or identifiable HIV nucleic acid sequences prior to initiating therapy.

explanation.educational_objective: Neonatal sepsis is a severe condition warranting broad antimicrobial coverage. Thorough evaluation for a source is indicated, including lumbar puncture. Empiric coverage with acyclovir for HSV meningoencephalitis should be initiated if the CSF displays an increased erythrocyte count or if the patient presents with characteristic herpetic lesions. .,.

and lost control of bladder function. She did not notice any movement during the episode. He had a similar episode 1 month ago while shaving. At
that time, echocard iography, 24-hour ambulatory ECG monitoring, and a tilt test showed no abnormalities; cardiac enzyme activities were within
the reference range. His current blood pressure is 150/96 mm Hg. A grade 2/6, systolic ejection murmur is heard best at the upper left sternal
border. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Carotid sinus hypersensitivity syndrome is characterized by an exaggerated response to carotid baroreceptor stimulation, with resultant sinus bradycardia, hypotension, and syncope. Baroreceptors located at the carotid bifurcations and the aortic arch are important in regulating cardiac output and maintaining adequate perfusion pressures to the brain and organs of the upper body. Baroreceptors are sensitive to mechanical pressure; normally, an increase in blood pressure stimulates baroreceptor activity, which activates a reflex arc. This results in parasympathetic innervation of the sinoatrial and atrioventricular nodes and inhibition of sympathetic vascular tone. In turn, this causes decreased pulse and peripheral vascular resistance. Mechanical compression of the baroreceptors from external palpation, such as during shaving of the neck, can potentially stimulate this reflex.

distractor_explanations.A: is characterized by a transient blank stare, and typically occurs in brief episodes multiple times throughout the day. It is more common in children. EEG monitoring characteristically shows 3-Hz spike-and-wave complexes during the episodes. Often, patients disclose no postictal confusion. The patient's symptoms are not consistent with absence seizure. Aortic stenosis (
distractor_explanations.B: presents with a crescendo-dec rescendo systolic murmur best heard at the upper right sternal border with radiation to the carotid arteries. Syncope associated with aortic stenosis typically occurs during exertion because of the inability to increase stroke volume to match perfusion demands, resulting in consequent cerebral hypoperfusion. Syncope during shaving or other mild activities is less consistent with aortic stenosis. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Syncope is a common presenting complaint with numerous causes. A careful history that evaluates for provoking factors and physical examination can guide further diagnostic studies. Syncope that occurs exclusively with neck palpation is suggestive of carotid sinus hypersensitivity syndrome.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Myotonic dystrophy is a genetic disorder caused by expansion of a trinucleotide repeat, which occurs when a series of three nucleotides in repetition are replicated incorrectly and too many repeats are included in the replicated product. Other conditions caused by trinucleotide repeat expansions include fragile X syndrome, Huntington disease, and Friedrich ataxia. Myotonic dystrophy has several phenotypes, but all are characterized by muscle weakness and myotonia, defined as delayed relaxation following a normal contraction of the muscle. Classic myotonic dystrophy, as seen in this case, presents during the second, third, or fourth decades of life with muscle weakness, myotonia, cataracts, frontal balding, cardiac arrhythmias, and hypogonadism. The most frequently affected muscles include the facial muscles, sternocleidomastoid, distal forearm muscles, intrinsic hand muscles, and ankle dorsiflexors. Life expectancy is slightly reduced for patients with classic myotonic dystrophy and premature death is most commonly caused by respiratory or cardiac dysfunction.

distractor_explanations.B: is a type of muscular dystrophy in which progressive muscle weakness of the facial muscles, scapulae, upper arms, lower legs, and hip girdles occur. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Spinal cord compression can occur because of malignancy, trauma (eg, compression fractures with fragment retropulsion), disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal epidural abscess, or spinal epidural hematoma. Neurologic symptoms depend on the site of spinal cord compression, with sensation and motor deficits below the level of the lesion. Patients may manifest upper motoneuron examination findings such as spasticity, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar reflex (Babinski sign). Initial treatment for patients with epidural spinal cord compression and neurologic deficits include symptomatic treatment, pain control, and glucocorticoid therapy prior to definitive therapy. High-dose glucocorticoid therapy is helpful as a bridge to definitive therapy, can help control pain, and may transiently improve neurologic function in patients secondary to decreasing edema at the site of cord compression.

distractor_explanations.C: refers to metastatic neoplastic involvement of the leptomeninges, or the arachnoid and pia mater, of the central nervous system. corticosteroids during the past year. Medications include intravenous ceftriaxone and ampicillin, albuterol inhalers, theophylline, and prednisone. He
is confused and stuporous. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 142/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows
meningismus. An MRI of the brain shows diffuse meningeal enhancement with a basilar predominance. A lumbar puncture is done; cerebrospinal

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Chronic use of immunosuppressants including glucocorticoids increase the likelihood of tuberculosis reactivation. Tuberculous meningitis typically presents with nuchal rigidity, fever, and altered mental status, similar to the symptoms seen in bacterial meningitis. However, unlike bacterial meningitis which presents acutely, tuberculous meningitis typically shows a subacute presentation. Presence of cranial nerve palsies is also more likely in tuberculous meningitis than bacterial meningitis. Physical examination may show a positive Kernig or Brudzinski sign, indicative of meningeal irritation. Results of laboratory studies will show nonspecific changes including leukocytosis and mild anemia. A tuberculin skin test or interferon-gamma release assay are usually positive, but a negative result is also possible. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) evaluation is the initial diagnostic step and will reveal an increased opening pressure, increased white blood cell count with prominent lymphocytes, increased protein concentration, and decreased glucose concentration. Culture of the CSF for acid-fast bacilli may be positive, though the sensitivity of this test for tuberculous meningitis is less than 50%. Radiologic evaluation may show basilar exudates, as in this case, as well as periventricu lar infarcts and hydrocephalus.

distractor_explanations.A: presents with fever, altered mental status, and neurologic abnormalities, such as seizure, aphasia, hemiparesis, or cranial nerve deficits. Neuroimaging will typically show changes in the temporal lobe. The basilar predominance in this case is more suggestive of a tuberculous meningitis than herpes encephalitis. Lyme disease (
distractor_explanations.B: caused by disseminated Borrelia burgdorferi infection may cause neuropathy and meningitis. However, this would be expected to be accompanied by a rash in the pattern of erythema migrans and history of tick exposure. .... ~, r,

explanation.educational_objective: Tuberculous meningitis typically presents in a subacute fashion with nuchal rigidity, fever, and altered mental status. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) evaluation is the initial diagnostic step and will disclose an increased opening pressure, increased white blood cell count with prominent lymphocytes, increased protein concentration, decreased glucose concentration, and positive culture for acid-fast bacilli.

intermittent low-grade fever and episodes of stiffening of her body. Her father reports that she previously interacted with them and smiled when
prompted but has not made eye contact for the past 3 days. She has a history of hypotonia. She cannot yet roll over or sit up. Her parents are third
cousins. She is awake and irritable and has poor visual regard. Examination of the skin shows no neurocutaneous lesions. The optic nerves are
pale. Neurologic examination shows hyperextension of the head and back, ankle spasticity, and fisting. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk, and

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This infant's presentation of fever, spasticity, hypotonia, vision loss, optic nerve pallor, and Babinski sign, as well as a family history of consanguinity are consistent with a diagnosis of Krabbe disease, also known as galactosylceramide lipidosis. Krabbe disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by mutations in the GALC gene that encodes galactocerebrosidase, the deficiency of which results in accumulation of galactocerebroside and demyelinating neuronal degeneration. Patients typically present within the first year of life with progressive neurologic degeneration, spasticity, stiffness, seizures, feeding difficulty, and peripheral neuropathy, including optic neuropathy. The diagnosis is confirmed with serum enzyme assays, although MRI of the brain will show white matter degeneration caused by demyelination. There is no effective treatment for Krabbe disease and most affected children die during the first several years of life.

Dandy-Walker malformation does not typically present with spasticity and stiffness and presents with papilledema rather than optic nerve pallor. Holoprosencephaly (

3. A 57-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after a simple partial seizure. Examination shows mild weakness of the

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Meningioma is a common, benign central nervous system (CNS) tumor derived from the meninges that occurs along the surfaces of the brain and spinal cord, often in the parasagittal region. They occur in women more often than men and are associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 and multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. Patients may be asymptomatic or experience seizures or focal neurologic deficits related to the tumor location. Meningiomas are typically benign but can be malignant. Malignant meningiomas may grow rapidly, leading to symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (eg, postural headache, nausea, papilledema), or may metastasize. Meningiomas appear as well-circumscribed, extra-axia l (ie, outside of the brain parenchyma) masses that compress the parenchyma. They show uniform enhancement on imaging. Definitive diagnosis requires histologic examination of tissue, which will show spindle cells arranged in a whorled pattern with psammoma bodies. Treatment may include antiepileptics or surgical resection to alleviate the tumoral mass effect if significant, though often, periodic surveillance is all that is necessary.

distractor_explanations.A: is a primary CNS neoplasm that can occur as benign pilocytic astrocytoma in children or malignant glioblastoma multiforme (
distractor_explanations.C: in adults. Glioblastoma are highly malignant tumors appearing as intra-axial masses in the cerebral hemispheres, which typically show areas of necrosis and can spread to the opposite hemisphere across the corpus callosum. Ependymoma (
distractor_explanations.B: is a CNS neoplasm formed from ependymal cells. Location typical ly involves the fourth ventricle. Histologic characteristics include perivascular pseudorosettes formed by malignant cells arranged around a blood vessel. Schwannoma (
distractor_explanations.E: are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells in peripheral nerve sheaths. They commonly affect the facial and vestibulococh lear nerves, and mass effect may result in sensorineural hearing loss or ataxia. vignette.presentation:
4. A 67-year-o ld semiretired corporate executive comes to the physician with his wife because she is concerned about his increasing disorgan ization
at home over the past year. She also notes that he is unable to remember the names of recent acquaintances. He has insisted on working part-time
since stepping down from a CEO position. His secretary has told his wife that he has been forgetting scheduled appointments and becomes angry
and tearful when he is reminded. He drinks one to two cocktails each evening. Physical examination shows no abnorma lities. On mental status
examination, he is mildly agitated and has word-finding difficulty and short-term memory deficits. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Which of
the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Acute stress disorder J) Hypercalcem ia
Alcohol-induced amnest ic disorder K) Major depressive disorder
Dementia , Alzheimer type L) Multi-infarct (vascular) dementia
General paresis N) Normal-pressure hydrocep halus
Hepatolenticular degenerat ion (Wilson disease) P) Pick disease
HIV encepha litis Q) Normal aging

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Alzheimer dementia (AD) is the most prevalent dementia, presenting with progressive cognitive decline that begins with short-term memory impairment and decline in visuospatial abilities and progresses to apraxia, language abnormalities, and dysexecutive syndrome (resulting in the inability to recall scheduled appointments in this patient). The disease culminates in behavioral and persona lity changes that prevent the patient from performing basic activities of daily living such as bathing. AD may be treated with drugs that both directly and indirectly increase acetylcholine in synaptic clefts. These include donepezi l and cholinesterase inhibitors which non-competitively and reversibly inhibit acetylcholinesterase and thereby increase the amount of synaptic acetylcho line available for neurotransmission. Though these drugs may slow the rate of cognitive decline and modestly improve functiona lity, they are not curative for AD.

vignette.presentation:
5. A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 2 hours after he dove
into a shallow lake and struck the back of his head on the bottom. Hie immediately had the
onset of pain in his neck and a sensation of an electric shock radiating from his neck to his left
shoulder. He did not have loss of consciousness. He was able to stand, and two friends helped
him out of the water into a supine position on the dock. At the scene, his spine was immobilized
with a cervical collar, and his head was taped to a backboard. On arrival, he is alert. Vital signs
are within normal limits. Muscle strength is 3/5 on extension of the left wrist. Deep tendon
reflexes are normal. Babinski sign is absent. Sensorimotor examination of the right upper
extremity and lower extremities shows no abnormalities. Sensation to light touch is decreased
over the radial aspect of the left forearm and hand and over the palmar and dorsal aspects of
the left thumb. Rectal examination shows normal sphincter tone and sensation. A lateral x-ray
of the cervical spine is shown. This patient most likely has which of the following cervical spine
injuries?

question_stem:
most likely has which of the following cervical spine
injuries?

choices.text: Bilateral dislocation of facets with impingement of the left CS nerve root
Bilateral dislocation of facets with impingement of the left C6 nerve root
Unilateral dislocation of a facet with impingement of the left CS nerve
would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction in the lateral aspect of the

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient likely has bilateral dislocation of facets with impingement of the left C6 nerve root caused by cervical spinal injury. The C6 dermatom,e is located on the lateral (radial) aspect of the forearm and extends to the lateral two digits of the hand. Injury to the C6 nerve root will cause decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in these distributions (or part of this distribution) along with motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension. The C6 nerve root carries efferent information for the biceps reflex, so patients with C6 nerve injury may present with a diminished or absent biceps reflex. Dermatomes and myotomes are components of the embryonic somite, a paired segment of paraxial mesoderm. When fully developed, the dermatome is an area of skin whose afferent fibers travel within a single spinal nerve, and myotome is a group of muscles innervated by efferent fibers from a single spinal nerve. Disc herniation and spondylosis are common causes of spinal nerve root compression in older patients, and trauma

distractor_explanations.A: typically manifests with bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and motor function below the level of the lesion, along with autonomic dysfunction. The anterior spinal artery supplies the corticospinal, spinothalamic, and autonomic tracts. Bilateral dislocation of facets with impingement of the left CS nerve root (
distractor_explanations.B: and unilateral dislocation of a facet with impingement of the left CS nerve (
distractor_explanations.E: would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction in the lateral aspect of the shoulder and upper arm. CS nerve compression typically results in an absent biceps reflex, as the CS nerve root carries afferent information for this reflex. However, CS nerve compression would not cause decreased sensation in the digits. Brown-Sequard syndrome (
distractor_explanations.D: refers to hemisection of the spinal cord, which damages the anterior horn along with three major spinal cord tracts: the corticospinal tract, dorsal column-medial lemniscus tract, and spinothalamic tract. .... r ~- , r,

explanation.educational_objective: Cervical spinal injury can lead to vertebra l dislocation and impingement of the spinal nerve root, which leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesia, and pain in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected root. C6 nerve root compression will cause decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in the lateral forearm and lateral two digits. Additionally, C6 root compression causes motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension.
explanation.concept: Cervical spinal injury can lead to vertebra l dislocation and impingement of the spinal nerve root, which leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesia, and pain in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution

vignette.presentation:
6. A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after the sudden
onset of headache and left-sided weakness that have become increasingly severe.
He has hypertension treated with lisinopril and chronic neck pain treated with
325-mg aspirin. On arrival, he appears mildly lethargic. His pulse is 60/min,
respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. Examination shows
moderate weakness of the lower left side of the face. Muscle tone is decreased in
the left upper and lower extremities. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the left and 5/5 on the
right. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the left. Babinski sign is present on the left. A
CT scan of the head without contrast is shown. Which of the following is the most
likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hypertensive intracerebral hematomas (ICHs) can occur in patients with chronic hypertension, typically because of hemorrhage from small penetrating arteries in the pons, midbrain, thalamus, putamen, caudate, or cerebellum. Risk factors for hypertensive ICH include uncontrolled hypertension and antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy, such as with aspirin or warfarin. Patients can present with headache, vomiting, confusion, altered mental status, stupor, or coma. Focal neurologic deficits depend on the site of the ICH and can include hemiparesis, hemisensory symptoms, gaze palsy, dysarthria, aphasia, or if in the cerebellum, ataxia, vomiting, and disequilibrium. Patients may manifest upper motoneuron examination findings such as spasticity, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar reflex (Babinski sign). Diagnosis is made with noncontrast CT scan of the head which will show hyperdense intraparenchyma l products, which is the appearance of acute bleeding in the brain as seen in this patient's right hemisphere.

distractor_explanations.A: occurs secondary to amyloid deposition in cerebral blood vessels and leptomeninges. It can cause spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage in older adults, typically in a lobar location, because of the location of amyloid deposits in cortical vessels. In contrast, hypertensive hemorrhages typically occur in a deep location such as the putamen, thalamus, midbrain, or pons. lschemic cerebral infarction (
distractor_explanations.C: can occur as a result of thromboembol ic occlusion of cerebral arteries. Patients typically present with acute focal neurologic deficits, especially on one side of the body, and may have speech difficulty, dysarthria, or aphasia. A CT scan would not show hyperdense blood products unless the infarction is complicated by hemorrhagic conversion. Ruptured arteriovenous malformation (
distractor_explanations.D: can lead to intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage. Arteriovenous malformations are uncommon and usually present in individuals younger than 50 years old with intracranial hemorrhage, seizure, neurologic deficit, or headache, or may be an incidental finding. In an older patient with uncontrolled hypertension, a hypertensive intracerebral hematoma is more likely. Ruptured berry aneurysm (
distractor_explanations.E: typically leads to a subarachnoid hemorrhage. Patients typically present with an acute, severe headache (o ften described as the worst headache of the patient's life), along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases. CT scan of the head typically shows hyperdense blood products in the cerebral sulci and basal cisterns.

explanation.educational_objective: Hypertensive intracerebral hematomas can occur in patients with chronic hypertension, typically as a result of hemorrhage from small penetrating arteries in the pons, midbrain, thalamus, putamen, caudate, or cerebellum. Patients can present with headache, vomiting, confusion, altered mental status, stupor, upper motoneuron signs, and focal neurologic deficits such as hemiparesis and hemisensory symptoms.
explanation.concept: Hypertensive intracerebral hematomas can occur in patients with chronic hypertension, typically as a result of hemorrhage from small penetrating arteries in the pons, midbrain, thalamus, putamen, caud

vignette.presentation:
7. Over the past 6 months, an otherw ise healthy 19-year-old cheerleader has had increasingly severe neurologic symptoms. Initially, she had difficulty
jumping; 2 weeks later she had a tingling feeling in the toes of her right foot that quickly spread to the left foot. Over the past 2 weeks, she has
stumbled and fallen severa l times. Examination of the upper extremities shows normal findings. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower
extremities. She is unable to heel walk and has mild difficulty walking on her toes and rising from a low squatting position. Position sensation is
normal, but pinprick feels less sharp distally and occasiona l light touch stimuli are missed over the toes. Peronea l motor conduction velocity is
moderately slowed (22 m/sec; N=42-57). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Chronic inflammator y demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathYi G) Spinal cord tumor
Diabetic neuropathy H) Spinal epidural abscess
Epidural spinal cord metastasis I) Spondylotic myelopathy
Spinal cord infarction L) Vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradicu lopathy (CIDP) is an immune-mediated demye linating condition affecting the spinal nerve roots. The pathogenesis of CIDP involves inflammation of myelin by an unknown mechanism. The ventra l nerve roots containing motor efferents are common ly involved, though the dorsal nerve root (controlling sensation) may also be affected. As such, patients typical ly present with relapsing-remitting or gradually progressive symmetric muscle weakness with depressed or absent deep tendon reflexes (reflecting a lower motoneuron pattern of dysfunction) that affects the proxima l and distal lower extremities simultaneous ly and may also affect the upper extremities. Autonomic dysfunction may occur but is typically mild. Sensory deficits may occur (though these symptoms are typically mild compared to motor dysfunction). A slowing of conduction velocity on nerve conduction studies indicates demyelination and supports the diagnosis. The diagnosis is further supported by increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell counts on lumbar puncture, termed albuminocyto logic dissociation and thought to reflect generalized inflammation. Management includes glucocorticoids, immunomodulators, plasma exchange, or intravenous immunog lobulin therapy.

vignette.presentation:
8. A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of progressive weakness of his legs during the past week. He has chronic
kidney disease and receives dialysis three times weekly via a percutaneous tunneled catheter. Last week, he had an episode of sweating and chills.
His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 100/min and regular, and blood pressure is 150/92 mm Hg. Examination shows severe tenderness to
percussion over the lumbar spine. The catheter site appears normal. There is trace edema of the lower extremities. Muscle strength is 3/5 on flexion
and extension of the knees and ankles. Deep tendon reflexes are increased at the patellae. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 19,200/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 90%
Bands 5%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 4%
Platelet count 290,000/mm3
An MRI of the spine shows an epidural abscess at L4. Blood cultures grow Staphylococcus aureus. In addition to antibiotic therapy and drainage of
the abscess, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Epidural abscess is a localized collection of pus in the epidural space between the dura mater and periosteum. It most commonly occurs in the spine but may occur in the brain. Most patients have a history of another preceding or associated (even occult) infection and often have a history of immunocompromise (eg, diabetes mellitus, HIV infection, alcohol use disorder). Epidural abscess is more common in patients with a history of intravenous drug use or indwelling intravenous lines. Infectious organisms usually spread to the epidural space hematogenously, from spinal surgery, or from adjacent osteomyelitis. Staphylococcus aureus is a frequent causative organism. Patients present with signs and symptoms of fever, altered mental status, meningismus, localized back pain, and tenderness to palpation, along with weakness, numbness, and paralysis below the affected spinal level as a result of cord compression. Treatment is with broad spectrum antibiotics and surgical drainage of the abscess. It is also crucial to identify and remove potential sources of bacterial colonization, such as indwelling venous catheters. r ~• • ,• ! a , • : • - •• r,

Technetium 99m bone scan (

distractor_explanations.E: is useful for the diagnosis of meningitis but is not usually necessary for patients with epidural abscess.

explanation.educational_objective: Epidural abscess may result from hematogenous dissemination of bacterial or fungal infection to the epidural space between the dura mater and periosteum. It presents with fever, altered mental status, meningismus, localized back pain, and tenderness to palpation, along with weakness, numbness, and paralysis below the affected spinal level. Treatment is with broad spectrum antibiotics, surgical drainage of the abscess, and the identification and removal of any potential sources of bacterial colonization, such as indwelling venous catheters.

vignette.presentation:
9. A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 30 minutes after a 15-minute episode of inability to speak. He has a 15-year
history of poorly controlled hypertension . Three weeks ago, he had a transmural myocardial infarction and underwent placement of a stent in the left
anterior descending coronary artery. Current medications include clopidogrel, benazepril, and 81-mg aspirin. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes
daily for 30 years. On arrival, he is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. His pulse is 60/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is
160/100 mm Hg. A grade 1/ 6 systolic murmur is heard best at the second left intercostal space. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings.
Carotid duplex ultrasonography shows 40% stenosis of the left carotid artery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: An embolic ischemic stroke involves an event in which a clot breaks off and travels to the brain, occluding blood flow within a cerebral artery. Emboli can originate from proximal vessels, such as the internal carotid artery, or from an atrial or ventricular thrombus. This patient had a recent myocardial infarction, which predisposes him to a ventricular aneurysm. Ventricular aneurysms are more likely to form in the case of large, anterior myocardial infarctions as a result of obstruction of the left anterior descending coronary artery, as was the case in this patient. A small systolic murmur of mitral regurgitation may be heard. Within the aneurysm, as a result of areas of stagnant blood flow and despite being on clopidogrel, a thrombus can form that can embolize and cause an ischemic stroke. If a patent foramen ovale is present, an embolism may arise from either the right or left side of the heart. This patient also has other risk factors for ischemic stroke including hypertension and atherosclerotic disease. Because his symptoms resolved within less than 24 hours, his embolic event is classified as a transient ischemic attack.

A lacunar stroke may present with purely motor symptoms, purely sensory symptoms, ataxic hemiparesis, or dysarthria. Infarcts in these deep penetrating vessels are secondary to hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. While these risk factors would also predispose to myocardial infarction, this patient's transient ischemic event is most likely caused by an embolism from the left ventricle as opposed to a primary central nervous system infarction. lntraparenchyma l cerebral hemorrhage (
distractor_explanations.C: and subarachnoid hemorrhage (
distractor_explanations.E: are both causes of hemorrhagic stroke and are caused by ruptured intracranial or subarachnoid blood vessels in the setting of hypertension. vignette.presentation:
10. One month after starting isoniazid and rifampin therapy for pulmonary tuberculosis, a 62-year-old woman develops weakness, fatigue, and
paresthesias. Examination shows pallor and diminished light touch sensation in the extremities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 9 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 78 µm3
Leukocyte count 8000/mm3
Platelet count 210,000/mm3
These symptoms are most likely to respond to treatment with which of the following?

question_stem: most likely to respond to treatment with which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: lsoniazid and rifampin are used in the treatment of primary tuberculosis, which results from an initial exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. lsoniazid binds vitamin B (pyridoxine) which may result in early excretion and inactivation of pyridoxine, and also inhibits 6 pyridoxine phosphokinase, which is necessary to activate it. Pyridoxine deficiency results, of which primary symptoms are peripheral neuropathy and paresthesia. Pyridoxine deficiency limits synthesis of histamine, hemoglobin, and neurotransm itters including epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine, serotonin, and y-aminobutyric acid (GABA). In addition to peripheral neuropathy, deficiency commonly presents with dermatitis, sideroblastic anemia, glossitis, and seizures. These adverse effects may all be avoided by pyridoxine supplementation in all patients taking isoniazid.

distractor_explanations.A: is converted to tetrahydrofo lic acid and is used as a coenzyme in the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleosides. Folate is contained in leafy vegetables and absorbed in the jejunum. Folate deficiency is often seen in patients with malnutrition, alcoholism, and patients taking anti-folate medications (eg, phenytoin, methotrexate). It is not caused by isoniazid or rifampin and is not responsible for this patient's symptoms. Iron (
distractor_explanations.B: deficiency also presents with microcytic anemia. However, it is not induced by isoniazid or rifampin and its supplementation in this case would not address the symptoms of pyridoxine deficiency. ....

explanation.educational_objective: lsoniazid therapy for latent tuberculosis without sufficient pyridoxine supplementation can lead to pyridoxine deficiency. This is characterized by peripheral neuropathy, dermatitis, sideroblastic anemia, glossitis, and seizures. .,.

vignette.presentation:
11. A 22-year-old man who is a collegiate volleyball player comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressive pain and weakness in
his right shoulder. There is no history of trauma. He is 196 cm (6 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (210 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2 . There is significant loss of
muscle mass in the dorsal scapula region, especially in the area of the scapular spine. Passive abduction and external rotation of the right
shoulder and protraction of the scapula reproduce the pain. There is weakness with resisted external rotation and initiation of abduction. Active
range of motion shows full flexion and abduction. Sensory examinat ion shows no cutaneous deficits along the right side of the neck or in the right
upper extremity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are most consistent with entrapment of the suprascapu lar nerve. The suprascapular nerve originates from the superior trunk of the brachia! plexus and innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles. Nerve compression secondary to traction injury is common among volleyball players. Irritation of the suprascapular nerve results in pain along the course of the nerve and may result in chronic neuropathy with subsequent muscle wasting, atrophy, and degeneration of the infraspinatus and supraspinatus muscles. The supraspinatus is responsib le for adduction of the shoulder, and the infraspinatus is responsible for external rotation of the shoulder, which reproduce the pain and disclose weakness in this patient. Initial treatment is conservative with activity modification and physical therapy. Operative intervention may be required.

distractor_explanations.A: is a common cause of shoulder pain in adults, characterized by severely limited range of motion. Patients typically note a gradual onset of progressive shoulder stiffness and pain. Physical examination would disclose limited range of motion while this patient discloses full range of motion. Axillary nerve damage (
distractor_explanations.B: results in weakness of the deltoid and teres minor, which abduct and stabilize the shoulder. The axillary nerve gives rise to the superficial lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, and sensory deficits would be expected if injured. Brachia! plexus palsy (
distractor_explanations.C: describes a range of injury to the nervous system complex that gives rise to the nerves of the upper extremity. The mechanism is usually high-impact trauma or forced abduction of the shoulder. Physical examination typically discloses motor and sensory deficits involving several peripheral nerves. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Shoulder pain associated with impaired innervation to the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles is suggestive of suprascapu lar neuropathy. Causes include mass effect as a result of lesions compressing the nerve sheath, trauma, and traction injury (most commonly seen in volleyball players). .,.
explanation.concept: Shoulder pain associated with impaired innervation to the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles is suggestive of suprascapu lar neuropathy. Causes include mass effect as a result of lesions compress

12. A 32-year-o ld woman comes to the physician with her husband because of a 6-month history of fluctuating symptoms including fatigue, loss of
balance, blurred vision, and the sensation of pins and needles over he r arms and legs. Her husband says that she has also had mood swings with
episodes of uncontro llable crying over the past 2 months. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood
pressure is 128/86 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows reduced medial gaze of the left eye and numbness to pinprick over the left distal lower
extremities. Romberg sign is present. Babinski sign is present on the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Measurement of serum vitamin B (cobalam in) concentration

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Multiple sclerosis (MS), the most prevalent immune-mediated demyelinating disease, may present with episodic or progressive neurologic dysfunction. According to the McDonald criteria for MS diagnosis, patients must have evidence of demyelinating lesions that are separated in time and location. This evidence is typically based on subjective symptoms and radiologic studies. Lesions affecting the left medial longitudina l fasciculus (leading to decreased medial gaze of the left eye), the prefronta l cortex or corticobulbar tracts (leading to pseudobu lbar affect, or uncontrollable crying), and the major central nervous system (CNS) tracts innervating the extremities (lesions of the corticospina l tract causing Babinski sign, spinothalamic tract causing decreased pinprick, dorsal column-media l lemniscus causing Romberg sign and paresthesia) are likely separated in space. This patient experienced two discrete periods of symptom onset at 6 months and 2 months, illustrating separation in time. MRI typically shows white matter hyperintensities in the periventricular region, cortex, subcortical region, cerebellum, or spine. Oligoclonal bands of immunog lobulins, indicating immune overactivation, can be found in the cerebrospinal fluid but are not necessary for diagnosis. Treatment includes corticosteroids for symptomatic management of acute flares and long-term disease-modifying treatments such as interferon or monoclonal antibodies.
explanation.educational_objective: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disease that presents with focal neurologic deficits separated in space and time. Though most patients present with episodic deficits, some present with progressive disease. MRI, which confirms the diagnosis, typically shows white matter hyperintensities in the periventricu lar region, cortex, subcortical region, cerebellum, or spine.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Subacute combined degeneration, caused by demyelination of the dorsal columns, lateral corticospinal tracts, and spinocerebellar tracts, is a feature of vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency. Subacute combined degeneration causes a combination of motor and sensory 12 symptoms including ataxic gait, muscle weakness, paresthesia , and loss of proprioception and vibration sense. The effects of these features may include frequent falls, as in this case. Vitamin B deficiency is often a result of inadequate dietary intake, seen in 12 veganism, malabsorption, or pernicious anemia. Occasionally, elderly patients with poor nutrition may develop B deficiency. Other 12 manifestations include dementia and megaloblastic anemia. In an elderly patient with an acute or subacute change in behavior or activities of daily living, organic causes such as vitamin deficiency should be ruled out.

blood pressure is 170/96 mm Hg. Findings on right funduscopic examination are
shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting signs and symptoms of abrupt, painless vision loss and a pale fundus with normal foveal color are consistent with a diagnosis of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). CRAO commonly occurs as a result of embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery but may occur secondary to vasculitis, such as in giant cell arteritis (GCA). Patients may have a history of preceding amaurosis fugax. Examination shows profound diminishment of visual acuity, a relative afferent pupillary defect, and a pale fundus with preserved foveal color. CRAO is a medical emergency, as it an ischemic stroke of the ophthalmic vasculature and indicates a high risk for associated ischemic stroke to the brain. Patients who present with CRAO should be admitted to a stroke center for emergent evaluation, including a search for a possible embolic source with echocardiography and duplex ultrasonography of the carotid arteries. A careful history and laboratory evaluation of erythrocyte sedimentation rate, serum concentration of C-reactive protein, and platelet count should be performed to evaluate for possible GCA. There is no proven medical or surgical therapy for CRAO, and the visual prognosis Is poor.
explanation.educational_objective: Central retinal artery occlusion frequently occurs secondary to embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery in carotid or cardiac valvular disease. Patients present with acute, painless vision loss and examination findings including diminished visual acuity, relative afferent pupillary defect, and a pale fundus with preserved foveal color. Patients who present with central retinal artery occlusion should be admitted to a stroke center for emergent evaluation.

16. A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of facial numbness for 2 weeks. Her symptoms began as a "funny feeling" over a patch of
skin on the left side of her chin and have gradually progressed to a 1'novocaine" sensation. She has had no facial pain or numbness of the gums or
oral mucosa. She has a 3-year history of breast cancer metastatic to the lungs treated with tamoxifen. Examination shows supraclavicular
adenopathy. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and temperature is absent over the left side of the chin. Neurologic examination shows no other
abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely location of the abnormality?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Numb chin syndrome, or mental neuropathy, is an indication of bony metastasis to the mandible in this patient with a history of breast cancer. The mandibular (V branch of the trigeminal nerve passes through the bony canal of the mandible, branches to form the ) 3 inferior alveolar nerve, and branches again proximal to the mental foramen to form the mental nerve. The mental nerve branch affected by mandibular bony metastases provides sensory innervation to the ipsilateral skin of the anterior chin (another unaffected mental nerve branch provides sensory innervation to the ipsilateral lower lip and buccal gingiva). Compression of the mental nerve branch by bony metastasis of the mandible leads to anesthesia of the chin. Numb chin syndrome may indicate systemic malignancy, autoimmune disease (eg, multiple sclerosis), or may be related to local infection, trauma, or dental disease. This patient should receive full-body imaging to evaluate for metastatic spread.

pharmacotherapy?

the most appropriate initial

Topical lidocaine to the affected areas

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Peripheral neuropathy is a frequent finding in patients with HIV and may occur either secondary to direct viral infection of peripheral nerves or secondary to neurotoxicity associated with antiretrovira l medications, frequently medications in the nucleoside analog reverse-transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) class. HIV-associated neuropathy most frequently presents with symmetric, distal polyneuropathy characterized by sensations of burning, tingling, or numbness in a stocking-g love distribution, as well as reduced vibratory or pinprick sensation. As with other forms of distal polyneuropathy, tricyclic antidepressants such as nortriptyline are effective as first-line treatment. Other effective treatments include gabapentin, pregabalin, lamotrigine, and topical capsaicin or lidocaine.

vignette.presentation:
18. A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of moderate low back pain. He thinks he may have hurt his back while
doing yard work. His pain moderately improves with rest; he has been spending a great amount of time in bed. He has not had other symptoms,
weight loss, or a recent infection. He has no history of serious illness. His only medication is ibuprofen for the pain. He does not use intravenous
drugs or anabolic steroids. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Examination shows mild paraspinal muscle
tenderness. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Oxycodone therapy as needed for pain
Oxycodone therapy as needed for pain

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Low back pain is a common presenting complaint and it can be difficult to identify an exact underlying cause. Most nonspecific low back pain is attributed to musculoskeletal injury from exertion, overuse, or trauma. The majority of these cases will resolve with conservative management, which includes activity modification, stretching, over-the-counter analgesics such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), massage, acupuncture, and heat therapy. Certain red flag signs and symptoms should prompt more urgent evaluation for a cause, especially if there is concern for infection, malignancy, or fracture. These include new fevers, intravenous drug use, focal neurologic deficits (such as urinary retention, saddle anesthesia, bowel incontinence which may suggest cauda equina syndrome), progressive lower extremity neurologic symptoms, current or recent cancer history, advanced age, systemic corticosteroid use, and a significant traumatic mechanism. In this young, otherwise healthy patient with a mild inciting event, the

Activity modification for symptom relief should be advised, with encouragement to continue normal activities of daily living and non-exacerbating exertion. X-ray of the lumbar spine (
distractor_explanations.B: and MRI of the lumbar spine (
distractor_explanations.C: should be reserved for patients who present with red flag signs and symptoms to evaluate for evidence of fracture, infection, or malignancy. For otherwise healthy patients with back pain that has persisted for less than 4 weeks, imaging studies do not genera lly change management. Oxycodone therapy as needed for pain (
distractor_explanations.E: should be reserved for severe or refractory cases of acute low back pain. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Acute low back pain is a common presenting complaint in multiple medical settings. General management for pain persisting less than 4 weeks is conservative with over-the-counter analgesics, activity modification, and nonpharmacologic pain relief options. Initial imaging is not typically recommended in the absence of signs or symptoms suggestive of infection, malignancy, spinal cord compromise, or vertebral fracture. .,.
