vignette.presentation:
19. A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 3 weeks after operative repair of a circle of Willis berry aneurysm. Her
husband says that her behavior has changed since the operation. She is unmotivated and just sits around all day like a "bump on a log." She has
not had depressed mood. Examination shows psychomotor retardation. She is oriented to person, place, and time. She is cooperative and her
speech is fluent and grammatica l, but there is little spontaneous speech during conversation. Which of the following cerebral cortical regions is
most likely affected?

question_stem: most likely affected?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient is exhibiting symptoms of frontal lobe dysfunction. The frontal lobe is the largest lobe of the cerebral cortex, separated from the parietal lobe by the central sulcus. The major areas of the frontal lobe are the primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, prefrontal cortex, Broca area, and the frontal eye fields. Symptoms depend on the location of the lesion. Involvement of the primary motor cortex and premotor cortex result in impaired motor function of the contralateral side of the body and psychomotor retardation. Disruption of Broca area may cause expressive aphasia with retention of language comprehension. Lesions of the frontal eye fields result in ipsilateral deviation of the eyes. Dysfunction of the prefrontal cortex can result in disinhibition, apathy, personality changes, aggressive behavior, and impairments in judgement, concentration, and orientation, as exhibited by this patient. Patients should be evaluated for other medical causes of cognitive impairment, such as vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency, hypothyroidism, syphilis infection, and 12 intoxication. In this patient with a recent invasive procedure, CT scan or MRI of the brain is likely to show the diagnosis.

distractor_explanations.B: cortex lesions may result in impairments in emotional and/or sensory processing, motor control, and speech. Patients may display a progressive expressive dysphasia characterized by non-fluent and grammatically incoherent speech. Occipital (
distractor_explanations.C: lobe lesions typically present with difficulties in processing visual sensory inputs. Patients may complain of visual field cuts depending on the precise location of the lesion. Parietal (
distractor_explanations.D: lobe lesions manifest differently depending on the side affected. Dominant parietal lobe lesions, most commonly on the left side, may result in Gerstmann syndrome, characterized by agraphia, aphasia, agnosia, acalculia, and right-left confusion. Nondominant parietal lobe lesions typically manifest with hemineglect of the contralateral side. ....

explanation.educational_objective: The frontal lobe contains the primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, Broca area, frontal eye fields, and prefrontal cortex, which is involved in the regulation of behavior, inhibition, and other executive functions. Injury to the frontal lobe may result in personality or behavior changes, disinhibited behavior, expressive aphasia, and motor dysfunction. .,.
explanation.concept: The frontal lobe contains the primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, Broca area, frontal eye fields, and prefrontal cortex, which is involved in the regulation of behavior, inhibition, and other execu

vignette.presentation:
20. A 10-day-old newborn is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after a seizure that involved clonic jerking of the left arm. He had been well
until 2 days ago when he began sleeping somewhat more but continued to feed well. Pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Vital
signs are within normal limits. He is difficult to awaken but moves all extremities when stimulated. He is hypotonic but hyperreflexic. Babinski sign
is present. During examination, he has a clonic seizure of the right lower extremity. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. Cerebrospina l
fluid analysis shows:
Glucose 55 mg/dl
Protein 110 mg/dl
Leukocyte count 85/mm3
Erythrocyte count 860/mm3
A Gram stain is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neonatal herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis is the most likely diagnosis in this 10-day old infant with new onset seizures, a normal head CT scan, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing increased protein and leukocyte count with a low-normal glucose concentration, which is consistent with aseptic (nonbacterial) meningitis. Further suggestive is the presence of erythrocytes in the CSF which is often seen in herpetic encephalitis. Most cases of HSV encephalitis are caused by HSV-2, although infection with HSV-1 occurs and is treated in the same way. Most patients acquire the virus via transmission from the mother, often during the third trimester, with encephalitis developing usually within a week. Symptoms are nonspecific and include fever, lethargy, poor feeding, and occasionally seizures or focal neurologic deficits. Concomitant oral lesions may occur, but their absence does not rule out the diagnosis. The CSF findings include increased protein, lymphocytic pleocytosis, and a normal or low-normal glucose concentration. In many instances the causative virus can be identified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) of the CSF, although empiric therapy with intravenous acyclovir is warranted prior to diagnosis. Failure to recognize and treat infection can result in organ dysfunction and death, or long-term neurologic sequelae.
explanation.educational_objective: HSV encephalitis should be suspected in neonates who develop fever, lethargy, and/or neurologic symptoms, including focal deficits or seizures shortly after birth. A history of HSV infection in the mother may or may not be present. Evaluation of the CSF typically shows an increased protein concentration with a lymphocytic pleocytosis but normal glucose concentrations. Therapy is with intravenous acyclovir.
explanation.concept: HSV encephalitis should be suspected in neonates who develop fever, lethargy, and/or neurologic symptoms, including focal deficits or seizures shortly after birth. A history of HSV infection in the mo

vignette.presentation:
21. A 47-year-o ld woman comes to the physician because of increasingly frequent headaches during the past 3 months. The headaches are
throbbing, occur only on the right side, and are associated with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. She has had one or two
headaches yearly since the age of 17 years but now has two or three weekly. She is a schoolteacher and has had no changes in work, lifestyle, or
environment. Four months ago, conjugated estrogen therapy was begun for treatment of menopausal symptoms. Her temperature is
37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Butalbital therapy combined with acetaminophen and caffeine

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Migraine is a common condition that presents with recurrent primary headaches. Migraine headaches are typically severe, unilateral, throbbing, and associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia. The pain is usually located behind or adjacent to the eye. Some patients additiona lly experience an aura before or during the headache, which may present with vision loss followed by the perception of scintillating shapes or lines and/or paresthesia. Migraine triggers include stress, menstruation and changes in hormonal concentrations , weather changes, fasting, and alcohol. Sleep may improve migraines. Patients who experience migraines associated with conjugated estrogen therapy may require discontinuation of therapy or a reduction in dose. Migraines are postulated to arise from deficient serotonin inhibition of descending pain pathways. Acute migraine treatment may include triptans and/or nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). For patients with disabling or frequent migraines, prophylactic treatment is also recommended and includes ~-adrenergic blockers, antidepressants such as tricyclic antidepressants and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, and anticonvulsants.

23. A 72-year-o ld woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of pain in the left thigh and flank and weakness of the left leg. She has a
30-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus currently controlled with glyburide. Examination shows weakness of the left iliopsoas and quadriceps
muscles. Deep tendon reflex of the left quadriceps muscle is decreased. Sensation to pinprick is decreased over the left lateral thigh and medial
calf. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?

question_stem: the most likely location of the lesion?

choices.text: Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve J) S1 Radiculopathy

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Lower extremity neuropathies can be caused by nerve compression, ischemia, inflammation, degeneration, infection, or transection. Diabetic patients may develop spontaneous femora l neuropathies secondary to inflammation and ischemia. The femoral nerve arises from L2 to L4 and exits the lumbosacral plexus by passing under the inguinal ligament. Neuropathy of the femoral nerve or its roots presents with unilatera l quadriceps and iliopsoas weakness, decreased sensation over the anteromedial thigh and medial calf (the latter via its saphenous branch), and absent patellar tendon reflex.

vignette.presentation:
24. A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a progressive tremo r of his hands. He and his family have noticed that
his movements have become more shaky during this period and that he has been walking more slowly during the past year. He has hypertension.
Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and aspirin. There is no family history of serious illness. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His
pulse is 56/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a fine tremor of the hands at rest; the tremor is exacerbated with
movement. There is cogwheel rigidity of the upper extremities. His gait is slow and shuffling. Mental status examination shows no abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Carbidopa-levodopa is a dopamine agonist used to treat Parkinson disease by increasing the amount of dopamine available in the nigrostriatal pathway. Carbidopa and levodopa are given together in order to increase availability of levodopa to the brain. Levodopa is converted to dopamine by the enzyme dopa decarboxylase in the peripheral circulation and the brain. Dopamine is not able to cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB), so any levodopa which is converted to dopamine peripherally is unable to effect change in the basal ganglia. Carbidopa indirectly increases dopamine availability in the basal ganglia by inhibiting dopa decarboxylase peripherally. In this way, more levodopa is able to cross the BBB and be converted to dopamine in the brain, where it is then able to act on the nigrostriatal pathway. Increased dopamine leads to improvement of Parkinson disease symptoms including the tremor, rigidity, akinesia, and postural instability shown by this patient.

distractor_explanations.E: , a barbiturate, are both used in the treatment of essential tremor. This patient's resting tremor accompanied by unsteady gait and cogwheel rigidity is more consistent with Parkinson disease. Donepezil (
distractor_explanations.C: is an anticholinesterase inhibitor which indirectly increases the concentration of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine. It is used to treat Alzheimer disease. Acetylcholine and dopamine have opposing effects in the basal ganglia related to movement such that decreasing acetylcholine has the same effect as increasing dopamine. Thus, medications which decrease, not increase, acetylcholine are used in Parkinson disease. Nifedipine (
distractor_explanations.D: is a calcium channel blocker and does not play a role in the treatment of Parkinson disease. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Carbidopa-levodopa is the first-line treatment used in Parkinson disease. Carbidopa cannot cross the blood brain barrier. It therefore increases the bioavailability of levodopa to the brain without inhibiting the conversion of levodopa to dopamine in the brain.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hypertensive encephalopathy may result from acute and severe increases in blood pressure. It potentially manifests with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizure, and may progress to obtundation and coma. Visual symptoms may result from cortical dysfunction or from hypertensive retinopathy , including retinal hemorrhages and exudates. Treatment includes carefully lowering the blood pressure while avoiding excessively rapid drops in blood pressure, which can cause end-organ ischemia. In general, a decrease in the mean arterial pressure of 25% within the first hour is appropriate, with gradual correction over the

Cerebral infarction (

Patients typically present with acute focal neurologic deficits, especially on one side of the body, and may have speech difficulty, dysarthria, or aphasia. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (

vignette.presentation:
26. A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of excessive sleepiness and fatigue. She has required more sleep for several years, but the
problem has become increasingly worse during the past 7 months. She sometimes falls asleep in the middle of conversations and at dinner. She
recently collapsed onto the floor of her apartment; she was aware o1f her surroundings but unable to move for 5 minutes. She has no history of
seizures or other neurologic disorders. Her only medication is celecoxib for treatment of osteoarthritis. She appears well nourished. Physical
examination shows limited range of motion in the lower extremities. There is swelling and crepitus of the knees. She has moderate pain on
standing. An ECG, EEG, and 72-hour ambulatory ECG monitoring show no abnormalities. Polysomnography is pending. Which of the following is
the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Methylphenidate is a non-amphetamine central nervous system stimulant medication that is used in the treatment of narcolepsy, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with fatigue and episodes of cataplexy. Methylphenidate works by blocking the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine into presynaptic neurons. The pathogenesis of narcolepsy involves the loss of orexin-A and orexin-B, which are neurotransmitters found primarily in the hypothalamus that promote wakefulness and inhibit rapid eye movement (REM) sleep. Loss of these neurotransmitters permits abnormal transition from wakefulness to REM sleep with subsequent development of hallucinations and other features of narcolepsy including cataplexy and sleep paralysis. Diagnosis can be made in patients with daytime somnolence and cataplexy or, in cases where cataplexy is not present, with sleep latency testing. Polysomnography is appropriate to support the diagnosis and to rule out similar sleep-related conditions such as sleep apnea. Occasionally patients undergo lumbar puncture to directly measure concentrations of orexin-A in the cerebrospinal fluid, but this is generally not required for the diagnosis. Pharmacotherapy is directed at promoting wakefulness, and methylphenidate is one relatively safe and effective stimulant used to do this.

distractor_explanations.B: is an antidepressant that increases presynaptic release of serotonin and norepinephrine. It tends to cause drowsiness and weight gain and is occasionally used to treat patients with depression and sleep disturbances. Nortriptyline (
distractor_explanations.C: is a tricyclic antidepressant that is used to treat major depressive disorder and is used off label for a number of conditions including chronic pain, postherpetic neuralgia, and diabetic neuropathy. It can cause drowsiness. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Narcolepsy should be suspected in patients with daytime somnolence, hypnagogic hallucinations, or cataplexy. Diagnosis can be made clinically if cataplexy is present but otherwise requires sleep latency testing, which shows a shorter time from wakefulness to the initiation of REM sleep. Treatment is initially with stimulants such as methylphenidate, which promote wakefulness.
explanation.concept: Narcolepsy should be suspected in patients with daytime somnolence, hypnagogic hallucinations, or cataplexy. Diagnosis can be made clinically if cataplexy is present but otherwise requires sleep laten

vignette.presentation:
27. A 72-year-o ld right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the onset of double vision and right-sided weakness
that began while she was eating breakfast. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Medications include glyburide and atenolol. Her
temperatu re is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min and regular, and blood pressure is 170/105 mm Hg. She is alert and oriented. Her speech is fluent
but mildly slurred. She can follow complex commands. Cranial nerve examination shows left ptosis. Adduction and elevation of the left eye are
impaired. Ocular movements are full on the right. The right pupil is 3 mm, and the left pupil is 5 mm. The right pupil reacts normally, but the left
pupil does not constrict either to direct or consensual light stimulation. There is drooping of the right side of the mouth. Muscle strength is normal in
the left upper and lower extremities and is 4/5 in the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the right and 2+ on the left.
Babinski sign is present on the right and absent on the left. There is no ataxia. Sensation is intact. Which of the following is the most likely location
of this patient's lesion?

question_stem:
the most likely location
of this patient's lesion?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient likely has a lesion of the left midbrain that affects the cerebral peduncle and the oculomotor nerve, which causes contralateral hemiparesis and ipsilateral oculomotor palsy, known as Weber syndrome. The cerebral peduncle refers to the anterior portion of the midbrain and includes the crus cerebri, which contains the corticospinal tract and is supplied by paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery. A brainstem lesion of the corticospinal tract leads to contralateral weakness in an upper motoneuron pattern of dysfunction (eg, spastic paralysis, Babinski sign, and hyperreflexia). The corticobulbar tract (located within the cerebral peduncle) may also be affected in Weber syndrome, leading to facial droop and weakness. The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve Ill) is located anteriorly between the two cerebral peduncles and may be affected by strokes of the paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery, leading to ipsilateral dysfunction of the extraocu lar muscles and consequent diplopia, ptosis, and primary gaze palsy along with a deficit in pupillary constriction. Cerebral infarctions, or strokes, occur as a result of ischemic or hemorrhagic loss of blood supply to the brain. Risk factors for stroke include smoking, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, carotid or intracranial atherosclerotic disease, history of hypercoagulability, atrial fibrillation, and advanced age. Classically, strokes manifest as a neurologic deficit related to the affected part of the brain.

then spread to the right arm and the face. Neurologic examination shows normal findings. The most likely cause is a lesion at which of the
following sites?

question_stem:
The most likely cause is a lesion at which of the

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Focal neurologic deficits that start in one area of the body and spread are suggestive of partial seizure activity. Without an alteration in level of consciousness, this would be defined as a simple partial seizure manifesting with sensory symptoms, also called a simple partial somatosensory seizure. This type of seizure is most commonly associated with lesions of the parietal lobe as a result of the involvement of the primary somatosensory cortex, which processes sensory input from the contralatera l side of the body. Patients typically present with numbness, tingling, warmth, and/or pain. Other manifestations of parietal lobe epileptic activity may include receptive aphasia, dyslexia, and other language/comp rehensio n disturbances because of involvement of Wernicke area at the junction of the parietal and temporal lobes.

Simple partial seizure activity with motor symptoms may also occur because of involvement of the primary motor cortex. Brainstem lesions involving the medulla (

distractor_explanations.D: lesions are uncommon causes of focal seizure activity, but typically present with visual manifestations such as visual hallucinations, cortical blindness, and deviated gaze. ...

29. A 72-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of increasingly depressed mood, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, and a
decreased appetite resulting in a 2.3-kg (5-lb) weight loss. He was diagnosed with Parkinson disease 2 years ago. He also has hypertension and
benign prostatic hyperplasia. His medications are amlodipine, carbidopa-levodopa, and tamsulosin. He has smoked one and one-half packs of
cigarettes daily for 4 7 years. He states that he would like to stop smoking. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mild
cogwhee l rigidity, resting tremor of the hands, and gait instability. On mental status examination, he has a depressed mood and forlorn affect.
Results of laboratory studies, including thyroid function tests, are within the reference ranges. Addition of which of the following is the most
appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Bupropion can be utilized in patients with Parkinson disease, major depressive disorder, and nicotine use disorder to treat depression and promote abstinence from nicotine. Depression is a common complication of Parkinson disease. Since this patient's depression began after his Parkinson disease diagnosis, his depression is likely a result of Parkinson disease and should be diagnosed as depressive disorder caused by another medical condition. Many patients with this diagnosis improve once the medical condition resolves. Since Parkinson disease does not remit, the depression should be treated pharmacologically. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are first-line medications for patients with major depressive disorder and are frequent ly utilized for patients with comorbid Parkinson disease and major depressive disorder because of their effectiveness and low risk for adverse effects. However, serotonergic medications are not effective for smoking cessation. Bupropion is an antidepressant medication that increases the reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine (which targets depressive symptoms) and antagonizes the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (which targets tobacco use). Bupropion can increase blood pressure, so this patient with a history of hypertension should have his blood pressure monitored closely.

However, none of these medications are effective for smoking cessation. - . - . .... r ~ - - ,- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - - - - - " - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - r- - - ,- - - - - - -

30. A 72-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of visual hallucinations during the past 2 weeks. She has a 10-year
history of hypertension and a 5-year history of Parkinson disease. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, metoprolol, and
carbidopa-levodopa. Three weeks ago, her carbidopa-levodopa dose was increased because of decreased mobility, and metoprolol was added to
her medication regimen because of inadequate blood pressure control. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 10 years
ago. She drinks one glass of wine with dinner every night. Her temperatu re is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 58/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood
pressure is 148/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Neurologic examination shows a resting tremor of the
hands and cogwheel rigidity. Deep tendon reflexes are absent at the ankles. Her gait is shuffling. Mental status examination shows a constricted
affect. She is oriented to person but not to place or time. She can recall one of three objects after 5 minutes. She says she sees ghost-like figures
entering the room. Results of laboratory studies are within the reference range. A CT scan of the head shows mild atrophy. Which of the following
is the most likely cause of this patient's visual hallucinations?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's visual hallucinations?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Adverse effect of carbidopa-levodopa is the most likely cause of this patient's visual hallucinations. Parkinson disease is a progressive neurologic disease that manifests with bradykinesia, rigidity, masked facies, and a resting tremor. It is secondary to the destruction of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra, so pharmacotherapy focuses on replacing dopamine with carbidopa-levodopa. Frequently, early in the disease course, treatment is effective, but over time, many patients experience an "on-off'' phenomenon whereby pharmacotherapy only works for a short time after each dose before the effects dissipate. This often prompts an increase in the dose of carbidopa-levodopa, or a change in the dosing interval, but in elderly patients this can result in multiple off-target adverse effects including hallucinations. This patient has no evidence of another underlying medical illness that may cause hallucinations, so the

As the disease progresses, patients often require increasingly higher doses, which can cause hallucinations. If this occurs, the dose should be lowered. An alternative therapy for Parkinson disease includes deep brain stimulation. .,.

vignette.presentation:
31. A 77-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of increasingly severe low back pain for 3 months. He has had poor control of bowel and
bladder function for 2 weeks. He fell yesterday on his way to the bathroom. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 60 years. Examination
shows marked weakness of the lower extremities, normal upper extremity strength, bilateral brisk deep tendon reflexes in the lower extremities, a
sensory level at T9, and a flaccid anal sphincter. There is tenderness over the lower thoracic spine. Babinski sign is present. Which of the following
is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Epidural metastatic carcinoma resulting in spinal cord impingement is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with bowel and bladder incontinence, bilateral lower extremity weakness with hyperreflexia, and a sensory level at T9 that has developed over the preceding 3 weeks. Vertebral masses may be the first presenting sign of a systemic malignancy, or they may be a late complication of metastatic disease. In either scenario, large masses can result in compression of the spinal cord at any segment, with subsequent sensory and motor deficits below the affected segment. In this instance, the sensory level at T9 likely indicates the presence of a mass at or just above the T9 vertebra l body in the epidura l space, with compression of the spinal cord at that level. Masses related to cancer must be distinguished from abscesses or hematomas, as the treatment between the entities differs significantly. Depending upon the type of cancer, steroids or radiation may be an initial option to reduce the inflammation associated with malignant compression of the spinal cord. In many cases, surgical decompression is required.

distractor_explanations.A: can occur as a result of metastatic spread of a primary malignancy to the meninges around the brain, but it would present with headache and often with cranial nerve deficits. It does not present with neurologic evidence of spinal cord dysfunction. Cervical spondylosis (
distractor_explanations.B: refers to gradual, age-related degenerative changes of the cervical spine with osteophyte development ....

explanation.educational_objective: Lung, breast, and prostate are the most common malignancies that have a predilection for the spine. Metastatic disease within the epidural space can cause compression of the spinal cord, with consequent development of a distinct sensory level, bowel and bladder incontinence, and weakness below the level of the lesion. Depending upon the type of malignancy, steroids, radiation, and/or surgical intervention may be required to relieve the compression.

32. A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his friend 30 minutes after being found unconscious in his bed. The patient lives
alone in a trailer park, and his friend says he was well the night before. The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He
does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. He appears well nourished. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are
20/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. The nail beds and oral mucosa are pink. Neurologic examination shows no meningismus. The pupils
are 4 mm and sluggishly reactive. The doll's eye (oculocephalic) reflex is intact. There is no verbalization or eye opening in response to painful
stimuli. He withdraws all extremities symmetrically to painful stimuli. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ throughout. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally.
Results of laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a Pco of 30 mm Hg and Po of
2 2
80 mm Hg. In addition to supportive care, which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient's condition?

question_stem: the most appropriate therapy for this patient's condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning occurs as a consequence of inhaling the gas, often because of its generation in an area of poor ventilation (eg, a garage with door shut and car running, a space heater in a poorly-ventilated room, a malfunctioning basement furnace). CO is a byproduct of combustion. When inhaled, it avidly crosses the pulmonary capillary membrane and tightly binds hemoglobin, inducing a conformationa l change in the molecule and preventing the binding of oxygen. CO has an affinity for hemoglobin that is hundreds of times greater than that of oxygen, readily displacing oxygen from heme. CO also has affinity with the mitochondrial electron transport chain, thus, in addition to hypoxemia resulting from interference with oxygen carrying capacity, cells may not be able to make use of the oxygen that they do receive via aerobic metabolism. As a result, anaerobic metabolism dominates, and lactic acidosis caused by hypoxia ensues. Symptoms of CO poisoning include headache, loss of consciousness, dizziness, vomiting, and fatigue; in severe cases, seizures, dysrhythmias, coma, and death may occur. Examination may show red skin. Treatment for CO poisoning begins with the administration of 100% oxygen regardless of pulse oximetry readings, and if any neurologic symptoms or signs of end-organ dysfunction are present, as in this case, hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be indicated.

vignette.presentation:
33. A 5-year-old girl has the insidious onset of a clumsy gait over the past 3 months. Examination shows pes cavus of the left foot. There is
generalized diminished girth of the left leg, and a decreased tendon reflex of the left ankle. The tendon reflexes at the knees are brisk. There is a
sacral tuft of hair. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Tethered spinal cord, a defect in neural development whereby a caudal portion of the spinal cord becomes tethered to fixed fibrous structures that cause traction on the cord as the patient grows, is the most likely diagnosis. The filum terminale is a band of tissue that stretches between the caudal portion of the spinal cord and the sacrum, and persistent tethering of the spinal cord results in stretching as the child develops and axial growth occurs. Depending upon the severity, symptoms may present at infancy or can develop many years later, but progressive lower extremity neurologic dysfunction is typical as the spinal cord stretches and bends during normal activity. Sensory and gait abnormalities are typical, and bladder or bowel incontinence may also occur. Low back pain that worsens with activity and pain in the perineum can also occur. Clues to diagnosis include a tuft of hair over the sacrum or the presence of hemangiomas or dimples in the same region. Early detection and surgical intervention can improve symptoms and halt the progression of neurologic dysfunction.

distractor_explanations.A: is a genetic disorder that leads to early ataxia with progressively worsening gross and fine motor capabilities as children reach school age. Other findings include oculocutaneous telangiectasias and immunodeficiency. Friedreich ataxia (
distractor_explanations.B: is caused by a loss of function mutation in the frataxin gene resulting from a trinucleotide repeat. Patients usually present in adolescence with progressive ataxia of all limbs and dysarthria. Distal sensory loss and dysphagia may also be seen. Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (
distractor_explanations.C: has a diverse presentation but patients usually develop systemic symptoms including fevers and rash in addition to arthritis, which may affect nearly any joint. It does not present with asymmetric gait abnormalities or hyperreflexia. Spastic diplegia (
distractor_explanations.D: is a subtype of cerebral palsy and presents with symmetric spasticity of the lower extremities with associated sensory loss. In rare cases, the upper extremities may be involved, and intellectual disability can occur. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Tethered cord syndrome occurs when a caudal portion of the spinal cord remains attached to fibrous tissue near the sacrum leading to progressive stretching of the spinal cord as the child grows. It presents with either symmetric or asymmetric weakness and sensory changes in the lower extremities, and clues to the diagnosis include the presence of a sacral dimple or tuft of hair. .,.

34. A 42-year-old woman with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of progressive right-sided weakness, slurred speech, and
headache. She is right-handed. Funduscopic examination shows papilledema. Neurologic examination shows aphasia, right homonymous
hemianopia, and right-sided spastic weakness. A CT scan of the head with contrast shows multiple small ring-enhancing lesions with surrounding
edema and mass effect in the left frontal, right occipital, and left parietal lobes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Toxop/asma gondii is an intracellular protozoan parasite. Transmission can occur through the ingestion of oocysts from cat feces or infected meat, direct transmission between a mother and fetus, or from organ transplantation, which leads to invasion followed by dissemination of the parasite where it typically lies dormant. It is a ubiquitous organism and nearly 10% of individuals will be seropositive for T gondii, but the parasite does not usually cause severe disease in immunocompetent individuals. In patients with HIV infection and CD4+ T-lymphocyte counts less than 100 cells/mm 3, however, reactivation can occur with several distinct clinical syndromes of which cerebral toxoplasmosis results in the most morbidity. Cerebral toxoplasmosis typically presents with multiple ring enhancing lesions scattered throughout the brain. Seizures, focal neurologic deficits, and systemic symptoms are common, as are signs of increased intracranial pressure. Patients with HIV infection and positive Toxop/asma lgG antibodies are typically treated empirically with a sulfonamide and pyrimethamine if cerebral toxoplasmosis is suspected, but confirmatory diagnosis occurs through a brain biopsy, which will show a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells, along with the presence of the T gondii organism. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an AIDS-defining disease.

distractor_explanations.A: is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, an encapsulated fungus and opportunistic pathogen in immunocompromised patients. It can cause cryptococca l meningitis, encephalitis, and pulmonary cryptococcosis. Meningoencepha litis presents subacutely with fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity, often accompanied by cough and shortness of breath caused by concurrent pulmonary infection. Focal neurologic deficits and mass lesions on neuroimaging are rare. Cysticercosis (
distractor_explanations.B: is caused by Taenia so/ium and presents with headache, seizures, and increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging will show cystic, ring-enhancing, calcified lesions in the brain parenchyma, meninges, ventricles, spinal cord, and/or orbit. It less commonly presents with focal neurologic deficits such as those seen in this patient. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxop/asma gondii, an intracellular protozoan parasite that is most commonly transmitted via the ingestion of cat feces or infected meat. In immunocompromised patients, particularly AIDS patients with CD4+ T lymphocyte counts less than 100 cells/mm 3, it can cause cerebral toxoplasmos is, which presents with seizures, focal neurologic deficits, systemic symptoms, and increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging will show multiple ring-enhancing lesions, and treatment is with pyrimethamine and sulfonamide therapy.

35. A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of progressive numbness and weakness of his legs. Six
years ago, he had non-Hodgkin lymphoma treated successful ly with chemotherapy and radiation therapy. He is currently taking no medications.
Cranial nerve examination shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength is intact in the upper extremities but 3/5 in the proximal lower extremities and
4/5 in the distal lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ in the upper extremities and 3+ in the lower extremities. Babinski sign is present
bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick is decreased below the level of the nipples, and sensation to vibration is decreased over the feet and ankles.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Metastatic spinal cord compression occurs most commonly in prostate, lung, or breast cancer, although it can occur with any malignancy. It is generally caused by vertebral bony metastases that tend to occur in the vertebral body, particularly of the thoracic spine. Its presentation depends on the level of the lesion and the degree of spinal cord compression. Symptoms include back pain, which is often worse at night or with lying down, muscle weakness, sensory abnormalities, bladder or bowel dysfunction, and gait instability. It will generally present with an upper motoneuron pattern of injury in the lower extremities with hyperreflexia and positive Babinski signs, as in this patient, assuming the compression is in the thoracic or upper lumbar region. Ascending numbness or paresthesias are also common. Diagnosis is classically made utilizing MRI of the spine. Patients may be treated with glucocorticoids, radiation therapy, and/or surgical decompression and spine stabilization.

Most chemotherapy-induced polyneuropathy will improve over time after chemotherapy is stopped, making this a less likely explanation for this patient's acute onset of symptoms. distractor_explanations.B: is caused by autoimmune-mediated nerve destruction following a systemic infection, such as Campy/obacter jejuni. It classically presents with ascending paralysis with absent deep tendon reflexes that begins in the lower extremities. It can also ascend to involve the upper extremities, diaphragm, and cranial nerves in some patients. Myopathy (

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis K) Hypothyroid myopathy

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is likely given insidious onset of upper and lower motoneuron deficits. ALS is caused by the progressive destruction of motoneurons. Patients may develop asymmetric weakness of the extremities. Unilateral hand weakness, foot drop, and bulbar symptoms (eg, dysphagia, voice changes) may occur simultaneous ly. On physical examination, the presence of both upper motoneuron signs such as hyperreflexia and spasticity, combined with lower motoneuron signs such as hyporeflexia suggests the diagnosis. Parkinsonian features such as masked facies, tremor, and shuffling gait may occur, as can autonomic dysfunction. Eventually, patients develop respiratory insufficiency. The clinical progression is relentless and results in death.

vignette.presentation:
37. A 27-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 4-week history of difficulty with speech and weakness of his right leg. He has a 5-year
history of HIV infection treated with antiretroviral therapy. On admission, his temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Examination shows thrush. There is mild
nonfluent aphasia. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the right lower extremity. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the right lower extremity and 2+ elsewhere.
Babinski sign is present on the right. An MRI of the brain shows six ring-enhancing lesions in the cerebral hemispheres bilaterally; the largest
lesion is in the left frontal lobe. Some of the lesions have surrounding edema. Pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine therapy is started. Two weeks later,
there is no improvement in his symptoms. A second MRI of the brain shows no decrease in the size of the lesions, and some have increased in
size. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma is a rare variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs most commonly in immunocompromised patients. It can occur in the brain, spinal cord, leptomeninges, or eyes. Presenting symptoms include focal neurologic deficits, vision changes, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, headache, nausea, emesis). In immunocompetent patients, neuroimaging will most commonly show a solitary, hypodense periventricular mass with well defined borders and mild surrounding edema. In immunocompromised patients, however, the development of primary CNS lymphoma is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, with additional risk factors in HIV including a decreased CD4+ T lymphocyte count, increased viral load, and chronic co-infection with hepatitis B or C virus. Imaging in immunocompromised patients more commonly shows multifocal disease, numerous, ring- or heterogeneously enhancing lesions throughout the corpus callosum, periventricular areas, and periependyma l regions. The diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow cytometry or cytology, with evidence of EBV DNA in the CSF supporting the diagnosis. Treatment typically consists of high-dose and generally intrathecal chemotherapeutics and antiretroviral therapy.

distractor_explanations.A: of the brain can occur in immunocompromised patients. These are typically microabscesses that can lead to the development of encephalopathy with altered mental status and are seen on MRI as small, ring-enhancing lesions often with a hemorrhagic component. However, these patients commonly present with fever, nuchal rigidity, and headache, which this patient does not demonstrate. ....

explanation.educational_objective: CNS lymphoma is a rare form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs in immunocompromised patients with focal neurologic deficits, vision changes, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging will show ring enhancing lesions that do not improve with sulfadiazine or pyrimethamine therapy.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Vascular dementia is the second most common form of dementia after Alzheimer type, characterized by stepwise cognitive decline following recurrent cerebral infarctions (strokes). The rate of decline and specific symptoms depend on the regions of the brain affected, and patients typically develop cognitive impairment, motor dysfunction, and behavioral changes as the disease progresses. Risk factors include age, hypertension, obesity, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and prior cerebrovascular accidents. Diagnosis is made clinically with support of neuroimaging demonstrating cerebral ischemic changes. Risk factor reduction is the primary approach to prevention. Continued control of blood pressure is most likely to decrease the risk for this patient developing vascular dementia.

distractor_explanations.C: is recommended for patients who have existing clinically significant cardiovascular disease (such as history of a myocardial infarction or cerebrovascular event). It is not likely to significantly lower the risk for vascular dementia in this patient. Daily vitamin D and calcium supplementation (
distractor_explanations.E: is recommended for women who are postmenopausal, patients taking chronic systemic corticosteroids, and patients with advanced renal disease to reduce the risk for osteoporosis and fragility fractures. explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) refers to bleeding into the subarachnoid space and can be caused by aneurysmal or non-aneurysma l rupture of an artery in the subarachnoid space. Patients typically present with an acute, severe headache (often described as the worst headache of their life), along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases. Fever can be associated with SAH and is associated with worse outcomes. CT scan of the head typically shows hyperdense blood products in the cerebral sulci and basal cisterns. However, the sensitivity of CT scan for SAH is lower with small volume bleeding or a delayed presentation. If there is strong suspicion for SAH with a negative CT scan, a lumbar puncture can be performed, which may show red blood cells or xanthochromia, which represents hemoglobin degradation products. As the blood products circulate within the subarachnoid space, complications include the development of communicating and/or obstructive hydrocephalus in the acute stage, along with the potential for re-bleeding and vasospasm in the days following the initial bleed. It is a neurosurgical emergency that may be fatal if progressive or untreated.

Discharging the patient with analgesic therapy (

The patient is at risk for hydrocephalus, vasospasm, rebleeding, or severe hemorrhage after a sentinel bleed. .... r ~ - - ,- ------ --- -- -- - -- -- --- - -- - - - -- - - -- --- - -- - - -- -- - - - - -- r - - - , - -

vignette.presentation:
41. A 37-year-old woman with alcoholism is hospitalized for detoxification. On the second day after admission, she has an impaired sensorium and a
decreased attention span during examination. She appears frightened and disoriented and shrieks, "Make the snakes go away." Her temperature
is 38.3°C (101 °F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 190/120 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in
management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate next step in
management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient has developed delirium tremens, a serious complication of alcohol withdrawal. Alcohol increases the central nervous system activity of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), the main inhibitory neurotransmitter. Abrupt discontinuation of alcohol results in imbalanced and unopposed sympathetic excess. Uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal typically presents with tremors, anxiety, restlessness, headache, nausea, and diaphoresis, which can begin within hours after the cessation of alcohol use. Delirium tremens, the most concerning and life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal, involves severe confusion and disorientation, fluctuations in consciousness, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability (generally characterized by tachycardia, hypertension, and potentially hyperthermia). As in this patient, delirium tremens can begin 2 to 5 days after the patient's last alcoholic drink. Delirium tremens is managed supportively with benzodiazepines (GABAA receptor agonists) to address the psychomotor agitation associated with withdrawal and prevent the worsening of withdrawal manifestations. The specific benzodiazepines utilized include chlordiazepoxide, a long-acting benzodiazepine given on a scheduled basis in patients experiencing or at risk for complicated withdrawal (eg, delirium tremens), and/or lorazepam, a short-acting benzodiazepine given as-needed for withdrawal symptoms. Management also includes frequent assessments including vital sign checks, fluid resuscitation, and nutritional supplementation (especially with commonly deficient vitamins and minerals such as thiamine, potassium, and magnesium).

distractor_explanations.A: and oral thioridazine (
distractor_explanations.C: , a first-generation antipsychotic, would be unnecessary in this patient whose acute-onset disorientation and hallucinations are consistent with delirium tremens. Psychosis and agitation related to alcohol withdrawal should be treated with benzodiazepines rather than antipsychotics. Intravenous antibiotic therapy (
distractor_explanations.D: would be unnecessary in this patient whose hyperthermia and tachycardia are consistent with delirium tremens rather than infection. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Delirium tremens is a life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal related to decreased GABA activity that presents with severe confusion, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability. Benzodiazepines are GABAA receptor agonists utilized to treat agitation during withdrawal and prevent the worsening of withdrawa l manifestations. .,.

42. An otherwise healthy 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after the sudden onset of severe low back pain and
severe shooting pain down her left buttock and leg. The pain began when she arose quickly from a seated position to open a sliding glass door.
Two analgesic tablets leftover from a dental procedure provided no relief. She is an avid cyclist. On arrival, intravenous administration of morphine
is begun and provides minimal relief. The patient notes numbness over the perineum when she attempts to void. She is reluctant to move from a
flexed, seated position to a stretcher because of the pain. Muscle strength is 3/5 on great toe extension, dorsiflexion, and plantar flexion of the left
foot. Knee jerk is present on the left. Achilles tendon reflex is absent on the left. An MRI of the lumbosacra l spine shows a large central herniation
at L4-5 that compresses the L5 and S1 nerves on the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cauda equina syndrome occurs as a result of compression of the spinal nerve roots comprising the cauda equina. Often, such compression occurs because of malignancy, trauma (eg, compression fractures with fragment retropulsion), disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal epidural abscess, or spinal epidural or subdural hematoma. Symptoms include lower extremity numbness, weakness, paralysis, hyporeflexia, perinea! anesthesia, fecal incontinence with poor rectal tone, and overflow incontinence marked by inability to void and urinary retention. Emergent MRI of the lumbosacral spine is indicated to investigate the cause of cauda equina syndrome, and to determine the necessity of surgical decompression. Initial treatment for patients with epidural spinal cord compression and neurologic deficits include symptomatic treatment, pain control, and glucocorticoid therapy prior to operative therapy. High-dose glucocorticoid therapy is helpful as a bridge to definitive therapy, can help control pain, and may transiently improve neurologic function secondary to decreasing edema at the site of cord compression. However, cauda equina syndrome is a surgical emergency and requires decompression with lumbar laminectomy as soon as possible.

Diagnosis is made with MRI and definitive treatment includes emergent surgical decompression with lumbar laminectomy. .,.

43. A 32-year-o ld man comes to the physician 2 hours after the onset of dizziness, nausea, and unsteadi ness. He had a whiplash neck injury 2 years
ago and is still receiving monthly chiropractic man ipulations. His voice is hoarse . There is left ptosis and nystagmus . The left pupil is 2 mm smaller
than the right. There is decreased sensation to pain over the left side of the face and right extrem ities. He has ataxia on the left. Mental status
examination shows no abnorma lities. Which of the following arteries is most likely to be occluded?

question_stem: most likely to be occluded?

choices.text: Left anterior cerebral I) Right carotid
Left carotid J) Right middle cerebral
Left middle cerebral K) Right ophthalmic
Left ophthalmic L) Right posterior cerebral
Left posterior cerebral M) Right vertebra l

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient likely has an occlusion of the left vertebra l artery leading to vertebrobasilar insufficiency. Vertebrobasi lar insufficiency can be caused by ischemia in patients with poor sympathetic regulation or thromboembolism common ly originating from an atherosclerotic plaque in or dissection of the vertebra l artery (known as a posterior circulation stroke). A thrombus of the vertebral artery commonly forms from atherosclerotic disease but may also form as a result of an intimal defect from trauma or vertebra l artery dissection, a known complication of chiropractic manipu lation. The brain stem, cerebellum, and occipital lobes are common ly affected. Patients typically present with vestibu locerebe llar signs (eg, ataxia, dysmetria, dizziness, imbalance, vertigo, vomiting, nystagmus), ipsilateral cranial nerve dysfunction (eg, dysphagia, dysarthria, vertical or horizonta l gaze palsies), contralateral hemiparesis (caused by corticospinal tract damage), contralateral impairment in pain and temperature sensation (caused by spinothalamic tract damage), and/or contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (caused by posterior cerebral artery involvement). In posterior circulation strokes affecting the lateral pons, Horner syndrome may occur, which presents with unilateral ptosis and miosis (pupillary constriction) and ipsilateral facial anhidrosis. If no hemorrhage is shown on noncontrast CT scan of the head, acute management of posterior circulation strokes may involve tissue plasminogen activator therapy or thrombectomy. In dissection, antiplatelet and anticoagu lant administration is indicated to prevent conversion to a thromboembolic stroke if none has yet occurred.

and takes no medications. Menses occur at irregular 2- to 10-week intervals . She has had an 18-kg (40-lb) weight gain during the past 7 months.
She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and now weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally.
Visual field testing shows no abnorma lities. Funduscop ic examination shows blurred optic discs; there are no spontaneous venous pulsations. The
remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A CT scan of the head shows small lateral ventricles. On lumbar puncture, the opening

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Impaired resorption of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is the primary mechanism behind pseudotumor cerebri, or idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). IIH is characterized by signs of increased intracranial pressure including headache, papilledema, and increased opening pressure on lumbar puncture without any underlying pathology to cause such findings on neuroimaging. It is primarily seen in young women who are overweight. Although there is no malignant cause underlying the increased intracranial pressure, it may cause debilitating headaches and permanent vision loss. Headaches that are secondary to increased intracranial pressure often are worse when lying down and relieved by standing. The most common risk factors for the development of pseudotumor cerebri include female gender and obesity. However, hypervitaminosis A from increased dietary intake is another potential cause of IIH. This can be from excessive dietary intake or from the use of retinoid medications such as isotretinoin or all-trans retinoic acid. Other medications associated with IIH include tetracyclines, danazol, and growth hormone.

the left cheek, and an abrasion on the right elbow. Neurologic findings are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Mild traumat ic brain injury, also known as a concussion, commonly results in the loss of consciousness, confusion, amnesia, headache, dizziness, nausea, and/or vomiting minutes after the injury. A concussion can be caused by direct or indirect blunt head trauma and typically causes self-limited brief neurologic impairment , such as the loss of consciousness, repetitive questioning, or confusion. Symptoms that commonly develop within the following days include mood disturbances, photophonophobia, trouble concentrating, and/or insomnia. Patients do not have focal neurologic symptoms such as limb weakness or vision changes that would indicate traumatic vascular injury or intracran ial hemorr hage. All patients with suspected concussion should undergo a thorough neurologic examination, and a subset of at-risk patients should receive neuroimaging. All patients should be monitored closely for neurologic deterioration, which may indicate a developing intracran ial hem1atoma. To prevent cumulative brain injury (eg, from a second concussion), patients with concussion should return to their usual activities in a graded fashion, beginning with the return to school and without return to sports until cleared by a physician.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient is presenting with symptoms suggestive of spinal stenosis with neurogenic claudication. Spinal stenosis describes narrowing of the central canal, neural foramen, or lateral recesses of the spine with subsequent nerve compression and ischemia. Common causes include degenerative arthritis, spondyloarthropathies, degenerative disc disease, hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum, and osteophyte formation in the facet joints. Neurogenic claudication describes low back pain with radiation to the buttocks and lower extremities that results from increased nerve compression, as may occur with extension of the spine during standing and walking downhill. Reducing narrowing within the spinal column with spinal flexion as during sitting or walking uphill tends to relieve the pain. Diagnostic evaluation involves x-ray imaging followed by MRI of the lumbar spine.

distractor_explanations.C: can be used to confirm the presence of radiculopathy caused by nerve root compression or evaluate for other myopathy or neuropathy as the cause of the patient's symptoms. These tests are reasonable if the diagnosis is still in doubt after the initial imaging studies. MRI is the most appropriate

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's examination findings of attention deficit (likely neglect) and left arm drift are suggestive of the presence of a contralateral upper motoneuron lesion, which, in conjunction with her symptoms of new chronic headache, is suggestive of a brain tumor. Hemispatia l neglect often occurs as a result of lesions of the parietal cortex and may also occur in stroke. Similarly, left arm drift may be suggestive of an upper motoneuron lesion in a variety of locations, such as the contralateral frontal cortex, cerebellum, or pyramida l tract. Collectively, this patient's findings localize her lesion to the right parietal cortex.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Radiation-induced brachia! plexopathy is a potential complication of radiation to the brachia! plexus, most commonly occurring after radiation therapy for breast or lung cancer. Radiation damages the brachia! plexus and presents with symptoms of brachia! neuritis, including pain, paresthesia, and weakness in the distribution of the affected nerves that may occur months or years after the initial insult. In this scenario, the radiation has likely affected the C5 and C6 nerve roots (called Erb Palsy), leading to dysfunction of the deltoid, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and biceps brachii muscles, resulting in impaired upper extremity abduction, lateral rotation, flexion, and supination. Consequent ly, the patient's upper extremity hangs near the body in a medially rotated, extended, and pronated position as shown in the photograph. Lymphedema of the upper extremity can also result from radiation-induced fibrosis of the lymph nodes and is often associated with radiation-induced brachia I plexopathy. Neoplastic brachia! plexopathy should be ruled out with MRI. Treatment is supportive and includes brachia! decompression surgery, pain management, and physical and occupationa l therapy.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neurologically impaired patients should not be assumed to lack decisional capacity to make decisions about their care. The medical team should evaluate the decisiona l capacity of this patient who is making decisions about his end-of-life care. This patient is able to communicate a consistent decision and demonstrate an appreciation of the consequences of his decision, and therefore, he appears to possess decisiona l capacity to make the decision to withdraw care. The medical team should respect the patient's autonomy and withdraw care. If a patient lacks decisional capacity, the medical team should identify a surrogate decision-maker. Unless the patient has identified a durable power of attorney, the spouse should serve as decision maker (adult children are typically second in line, followed by parents). Further reassuring in this case is that the patient's wife and adult children corroborate his decision. His estranged daughter's wishes may not reflect the patient's wishes, and given demonstrated decisional capacity with support from surrogates, the patient's wishes should be respected.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Carbamazepine is a common antiepileptic medication. It has been shown to interact with other medications and caution should be exercised when choosing concomitant medications for treating patients. It is a CYP450 inducer, which may increase hepatic clearance of some medications (eg, warfarin, phenytoin, valproic acid), leading to subtherapeutic concentrations in the serum. Other drugs, such as erythromycin, can interfere with the hepatic metabolism of carbamazepine by inhibiting CYP450 enzymes, leading to decreased carbamazepine clearance, increased serum concentration, and toxicity. Carbamazepine toxicity typically presents with altered mental status, drowsiness, ataxia, nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting. Diagnosis can be made by measuring a serum carbamazepine concentration above therapeutic levels, and there is a dose-dependent effect on neurologic depression. Treatment is supportive, with benzodiazepines for seizures or agitation, and involves discontinuation of offending medications.

2. A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive billateral leg pain over the past year. The pain is located on the posterior aspect
of the thighs and calves, occurs only when he is standing, and resolv,es within 30 seconds of sitting or lying down. He has noticed that the pain is
less intense if he leans on something as he walks, such as a grocery cart. He can still ride an exercise bicycle without developing any pain. He has
hypertension, hyperlipidemia , and a small abdominal aortic aneurysm. He had a left carotid endarterectomy 3 years ago after several transient
ischemic attacks in the left hemisphere. Medications include lisinopril, lovastatin, and aspirin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for
30 years. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 110 kg (242 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations
are 12/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a right femoral bruit and diminished pedal pulses. Which of the following is
the most likely cause of this patient's lower extremity pain?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's lower extremity pain?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient's symptoms are most consistent with neurogenic claudication caused by lumbar spinal stenosis. Spinal stenosis describes narrowing of the central canal, neural foramen, or lateral recesses of the spine with consequent nerve compression. Common causes include degenerative arthritis, spondyloarthropathies, degenerative disc disease, hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum, and osteophyte formation in the facet joints. Neurogenic claudication describes lower back pain with radiation to the buttocks and lower extremities that results from increased nerve compression, as may occur with extension of the spine during standing and walking downhill. Lengthening the spinal column with spinal flexion as during sitting, walking uphill, or leaning against a grocery cart, tends to relieve the pain. Diagnostic evaluation involves x-rays followed by MRI of the lumbar spine to evaluate the degree of spinal stenosis and whether surgical management is necessary.

distractor_explanations.A: is a concern in this patient with multiple risk factors and a history of transient ischemic attacks; however, progressive bilateral leg pain that is worsened or relieved by postural changes is more consistent with lumbar spinal stenosis. Persistent or new motor or sensory deficits would be more concerning for cerebrovascular disease. Lumbosacral plexopathy (
distractor_explanations.C: describes a diverse range of motor and sensory disturbances to the lower extremities, including weakness, paresis, pain, numbness, and tingling, resulting from lesions of the lumbosacra l plexus. Patients typically display abnormalities along multiple contiguous nerve root distributions. Diagnostic evaluation includes a thorough neurologic and .... r ~ -- - - ,- - - - - - - -- - - - - -- - - - - - - - -- - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - r,

3. A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of dribbling fluid from her mouth every time she drinks. She has not had
difficulty swallowing or any other symptoms. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She has an active lifestyle. Vital signs
are within normal limits. Examination shows drooping of the lower lip on the left. The left forehead does not wrinkle on upward gaze. The remainder
of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Bell palsy refers to a facial nerve palsy that leads to unilateral facial paralysis. It is most commonly caused by viral-mediated inflammation or immune reaction in the setting of a herpes simplex or herpes zoster infection, although it can also be idiopathic or caused by other viral infections. It presents acutely with unilateral facial paralysis that includes the forehead, consistent with its lower motoneuron pathologic involvement. It can also be associated with loss of taste on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and decreased lacrimation. Symptoms typically peak around 3 weeks, with slow recovery beginning within 6 months. Diagnosis is most commonly based on clinical symptoms, but electrodiagnostic tests, such as EMG, and imaging of the face and head can be utilized if the diagnosis is unclear. Initial treatment consists of oral glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, and antiviral therapy in severe cases.

However, a stroke that affects the facial musculature would spare the forehead. Additiona lly, this patient has no risk factors for stroke or symptoms such as extremity weakness or numbness to suggest this as an underlying diagnosis. MRI of the brain (
distractor_explanations.B: is useful in the evaluation of stroke, especially early in the course of the disease, before it may be evident on CT scan. This patient's symptoms are not consistent with stroke. Doxycycline therapy (
distractor_explanations.C: can be used in the treatment of Lyme disease, which may present with Bell palsy in disseminated Lyme disease. Lyme disease also typically presents with erythema migrans, fatigue, headache, myalgias, arthralgias, and lymphadenopathy, as well as myocarditis, abnormal liver function tests, and kidney injury. This patient has no other signs or symptoms to suggest Lyme disease. .... r ~ -- -, - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - r - - - , - - -

4. A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of imbalance and leg weakness and a 3-day history of difficulty initiating
urination. He also has had mild midthoracic back pain for 5 months, but during the past 2 weeks, the pain has worsened and frequently awakens
him. He has had a 9-kg (20-lb) weight loss since an episode of bronchitis 6 months ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years.
He is cachectic and appears chronically ill. Examination shows scleral icterus. Muscle strength in the lower extremities is decreased in the proximal
and distal muscles bilaterally. There is no muscle atrophy, but tone is increased. Deep tendon reflexes are hyperactive, and Babinski sign is present
bilaterally. Sensation is decreased to pinprick to the umbilicus. Muscle strength, sensation, and reflexes in the upper extremities are normal. Which

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting signs and symptoms of focal back pain, upper motoneuron signs, and weight loss are suggestive of epidural spinal cord compression caused by metastatic carcinoma. Metastatic disease frequently affects the vertebral column and may cause compression of the spinal cord by extending into the epidural space or by causing bony destruction and fracture of the vertebral bodies. Patients present with back pain, lower extremity weakness, loss of balance, urinary or bowel incontinence, or complete paralysis of the lower extremities. Early detection and treatment are crucial to prevent permanent spinal cord damage and myelopathy. Patients may benefit from short-term treatment with intravenous dexamethasone to decrease spinal cord edema, although definitive treatment often requires a combination of surgical decompression, chemotherapy, and/or radiotherapy.

Neuroimaging may be required to distinguish this entity from compressive spinal cord lesions. This patient's history of subacute onset and weight loss is more suggestive of a compressive epidural malignant lesion. Syringomyelia (

two blocks or stands for more than 10 minutes; sitting or bending forward provides relief within 1 minute. She has not had weakness or loss of
sensation. Bladder function has been normal. She has a 20-year history of lower back pain relieved with rest. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus well
controlled with metformin. Muscle strength is full. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ except for absent ankle reflexes. Sensation is intact. There is

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient's symptoms are best explained by lumbar spinal stenosis. Spinal stenosis describes narrowing of the central canal, neural foramen, or lateral recesses of the spine with consequent nerve compression. 6. An otherwise healthy 77-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of severe dizziness. Several times every day she
has the sudden onset of a spinning sensation and loss of equilibrium that lasts for 20 to 30 seconds. The episodes begin most frequently after she
rolls over in bed or turns her head to the right. Her pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows no
abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Doppler ultrasonography of the carotid arteries

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a common cause of vertigo and is best diagnosed with positional oculovestibular testing. BPPV occurs when an otolith becomes dislodged from the utricle and enters the semicircular canals. Changes in head posture then cause the malpositioned otolith to move within the semicircular canals, stimulating abnormal movements in endolymph and causing a sensation of vertigo. Patients typically report symptoms of intense, brief episodes of vertigo that occur after changes in position (such as after rolling over or rising from bed), accompanied by visual disturbances (caused by nystagmus), nausea, and vomiting. Positional oculovestibular testing, such as the Dix-Hallpike test, allows the examiner to reproduce the patient's symptoms by repositioning the otolith. Further positional maneuvers, such as the Epley maneuver, can be used to move the malpositioned otolith to its proper position within the utricle. Patients with refractory symptoms may benefit from medical management including scopolamine or meclizine.

distractor_explanations.B: , or tilt testing, is useful for the diagnosis of orthostasis. While orthostasis may cause position-dependent symptoms of vertigo, presyncope, or syncope, these symptoms are more likely to occur upon suddenly standing, rather than while rolling in bed or turning one's head. Holter monitoring (
distractor_explanations.C: , or ambulatory ECG monitoring (24-hour), is useful for the diagnosis of cardiac arrhythmia. Cardiac arrhythmia is unlikely to produce paroxysmal symptoms with a positional component that is dependent on rolling in bed or turning one's head. ....

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Abnormal sympathetic neural response, also known as reflex sympathetic dystrophy or complex regional pain syndrome, can potentially occur after traumatic injuries and has a variety of clinical characteristics. Commonly, patients will develop pain out of proportion to the degree of injury in a distinct anatomic location that does not correspond to a single nerve or dermatome. The exact pathophysiology is unknown but is thought to involve either changes in central pain processing or aberrant stimulation of damaged peripheral nerves that release inflammatory substances such as neuropeptide Y and substance P. Common clinical manifestations include pain out of proportion to the injury with severe allodynia, impaired muscle strength in the location of injury, autonomic changes including increased sweating and color or temperature changes, and occasionally atrophy or fibrosis.

Symptoms include sensory and motor disturbances in the distribution of the median nerve and depend upon the location at which the median nerve is affected. Post-traumatic arthritis (

Like most cases of osteoarthritis, pain is localized to the affected joint and worsens with activity but improves with rest. Temperature changes and sensory changes of the skin are not seen unless the traumatic injury also resulted in trauma to local tissues or nerves. - Radial artery thrombosis (

vignette.presentation:
8. A 25-year-o ld woman has had generalized weakness for 2 days. On quest ioning, she reports numerous hospital admissions for abdominal pain.
One episode occurred after treatment of a urinary tract infection with a sulfonamide. Examination shows global weakness and areflexia; Babinski
sign is absent. Sensation to pinprick is mildly decreased in a stocking-glove distribut ion, and sensation to vibration is decreased over the feet. She
has tachycardia that does not slow with carotid massage. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acute intermittent porphyria is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with episodic abdominal pain and peripheral neuropathy in a stocking-glove distribution, which is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the porphobilinogen deaminase gene (PBGD). This enzyme catalyzes the third step in heme synthesis, which combines four porphobi linogen (PBG) molecules into hydroxymethylbilane, which is subsequently converted to uroporphyrinogen Ill. Loss of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of PBG, which is toxic to the nervous system. Additionally, increased activity of the upstream enzyme, delta-aminolevulinic acid synthase (ALAS1) leads to accumulation of ALA, which is also toxic. The mutation affects both erythroid cells and hepatocytes. The disease's manifestations are primarily neurologic and include periphera l neuropathy, bladder dysfunction, and autonomic dysfunction. Abdominal pain is classic and results often from ileus. The penetrance is low, so a family history is not often present, which can delay the diagnosis. Disease flares can occur after exposure to certain triggers such as certain medications, tobacco and alcohol, stress, and starvation.

distractor_explanations.B: presents with a primary sensory neuropathy that starts in the feet and progresses proximally. A history of chronic alcohol intake is required for this diagnosis. Other nutritional deficiencies are often present as well. Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (
distractor_explanations.C: is a genetic disorder that presents with slowly progressive peripheral neuropathy often in association with foot deformities such as hammertoes and pes cavus. A family history is typical. Diabetic radiculopathy (
distractor_explanations.D: occurs most commonly in patients with recently diagnosed or uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, and is -- - - -- -- -- - - -- - - -- -- - - -- - - -- - - -- -- - - -- -- ....

explanation.educational_objective: Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant disease with low penetrance caused by deficiencies in the PBGD gene leading to the accumulation of hepatically synthesized heme intermediates, which are toxic to the nervous system. Typical findings include episodic abdomina l pain, sensory neuropathy, and autonomic dysfunction that occurs after certain triggers.
