vignette.presentation:
9. A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of stiffness and pain of her neck, shoulders, and hips. She has difficulty
dressing herself and combing her hair in the morning. She also has had generalized weakness, malaise, and a low-grade fever. She has had a
2.3-kg (5-lb) weight loss during the past month despite no changes in diet. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is occasiona l
acetaminophen for pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows pitting edema of the hands and the dorsal aspects of the feet.
Range of motion of the neck, shoulders, and hips is limited. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 110 mm/h. Additiona l laboratory findings, including
her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration, are within the reference ranges. X-rays of the shoulders and feet show no abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory condition in which aching and stiffness develop in the shoulders, hip, and neck. The most common risk factors are age (older than 50 years) and being female. It is also frequently associated with giant cell, or temporal arteritis, which presents with unilateral headache and vision loss, if untreated. Other inflammatory signs, such as malaise and fever, are often present, though localized muscle weakness is not typically seen. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates increased inflammatory markers, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein, and thrombocytosis. Polymyalgia rheumatica is responsive to glucocorticoids, which are the first-line therapy for the disease. Low-dose prednisone is the treatment of choice.

distractor_explanations.A: is inflammation of one or more bursae and is manifested by pain and swelling over a single joint. Some examples include the subacromial bursa which can cause pain in the shoulder, the trochanteric bursa which can cause pain over the lateral aspect of the hip, and the olecranon bursa which can cause pain and swelling posterior to the elbow. When inflamed or injured, fluid can collect inside the potential space of the bursa causing swelling, which can be appreciated on examination as a fluctuant, tender, circumscribed mass. Muscle stiffness is not a typical feature. Dermatomyositis (
distractor_explanations.B: and polymyositis (
distractor_explanations.E: are autoimmune inflammatory myopathies characterized by muscle weakness, rather than stiffness, of the proximal muscles. Dermatomyositis additionally demonstrates cutaneous findings including a Ii ht ink- or heliotro e-colored rash on the e elids and Gottron a ules on the dorsal fin ers.

explanation.educational_objective: Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory condition in which aching and stiffness develop in the muscles of the hip and shoulder girdles. Low-dose prednisone is the treatment of choice.
explanation.concept: Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory condition in which aching and stiffness develop in the muscles of the hip and shoulder girdles. Low-dose prednisone is the treatment of choice.

11. A 42-year-old man comes to the physician with his wife because of a 6-month history of increasing clumsiness and a 1-month history of irritability.
His wife has noticed jerkiness of his limbs when he walks down stairs or walks quickly. During the past month, he has had the same involuntary
movements at rest after stressful days at work. He has not had fever, chills, or night sweats. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use
illicit drugs. He goes camping several times yearly. He does not appear to be in distress. Examination shows involuntary movements of the right
upper extremity, which the patient is able to suppress when made aware of them. His gait is ataxic. Additional testing is most likely to show which
of the following abnormalities?

most likely to show which
of the following abnormalities?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Atrophy of the caudate nucleus on brain imaging would be expected in this patient who most likely has Huntington disease, a progressive neurodegenerat ive condition that arises from misfolded proteins as the result of a trinucleotide expansion in the Huntington gene. Patients develop choreiform movements, which are characterized by involuntary flailing motions of the upper extremities. Eventually, these motor disturbances and others, including ataxic gait, greatly interfere with daily life. Concomitant psychiatric disturbances such as emotional !ability, anxiety, depression, and psychosis may also occur in the later stages of the disease. Many patients exhibit a family history of similar symptoms, but the disease can also arise de novo. Since this is an autosomal dominant disease, there is a 50% chance that an affected individual will pass it on to offspring. Anticipation, whereby symptoms manifest at progressive ly earlier ages and/or more severely in subsequent generations, is also typical of this disease.

distractor_explanations.C: are seen in patients with hydrocephalus, which can either be communicating or noncommunicating. Patients can present with headaches, nausea, vomiting, or gait instability but would not typically exhibit choreiform movemen.ts. . . . . . . .. . . ... . - . . - - . - -

12. A previously healthy 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of difficulty communicat ing. His wife
reports that when he awoke this morning, he seemed slightly confused and "did not make sense." He has hyperlipidemia treated with simvastatin.
He does not appear to be in distress. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 35 kg/m2 . His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F),
pulse is 85/min and irregular, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Examination shows mild right pronator drift. During the
examination, he is attentive but has some difficulty naming objects correctly and following two-step commands. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation.
Which of the following is this patient's greatest risk factor for his neurologic condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The acute onset of focal neurologic deficits, motor weakness, confusion, and dysphasia is concerning for a thromboembo lic cerebral infarction, or stroke. Atrial fibrillation is a major independent risk factor for strokes, and stroke prevention is an essential aspect of management. The loss of coordinated atrial contraction in this dysrhythmia results in blood stasis within the atrial compartment and promotion of thrombus formation. Embolism to the cerebral arteries results in ischemic stroke. The presence of right-sided hemiplegia and expressive dysphasia are suggestive of a lesion involving the left middle cerebral artery distribution. The middle cerebral arteries are the most common cerebral arteries involved in acute thromboembolic stroke.

distractor_explanations.A: , hyperlipidemia (
distractor_explanations.C: , increased blood pressure (
distractor_explanations.D: , and weight (
distractor_explanations.E: are all additional risk factors for cardiovascular disease and stroke. Other risk factors include tobacco use, diabetes mellitus, presence of mechanical heart valves, hypercoagu lable conditions, patent foramen ovale (allowing for passage of paradoxical venous thromboembo lism to the systemic circulation), heart failure with severely decreased ejection fraction, and a personal or family history of prior stroke. The presence of atrial fibrillation in this patient is the greatest risk factor for a stroke.

explanation.educational_objective: Atrial fibrillation is a major independent risk factor for ischemic stroke. Preventative anticoagulation should be considered for patients with additional risk factors, such as congestive heart failure, hypertension, advanced age, diabetes mellitus, prior stroke or transient ischemic attack, and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

17. A 37-year-old woman with a 10-year history of HIV infection comes to the physician because of headache and fever for 2 days. Her temperature is
38.9°C (102°F). Examination shows confusion and mild weakness of the left upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are increased, and
Babinski sign is present on the left. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 4/mm3 (Normal~500), and plasma HIV viral load is 60,000 copies/ml. Which
of the following is the most likely finding on MRI of the brain?

question_stem: the most likely finding on MRI of the brain?

choices.text: Diffuse leukoaraiosis with periventricular white matter changes
Markedly enlarged sulci with generalized loss of brain matter
Markedly enlarged ventricles with minimal changes in sulci
Mass lesion within the substance of the right frontal cortex with shift to the left of midline structures
Opaque mass over convexity of left frontal cortex with compress ion of brain substance

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Toxop/asma gondii is an intracellular protozoan parasite. Transmission can occur through the ingestion of oocysts from cat feces or infected meat, direct transmission between a mother and fetus, or from organ transplantation, which leads to invasion followed by dissemination of the parasite where it typically lies dormant. It is a ubiquitous organism and nearly 10% of individuals will be seropositive for T gondii, but the parasite does not usually cause severe disease in immunocompetent individuals. In patients with HIV infection and CD4+ cell counts less than 100 cells/mm 3, however, reactivation can occur with several distinct clinical syndromes of which cerebral toxoplasmosis results in the most morbidity. Cerebral toxoplasmosis typically presents with multiple ring-enhancing lesions within the substance of the cerebral cortex, most commonly the frontal and parietal lobes, although single lesions can occur. It is commonly associated with cerebral edema, which may result in mass effect and shifting of adjacent structures. Seizures, focal neurologic deficits, and systemic symptoms are common, as are signs of increased intracranial pressure. Patients with HIV and positive toxoplasma lgG antibodies are typically treated empirically with a sulfonamide and pyrimethamine if cerebral toxoplasmosis is suspected. If necessary, the confirmatory diagnosis occurs through a brain biopsy, which will demonstrate a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells, along with the presence of the T gondii organisms. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an AIDS defining disease.

explanation.educational_objective: Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxop/asma gondii, an intracellular protozoan parasite that is most commonly transmitted via ingestion of cat feces or infected meat. In immunocompromised patients, particularly AIDS patients with CD4+ T lymphocyte counts less than 100 cells/mm 3, it can cause cerebral toxoplasmosis, which presents with seizures, focal neurologic deficits, systemic symptoms, and increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging will show one or more ring-enhancing lesions within the cerebral cortex, and empiric treatment is with pyrimethamine and sulfonamide therapy.

vignette.presentation:
20. An 80 year old man briefly loses consciousness and falls to the floor in a grocery store. He awakens within 1 minute and feels dizzy, but after
several minutes the dizziness passes. His pulse is 80/min; his blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg while supine and 150/86 mm Hg while standing.
Cardiac examination and ECG show no abnormalities. During the physical examination , when his head is turned to the right, he suddenly loses
consciousness and motor tone. While unconscious, his pulse is 40/min. He awakens within 20 seconds and feels slightly dazed, but this feeling
passes after 1 minute. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Carotid sinus hypersensitivity syndrome is characterized by an exaggerated response to carotid baroreceptor stimulation, presenting with resultant sinus bradycardia, hypotension, and syncope. Baroreceptors located at the carotid bifurcations and the aortic arch are important in regulating cardiac output and maintaining adequate perfusion pressures to the brain and organs of the upper body. Baroreceptors are sensitive to mechanical pressure; normally, an increase in blood pressure stimulates baroreceptor activity, which activates a reflex arc resulting in parasympathetic innervation of the sinoatrial and atrioventricular nodes, and inhibition of sympathetic vascular tone. This results in a decreased heart rate and periphera l vascular resistance and may result in syncope, especially in older adults. In carotid sinus hypersensitivity syndrome, this response may be triggered by mechanical compression of the carotid sinus from external palpation or with movement of the muscles of the neck. Cardiac examination and diagnostic studies are often unrevealing.

distractor_explanations.B: , also called focal onset impaired awareness seizures, is characterized by localized motor or sensory symptoms associated with loss of awareness during episodes. Generalized loss of motor tone and bradycardia are more suggestive of carotid sinus hypersensitivity. Idiopathic orthostatic hypotension (
distractor_explanations.C: is unlikely to explain this patient's symptoms given normal orthostatic vital signs on examination. Orthostatic hypotension is characterized by tachycardia in response to the decreased preload, rather than bradycardia as observed in this patient. Vasodepressor syncope (
distractor_explanations.D: , also called vasovagal syncope, is common and results from an acute decrease in peripheral vascular resistance with an inadequate responsive increase in cardiac output to maintain perfusion pressure to the brain. Common triggers include standing for long periods of time, heat, and intense emotion or pain. In this case, the onset of symptoms when the patient's head is turned to the right raises concern for carotid sinus hypersensitivity. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch detect changes in mean arterial pressure to appropriate ly regulate perfusion pressures to the brain and body organs. Carotid sinus hypersensitivity can result in the abnormal provocation of this reflex arc, causing sinus bradycardia and syncope. .,.

vignette.presentation:
21. An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a 5-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She has a 1-year
history of sudden jerking movements of her hands and arms; the episodes frequently occur while she is getting ready for work in the morning. On
arrival, she is confused but gradually becomes oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 80/min,
respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mm Hg. On examinat ion, ocular movements are full. The remainder of the examination
shows no abnormalities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ throughout. In addition to valproic acid therapy, supplementation with which of the following
is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Supplementation with folic acid should be prescribed in all women of child-bearing age taking anti-epileptic drugs, particularly valproic acid. Valproic acid increases sodium channel inactivation and increases y-aminobutyric acid (GABA) concentration, leading to anti epileptic effects. However, it also increases the risk for neural tube defects by twenty-fold when taken during the first trimester of pregnancy. Supplementation of folic acid prior to conception is effective in lowering the risk of neural tube defects. Patients without other risk factors can take the standard dose of folic acid, 0.4 mg daily, while patients on anti-epileptics other than valproic acid should take 1 mg daily, and patients on valproic acid should take 4 mg daily. Valproic acid is also used to treat migraines and bipolar disorder, and the same folic acid supplementation should be recommended in those cases.

distractor_explanations.C: deficiency causes variable manifestations including dry beriberi (peripheral neuropathy with mental 1 status change), wet beriberi (dilated cardiomyopathy leading to heart failure), and Wernicke encephalopathy (confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia). Since the patient does not demonstrate any of these findings, supplementation with thiamine is unnecessary. Vitamin B (pyridoxine) (
distractor_explanations.D: supplementation is needed in patients taking isoniazid. Without it, pyridoxine deficiency develops, 6 which is characterized b eri heral neuro ath , dermatitis, sideroblastic anemia, lossitis, and seizures.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Vitamin B , or thiamine, deficiency causes two potential syndromes: Wernicke encephalopathy and Korsakoff dementia. The classic 1 triad of Wernicke encephalopathy demonstrates encephalopathy, ataxia, and oculomotor dysfunction. If Wernicke syndrome is allowed to progress without treatment, Korsakoff syndrome may develop, which is manifest by retrograde and anterograde amnesia, confabulation, and horizontal nystagmus. Wernicke encephalopathy develops in patients with extreme malnourishment and/or alcohol use disorder. While a serum thiamine concentration may be decreased, this is not useful in managing patients as it cannot be checked quickly. Thus, diagnosis is clinical and should be rapidly treated with intravenous thiamine administration.

This most commonly occurs in the context of vegan ism, pernicious anemia, and Crohn disease. It is 12 not necessary to supplement in the case of Wernicke encephalopathy. Oral lactulose therapy (
distractor_explanations.E: is the treatment of choice for hepatic encephalopathy. This is most commonly seen in patients with cirrhosis whose ability to process ammonia from the gastrointestina l tract is impaired. 23. A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after an episode of flaccid paralysis and numbness of the left upper and lower
extremities that lasted 2 hours. During the episode, she was unable to see objects in her left visual field. Neurologic examination now shows no
abnormalities. A CT scan of the head shows no lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Rupture of a cerebral artery aneurysm

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction lasting less than 24 hours caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia without evidence of infarction. This patient has developed focal neurologic deficits that resolved after 2 hours, qualifying as a TIA. TIA can be induced by either an embolus arising from a proximal site or from temporarily decreased blood flow to a watershed area in the brain. A hypotensive TIA typically lasts until resolution of the low-flow event while an embolic TIA lasts hours, as in this case. An embolic ischemic stroke involves an event in which a clot breaks off and travels to the brain, occluding blood flow within a cerebral artery. Emboli most commonly originate from proximal vessels, such as the internal carotid artery, or from an atrial thrombus. If the embolus successfully undergoes physiologic thrombolysis, blood flow is restored to the affected area and reverses the clinical symptoms. After a TIA, measures for prevention of an ischemic stroke should be enacted, along with evaluation for the potential source of embolus, such as carotid artery doppler and echocardiography.

distractor_explanations.B: , frontal lobe meningioma (
distractor_explanations.D: , and temporal lobe astrocytoma (

vignette.presentation:
24. A 25-year-old farm worker is brought to the emergency department because of the sudden onset of headache, dizziness, nausea, and vomiting
while picking peaches. His pulse is 52/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. He has generalized weakness, diaphoresis, and pinpoint pupils.
Which of the following precautions should medical professiona ls take while caring for this patient?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Organophosphates are commonly found in insecticides and exposure to them can occur transcutaneously, or via inhalation or ingestion. Organophosphates bind to and are inhibitors of acetylcholinesterase, preventing the breakdown of acetylcholine (ACh), which leads to excess concentrations of ACh in the neuromuscular junction. ACh acts on both nicotinic and muscarinic ACh receptors. Nicotinic ACh receptors are found in autonomic ganglia, adrenal medulla, and skeletal muscle, whereas muscarinic ACh receptors are found in heart, brain, smooth muscle, exocrine glands, and sweat glands. Resultant cholinergic excess leads to bronchospasm, bronchorrhea, bradycardia, diarrhea, lacrimation, and salivation. Because of the potential for organophosphate toxicity via transcutaneous exposure, medical professionals should always wear rubber gloves when treating the patient. Treatment involves decontamination of the patient, along with atropine to antagonize the muscarinic receptors, and 2-pralidoxime to regenerate functional acetylcholinesterase.

distractor_explanations.A: or wearing a surgical mask (
distractor_explanations.C: would not be as protective as wearing gloves. This patient was likely transcutaneously exposed to organophosphates while picking peaches, so wearing protective rubber gloves is a priority. Wearing no protective equipment (
distractor_explanations.D: would not be advised, since medical professionals treating the patient could inadvertently be exposed to organophosphates by touching the patient.

explanation.educational_objective: Organophosphates are commonly found in insecticides and exposure to them can occur transcutaneously, or via inhalation or ingestion. Because of the potential for organophosphate toxicity via transcutaneous exposure, medical professionals should always wear rubber gloves when treating the patient.

25. A 62-year-o ld man with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive shortness of breath. The
shortness of breath is exacerbated when he is supine. His only medication is an 81-mg aspirin tablet daily. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes
daily for 30 years but stopped 10 years ago. His pulse is 76/min and regular, respirations are 18/min while sitting and 26/min while supine, and
blood pressure is 112/78 mm Hg. There is no jugular venous distention. Scattered rhonchi are heard on auscultation; they resolve with coughing.
An S is heard. Abdom inal examination shows retractio ns of the abdom inal walls with inspiration. There is no peripheral edema. Which of the
4
following is the most likely cause of his shortness of breath?

question_stem: the most likely cause of his shortness of breath?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder arising in midlife that affects both lower motoneurons arising from the anterior horn and upper motoneurons of the lateral corticospina l tract within the brain and spinal cord. Neurons degenerate as the result of an unknown cause that may involve RNA processing and/or excitotoxicity. Patient presentations are variable, though typically feature a combination of upper motoneuron (eg, increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign) and lower motoneuron findings (eg, decreased muscle tone, hyporeflexia, early muscle atrophy) in an asymmetric distribution that may include the bulbar muscles. Some patients may experience cognitive or behavioral changes, though other patients are cognitively normal. The diagnosis is primarily clinical but may be supported by electromyographic findings of acute and chronic denervation. ALS is a progressive disease with death usually occurring within 3 to 5 years of diagnosis, most commonly secondary to neuromuscular respiratory failure. This patient's dyspnea with lying supine is most likely secondary to diaphragmatic paralysis caused by his ALS. Symptoms of diaphragmatic paralysis worsen in the supine position, as gravity no longer assists in contracting and moving the diaphragm downward.

distractor_explanations.A: occurs most commonly in the setting of reactive airway disease, such as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. It typically presents with shortness of breath and wheezing on auscultation that is not position-dependent. While this patient may have some degree of reactive airway disease secondary to his significant smoking history, his symptoms are more consistent with diaphragmatic paralysis. ....

explanation.educational_objective: ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects both lower and upper motoneurons. Death typically occurs secondary to neuromuscular respiratory failure, with diaphragmatic paralysis presenting with dyspnea that is worse in the supine position.

26. A 14-month-old infant is brought to the physician because of four episodes of loss of consciousness over the past month. While in the office, the
infant has a typical episode. Prior to onset, the infant became fretful when his pacifier was taken away. He cried for 30 seconds, then stopped
crying and breathing and became rigid and cyanotic. There are no clonic movements and no response to noxious stimuli. His eyes deviate upward
conjugately; the pupils do not respond to direct or consensual light. Faint heart sounds are heard on apical auscultation; a pulse cannot be located.
He recovers without intervention and returns to normal behavior within 10 minutes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Syncope triggered by emotional distress in this infant was likely caused by a breath-holding episode. Breath-holding episodes are common paroxysmal events that occur between ages 6 months and 6 years and are typically triggered by stress-induced autonomic dysfunction in the form of transient profound bradycardia. The typical sequence of events is crying, followed by breath holding in forced expiration and cyanosis, then muscle rigidity and shaking, and finally atonia and loss of consciousness. The eyes may deviate upward, and the pupils may dilate. Episodes may recur several times (weekly on average). Physicians should assess patients for iron deficiency anemia, which is commonly associated with breath-holding episodes, and treat with iron if deficient. Breath-holding episodes typically remit spontaneously.

distractor_explanations.A: are generalized seizures that cause transient staring episodes with intact consciousness after the seizure. This patient transiently lost consciousness (did not respond to noxious stimuli), and the characteristic sequence of events for a breath holding episode would be atypical for an absence seizure. No medications (
distractor_explanations.B: are known to cause breath-holding episodes. Carotid artery trauma (
distractor_explanations.D: may lead to carotid artery dissection and ischemic stroke. However, this patient does not demonstrate persistent neurologic deficits consistent with a stroke. Nor does he present symptoms of carotid sinus syncope which results from pressure against the carotid sinus baroreceptors. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Breath-holding episodes are common paroxysmal events in infants and toddlers typically arising from stress induced autonomic dysfunction. Patients typically present with breath holding in forced expiration, acute cyanosis, muscle shaking and atonia, and loss of consciousness, which occur after crying. .,.

27. A 22-year-o ld woman comes to the physician because she has had a black spot that occludes her vision in her right eye fo r 1 day. She also has
pain in the right eye. There is no history of trauma. Exam ination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye; the best corrected vision in the right
eye is 20/200. The left pupil is normal; the right reacts sluggish ly to direct light but consensua lly. Funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities.
The eyes are not injected . Which of the following is the most likely site of the lesion?

question_stem: the most likely site of the lesion?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Optic neuritis results from autoimmune demyelinating inflammation of the optic nerve (crania l nerve II) and presents in young, often female, patients with unilatera l vision loss and pain that is exacerbated with extraocular movements. Ocular examination demonstrates decreased visual acuity and color vision, a relative afferent pupillary defect (rAPD), and possibly optic disc edema. Diagnosis is confirmed with MRI demonstrating hyperintensity of the optic nerve. Patients with optic neuritis are at an increased risk for multiple sclerosis (MS), and optic neuritis is a common initial finding in patients with MS. Recently, autoantibodies against myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) and aquaporin-4 (AQP4) have been identified as a causative factor of some cases of optic neuritis. Patients who develop optic neuritis because of antibodies against MOG and AQP4 often have severe presentations but also have a decreased risk for subsequent MS compared with patients with optic neuritis who lack these autoantibodies. The Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial demonstrated that a short course of treatment with high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone speeds the rate of visual recovery and delays the onset of MS, although it does not impact final visual acuity, and demonstrated that the presence and quantity of periventricular white matter lesions on MRI imaging is the most important prognostic risk factor for the subsequent development of MS.

distractor_explanations.A: coordinates ocular saccades, pursuit movements, and gaze holding. Cerebel lar lesions do not cause an .... a r ~I• , r,

explanation.educational_objective: Optic neuritis is an autoimmune, inflammatory disorder of the optic nerve (cranial nerve II) that presents with acute onset vision loss and ocular pain that is exacerbated with extraocular movements. Patients typically present with profound ly decreased visual acuity and color vision, along with a relative afferent pupillary defect. Diagnosis is confirmed with MRI and with testing for serum autoantibodies. MRI provides importan t prognostic information regarding the subsequent risk for developing multiple sclerosis, which commonly occurs in association with optic neuritis. Treatmen t with high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone speeds visual recovery and delays the onset of multiple sclerosis.
explanation.concept: Optic neuritis is an autoimmune, inflammatory disorder of the optic nerve (cranial nerve II) that presents with acute onset vision loss and ocular pain that is exacerbated with extraocular movements.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Sleep paralysis, a manifestation of the atonia that primarily occurs during REM sleep, happens during the transition from sleep to wakefulness at least once in most people's lives. The precise mechanism of sleep paralysis during the transition to wakefulness is unknown, but stress, psychiatric disorders, sleep deprivation, and substance use may increase the risk. This patient's preceding stress and potential sleep deprivation and substance use during spring break may have contributed to his sleep paralysis episode. Patients are typically distressed during the episode and may experience an associated feeling of impending doom. Other features of REM sleep may also intrude into transitions from sleep to wakefulness or wakefulness to sleep (eg, hypnopompic or hypnagogic hallucinations). Management of an isolated sleep paralysis episode consists of reassurance and education about normal sleep behavior. If sleep paralysis episodes persist, then the patient should be evaluated for narcolepsy.

distractor_explanations.B: would confirm a diagnosis of narcolepsy. Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder that involves deficient orexin secretion, leading to the repeated intrusion of sleep phenomena (eg, sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis) into times of wakefulness. An isolated episode would not be concerning for narcolepsy. Psychiatric assessment (
distractor_explanations.C: and toxicology screening (
distractor_explanations.D: are unnecessary. Though this patient experienced stress, possibly contributing to the sleep paralysis, a single episode of sleep paralysis during wakefulness is common and not an indication of a psychiatri.c o r .su bstance use disorder. . .. . . . .. -- - - - - - - - atients with a normal standard EEG when the h

explanation.educational_objective: Sleep paralysis, a manifestation of the atonia that primarily occurs during rapid eye movement (REM) sleep, happens during the transition from sleep to wakefulness at least once in most people's lives. After a single episode of sleep paralysis, reassurance is appropriate, but if sleep paralysis recurs, narcolepsy should be ruled out. .,.

sign is present bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick and temperature is decreased over the dorsal forearms and hands. Her gait is broad based and

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cervical spondylotic myelopathy is a spinal cord syndrome caused by compression of the cervical spinal cord by degenerated vertebral bodies, facet joints, and/or herniated intervertebral discs. The process begins with progressive degeneration of these surrounding bony structures, which then causes impingement on the central spinal canal. Depending on the level of involvement, the exact symptoms will differ. In most cases, compression of the spinal nerves at the level of the degenerative changes will cause lower motoneuron findings including weakness, hyporeflexia, and atrophy, as seen in the upper extremities of this patient. In contrast, compression of the tracts within the spinal cord, including the lateral corticospinal tract, will cause weakness with upper motoneuron findings in the levels inferior to the degenerative changes. As in this patient, hyperreflexia and an upgoing Babinski sign will be present. The spinothalamic tract may also be compressed, leading to impaired pain and temperature sensation.

distractor_explanations.D: is an intracranial tumor that grows along the falx cerebri and may compress the adjacent cerebral cortex, possibly including the primary motor cortex in the lower extremity portion of the motor homunculus. This has the potential to cause weakness of the lower extremities with findings of upper motoneuron disease. he says that he falls occasionally. He has a 1-month history of sharp right-sided abdominal pain that is exacerbated by coughing, sneezing, and

negative. He has hypertension treated with atenolol. His temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg.
Examination shows tenderness to percussion over the midthoracic spine. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the iliopsoas, hamstrings, and anterior tibialis

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting signs and symptoms of focal back pain and upper motoneuron signs are suggestive of epidural spinal cord compression, which often results from degenerative joint disease or metastatic disease. Metastatic disease frequently affects the vertebral column and may cause compression of the spinal cord by extending into the epidural space or by causing bony destruction and fracture of the vertebral bodies. Patients present with back pain, lower extremity weakness, loss of balance, urinary or bowel incontinence, or complete paralysis of the lower extremities. Early detection and treatment are crucial to prevent permanent spinal cord damage and myelopathy. Patients may benefit from short-term treatment with intravenous dexamethasone to decrease spinal cord edema, although definitive treatment often requires a combination of surgical decompression in the case of a bony structural lesion or chemotherapy, and/or radiotherapy in the case of malignancy.

distractor_explanations.C: , a loop diuretic, is useful for the treatment of hypervolemia such as in congestive heart failure or cirrhosis. Congestive heart failure does not commonly cause symptoms of myelopathy. Heparin (
distractor_explanations.D: is an anticoagulant and is useful for the treatment of deep venous thrombosis (DVT). While DVTs may cause lower .... r ~- - - , - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -- - - - - - r - - - -, -

Patients with epidural spinal cord compression present with back pain, lower extremity weakness, loss of balance, urinary or bowel incontinence, or paralysis of the lower extremities. .,.

vignette.presentation:
31. A 67-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of right facial weakness. She has hypertension
treated with lisinopril and hyperlipidemia treated with atorvastatin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Her pulse is 76/min,
and blood pressure is 168/90 mm Hg. Examination shows right facial weakness of the forehead and lower face. There is decreased hearing and
tinnitus on the right. Finger-nose testing shows mild ataxia on the right. An MRI of the brain is most likely to show an infarction in which of the
following areas?

question_stem:
most likely to show an infarction in which of the
following areas?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cerebral infarctions, also known as strokes, occur as a result of ischemic or hemorrhagic loss of blood supply to the brain. Approximately 80% to 85% of strokes are ischemic, commonly arising from thromboembolic disease (eg, middle cerebral artery occlusion from a thrombus), whereas 15% to 20% of strokes are hemorrhagic as a result of blood vessel rupture (eg, hypertension related intraparenchymal hemorrhage from a perforating artery). Risk factors for stroke include smoking, hypertension, diabetes, carotid or intracrania l atherosclerotic disease, history of hypercoagulability, atrial fibrillation, and advanced age. Classically, strokes manifest as a neurologic deficit related to the affected part of the brain. Infarction in the distribution of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery affects several cranial nerve nuclei within the pons, which together are referred to as the lateral pontine syndrome. Involvement of the facial nucleus leads to facial droop caused by muscle paralysis, decreased lacrimation, decreased salivation, and decreased taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Involvement of the vestibular nucleus causes vomiting, vertigo, and nystagmus. Involvement of the middle and inferior cerebellar peduncles will lead to ataxia and dysmetria. lpsilatera l Horner syndrome and contralateral pain and temperature sensation impairment, though not present in this patient, may also result.

distractor_explanations.B: causes either medial medullary syndrome, if the anterior spinal artery is affected, or lateral medullary syndrome, if the posterior inferior cerebellar artery is affected. In the former, the lateral corticospinal tract, medial lemniscus, and hypoglossal nerve are affected, leading to contralateral muscle weakness, contralateral impaired proprioception, and ipsilateral tongue deviation, respectively. vignette.presentation:
32. A 52-year-o ld man is brought to the emergency department from work 30 minutes after the sudden onset of blindness. He is unable to remember
all the events leading up to his visual loss, but he states that earlier in the day he saw his boss in a compromising position; he is uncomfortable
speaking about this and quickly changes the subject. He has not had any eye pain but says that he has a headache. He has a history of migraines
treated with sumatriptan. Ophthalmic examination shows no evidence of trauma, erythema, or infection. He flinches when the physician rapidly
raises her hand toward his face. Funduscopic examination shows no evidence of papilledema, optic neuritis, or retinal hemorrhage or detachment.
A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he appears unaffected by his vision loss. His speech is normal, and
he does not have any delusional behavior. When his wife arrives at the emergency department, he asks if he can go home and inquires about
when he can return to work. Which of the following is the most likely diagnos is?

question_stem: the most likely diagnos is?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurologic disorder, involves neurologic symptoms such as sensory or motor dysfunction that are not fully explained by objective findings on physical examination or imaging. This patient's flinching in response to a visual stimulus indicates a subconscious ability to see and makes a neurologic injury unlikely. Though the symptoms disrupt daily life, patients with functional neurologic disorder may or may not be preoccupied with their symptoms. Functiona l neurologic disorder is postulated to represent the subconscious conversion of intolerable emotional distress into physical symptoms as indicated by this patient quickly changing the subject when asked about a stressor. Psychiatric comorbidities such as depression are common but not present in all patients. Physicians should conduct a thorough history and physica l examination, and obtain laboratory and imaging studies to evaluate for medical or neurologic disease that may explain or partially explain the symptoms. Treatment of functiona l neurologic disorder involves education about the diagnosis, physical therapy, and cognitive-behavioral therapy.

distractor_explanations.A: refers to psychologica l stress responses (eg, dissociation, intrusive thoughts, depressed mood, avoidance, hyperarousa l) occurring within a month of a traumatic event. This patient's response to stress instead manifests as a neurologic symptom.

explanation.educational_objective: Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurologic disorder, involves neurologic symptoms such as sensory or motor dysfunction that are not fully explained by objective findings on physical examination or imaging. Functional neurologic disorder is postulated to represent the subconscious conversion of intolerable emotional distress into physical symptoms.

vignette.presentation:
33. A 72-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of a 24-hour history of severe right ear pain, drooping of the right side of her face, and
tearing of the right eye. She had a mild upper respiratory tract infection 1 week ago. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus currently treated with
glyburide. She is in distress. Her temperatu re is 37°C (98.6°F). Examination shows rotatory nystagmus on lateral gaze. There is severe palsy of
the right peripheral facial nerve with an inability to close the right eye. Examination shows a rash in the external auditory canal and hearing loss on
the right. There is no nuchal rigidity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

question_stem: the most likely cause of these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting signs and symptoms of unilateral facial nerve palsy, ear pain and rash, hearing loss, nystagmus , and tearing, are consistent with a diagnosis of Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also known as zoster oticus. Ramsay Hunt syndrome is caused by reactivation of a latent infection with herpes zoster virus within the geniculate ganglion. Viral reactivation within the geniculate ganglion leads to facial nerve palsy, which causes paralysis of the muscles of facial expression (including the forehead) and may cause lagophthalmos and corneal dryness. In addition, the proximity of the vestibulocochlear nerve to the geniculate ganglion increases the risk for its involvement, which causes a characteristic presentation of ear pain and vesicular rash of the external ear canal or auricle, and may also cause hearing loss, vertigo, and nystagmus. The diagnosis is clinical but may be confirmed with PCR amplification testing. Treatment includes oral prednisone and acyclovir.

In severe cases, it may cause subacute sclerosing panencepha litis. It does not typically cause facial or vestibulocochlear nerve palsy. Mucormycosis (
distractor_explanations.D: is caused by an invasive infection with fungal organisms such as Mucor or Rhizopus, and results in a ressive infections of the sinuses, nasal cavit , orbits, or lun s, rimaril in atients with a histor of immunocom romise e

explanation.educational_objective: Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also known as zoster oticus, is caused by reactivation of latent herpes zoster viral infection within the geniculate ganglion with subsequent cranial nerve palsy of the facial and vestibulocochlear nerves. Patients present with facial paralysis, lagophthalmos, exposure keratopathy, hearing loss, vertigo, nystagmus, and a vesicular rash of the external ear canal and auricle. Treatment is with oral prednisone and acyclovir. .,.

vignette.presentation:
34. A 47-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of a severe headache that began suddenly while she was
exercising at the gym. She rates her pain as a 10 on a 10-point scale and says it is present over her entire head. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus
controlled with metformin. She is 172 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (158 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2 . She is alert and oriented. Vital signs are within
normal limits. On examination, the right pupil is 5 mm and not reactive to light. Meningismus is present. The remainder of the examination,
including neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. The most likely cause of these findings is a lesion in which of the following arteries?

question_stem: The most likely cause of these findings is a lesion in which of the following arteries?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) refers to bleeding into the subarachnoid space. It most commonly occurs secondary to trauma, although aneurysmal rupture is the most common cause of nontraumatic SAH. Patients typically present with an acute, severe headache often described as the worst headache of their life, along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases. Aneurysms can occur at various locations within the intracranial vasculature. This patient presents with oculomotor nerve palsy, raising suspicion for a posterior communicating artery aneurysm. Oculomotor nerve palsy is a common presenting sign of a posterior communicating artery aneurysm because of its location and compression of the oculomotor nerve. The oculomotor nerve carries parasympathetic fibers allowing for pupillary constriction and motor fibers innervating the levator palpebrae superioris and several extraocular muscles. Patients with an oculomotor nerve palsy can present with pupillary dilation, ptosis, and extraocular muscle paresis leading to diplopia.

distractor_explanations.A: are connected by the anterior communicating artery, the most common site for aneurysms in the circle of Willis. Because of its location near the optic chiasm, it can cause visual field defects such as bitemporal hemianopsia. Basilar artery (
distractor_explanations.B: and middle cerebral artery (
distractor_explanations.C: aneurysms can also rupture and cause an acute headache, intracranial hemorrhage, and/or subarachnoid hemorrhage, but oculomotor nerve palsy would be atypical. Proximal internal carotid artery (
distractor_explanations.E: aneurysms within the neck are much less common than aneurysms of the posterior communicating artery. As well, aneurysmal rupture of the proximal internal carotid artery would not cause cranial nerve palsies, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or findings of meningismus. ....

Oculomotor nerve palsy is a common presenting sign of a posterior communicating artery aneurysm because of its location and compression of the oculomotor nerve. .,.

35. A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of difficulty walking and a tremor of the right arm. He says that his
movements have been slower. He has hypertension, schizophrenia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Current medications include
hydrochlorothiazide, fluphenazine, benztropine, and ranitidine. His blood pressure is 108/72 mm Hg. Examination shows increased muscle tone in
the right upper extremity; there is a resting tremor of the right hand and decreased right arm swing. His gait is short based. Mental status
examination shows a restricted affect. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's symptoms?

question_stem: most likely to improve this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Adding donepezil to the medication regimen
Adding risperidone to the medication regimen

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Fluphenazine, a first-generation antipsychotic medication, is a dopamine-2 (D ) receptor antagonist. By decreasing mesolimbic 2 dopamine signaling, fluphenazine treats the psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia. D antagonism in the basal ganglia can cause acute 2 dystonic reactions and parkinsonism, leading to this patient's bradykinesia (manifesting as a decreased right arm swing while walking), resting tremor, increased muscle tone, and postural instability (manifesting as a short, or shuffling, gait). The chronic use of antidopaminergic agents may also upregulate D receptors in the basal ganglia, leading to tardive dyskinesia. Management of 2 medication-induced parkinsonism typically involves adding an anticholinergic medication such as benztropine, which counteracts antidopaminergic activity and addresses parkinsonism. In this patient with schizophrenia already on an anticholinergic medication (benztropine ), the

distractor_explanations.C: is an anticholinergic medication that antagonizes muscarinic acetylcholine receptors in the central nervous system (CNS), modulating the dopamine-acetylcholine balance in the basal ganglia, and thus treats parkinsonism and acute dystonic reaction. An increase in cholinergic signaling through adding donepezil or discontinuing benztropine would not address this patient's parkinsonism (and in the case of discontinuing benztropine, would likely exacerbate parkinsonism). Risperidone (
distractor_explanations.B: is a second-generation antipsychotic that antagonizes the D receptor and modulates serotonin signaling. Of 2 the second-generation antipsychotics, risperidone demonstrates the most potent D antagonism and would likely exacerbate this 2 patient's parkinsonism. ....

To address drug-induced parkinsonism in patients with schizophrenia, anticholinergic medications should be added, or the offending medication should be discontinued in favor of an antipsychotic that causes less potent D receptor antagonism. 2 .,.

vignette.presentation:
36. A 25-year-o ld woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of depressed mood and episodes of daytime sleepiness despite getting
an adequate amount of sleep at night. She takes daily naps that are marked by visions of bloody bodies before she falls asleep or upon
awakening. She is frightened by these visions but cannot control her urge to sleep; she wakes up refreshed. She has smoked one pack of
cigarettes daily for 8 years and drinks one to two cups of coffee daily. She does not use illicit drugs. She is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs
75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2 . Her temperatu re is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Neurologic examination
shows no focal findings. Mental status examinat ion shows anxiety and a mildly depressed mood. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the
following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Narcolepsy is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with hypnagogic hallucinations and daytime somnolence. The pathogenesis of narcolepsy involves the loss of orexin-A and orexin-B, which are neurotransmitters found primarily in the hypothalamus that promote wakefulness and inhibit REM sleep. Loss of these neurotransmitters permits abnormal transition from wakefulness to REM sleep with the consequent development of hallucinations and other features of narcolepsy, including cataplexy and sleep paralysis. Diagnosis can be made in patients with daytime somnolence and cataplexy or, in cases where cataplexy is not present, with sleep latency testing, which shows a shorter time from wakefulness to the initiation of REM sleep. Occasionally patients undergo lumbar puncture to directly measure concentrations of orexin-A in the cerebrospinal fluid. Pharmacotherapy is directed as promoting wakefulness and avoiding cataplexy.

distractor_explanations.A: is characterized by hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech or behavior, or catatonia that lasts more than 1 day but less than a month and is not secondary to a mood disorder or substance abuse. Major depressive disorder (
distractor_explanations.B: is diagnosed when patients meet at least five of the nine criteria, including impaired sleep (either insomnia or hypersomnolence ), loss of interest, guilt, loss of energy, poor concentration, poor appetite, psychomotor retardation, or suicidal ideation. This patient does not meet the criteria. Nightmare disorder (
distractor_explanations.D: describes the presence of recurrent disturbing dreams. This disorder is not characterized by daytime .... r ~ - - -- -, - - - - - - -- - - - r,

explanation.educational_objective: Narcolepsy should be suspected in patients with daytime somnolence but restorative sleep with the concurrent presence of hypnagogic hallucinations or cataplexy. Diagnosis can be made clinically if cataplexy is present but otherwise requires sleep latency testing, which shows a shorter time from wakefulness to the initiation of REM sleep. .,.

vignette.presentation:
37. A 56-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after a simple partial seizure. A CT scan of the head shows a 1.5-cm,
uniformly and intensely enhancing parasag ittal mass in the left frontal region. Further evaluation for a primary lesion is negative. Examination
shows mild weakness of the right lower extremity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnos is?

question_stem: the most likely diagnos is?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Meningioma is a common, benign central nervous system (CNS) tumor derived from the meninges that occurs along the surfaces of the brain and spinal cord, often in the parasagittal region. They occur in women more often than men and are associated with neurofibromatosis 2 and multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 1. Patients may be asymptomatic, or they may experience seizures or focal neurologic deficits related to the tumor location. Meningiomas are typically benign but can be malignant. Malignant meningiomas may grow rapidly, leading to symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (postural headache, nausea, papilledema). Meningiomas appear as well-circumscribed, extra-axia l (outside of the brain parenchyma) masses that compress the underlying parenchyma. They demonstrate uniform enhancement on CT imaging. Definitive diagnosis requires histologic examination of the tissue, which will demonstrate spindle cells arranged in a whorled pattern with psammoma bodies. Treatment may include radiation and/or surgica l resection to alleviate the tumora l mass effect, if significant.

distractor_explanations.C: in adults. These highly malignant tumors appear as intra-axial masses in the cerebral hemispheres, which typically demonstrate areas of necrosis and can spread to the opposite hemisphere across the corpus callosum. Ependymoma (
distractor_explanations.B: is a CNS neoplasm formed from ependymal cells. Location typical ly involves the fourth ventricle. Histologic characteristics include perivascular pseudorosettes formed by malignant cells arranged around a blood vessel. Schwannoma (
distractor_explanations.E: are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells in peripheral nerve sheaths. They commonly affect the facial and vestibulococh lear nerves, and mass effect may result in sensorineural hearing loss or ataxia. They are associated with neurofibromatosis 2. - . .... r ~- - - ,- - - - - - - ' - - - - - -- - - - - - - - - - .. -- - - - - - - - -- - - -- - - - - - - - - -- - - - -- - - - - - - - -r- - , - - - - - - -

Neuroimaging typically demonstrates a spherica l and well-circumscribed uniformly enhancing mass that indents the parenchyma. .,.

vignette.presentation:
38. A 72-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation comes to the emerge ncy departme nt 2 hours after the sudden onset of visual problems. He
states that he was fine until this afternoon when he started walking into objects that were located on his right side. While driving himself to the
hospital, he sideswiped a parked car. His only medication is daily aspirin. On arrival, his pulse is 68/min and irregular, and blood pressure is
140/70 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows a right homonymous hemianopia. Pupils are equal and reactive, and funduscopic examination
shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength and sensation are normal. Mental status examination shows no abnormal ities. Which of the following
arteries is most likely to be occluded?

question_stem: most likely to be occluded?

choices.text: Left anterior cerebral H) Right internal carotid
Left internal carotid I) Right middle cerebral
Left middle cerebral J) Right ophthalmic
Left ophthalmic K) Right posterior cerebral

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cerebral infarctions, or strokes, occur as a result of ischemic or hemorrhagic loss of blood supply to the brain. Approximately 80% to 85% of strokes are ischemic, common ly arising from thromboembo lic disease, whereas 15% to 20% of strokes are hemorrhagic because of blood vessel rupture. Risk factors for stroke include smoking, hypertension, diabetes, carotid or intracranial atherosclerotic disease, history of hypercoagulability, atrial fibrillation, and advanced age. Classically, strokes manifest as a neurologic deficit related to the affected part of the brain. Occlusion of the left posterior cerebra l artery (PCA) explains this patient's deficits. The PCA supplies much of the occipita l lobes as well as the inferomedia l temporal lobe, posteromedia l parietal lobe, thalamus, and parts of the brainstem. Occlusion of the left PCA typically leads to right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing (as a result of damage of the left primary visual cortex). Right homonymous hemianopia likely explains this patient's car accident. Occlusion of the left PCA may also result in right hemisensory deficit (caused by thalamus damage) and right hemiparesis (caused by damage to the cerebral peduncles in the midbrain). As well, damage to the left parietal cortex may occur and lead to agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia, and left-right disorientation (Gerstmann syndrome).

vignette.presentation:
39. A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 14-day history of progressively severe headaches, mild neck soreness, and
photophobia. Twelve weeks ago, she was treated with x-ray radiation therapy and methotrexate, vincristine, procarbazine, and prednisone for
stage IVB Hodgkin disease with a large anterior mediastinal mass; the only complication of therapy was a brief episode of fever and neutropenia.
Her temperature now is 37.8°C (100°F). She does not appear acutely ill. Examination shows a mildly rigid neck. Neurologic examination shows no
papilledema. Lymph nodes, liver, and spleen are not palpable. Cardiopulmonary exam ination and x-rays of the chest show normal findings. Serum
glucose concentration is 70 mg/dL. Results of lumbar puncture show:
Glucose 15 mg/dL
Protein 120 mg/dL
Leukocyte count 500/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 10%
Monocytes 90%
Erythrocyte count 0/mm3
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Amphotericin B is the most appropriate therapy for Cryptococcus neoformans, which is an encapsulated, nondimorphic yeast and common opportunistic pathogen in immunocompromised patients. Malignancy (especially lymphoma or leukemia), HIV/AIDS, solid organ transplantation, sarcoidosis, cirrhosis, and chronic corticosteroid therapy are risk factors for infection. It can cause cryptococcal meningitis, encephalitis, and pulmonary cryptococcosis. Transmission is through inhalation, with risk for dissemination to the brain and meninges, as well as other distal sites. Pulmonary cryptococcosis typically presents with a low-grade, intermittent fever and nonspecific respiratory symptoms. Central nervous system involvement can cause headache, nuchal rigidity, photophobia, and progressive encephalopathy. Dermatologic spread can occur with pustular, papular, nodular, or ulcerated lesions. Diagnosis is made by analysis of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), sputum, urine, and/or blood. Histologic examination may show yeast cells with narrow-based budding and a bright red inner capsule on staining with mucicarmine or periodic acid-Schiff. In cryptococcal meningitis, lumbar puncture classically demonstrates an increased opening pressure, increased CSF protein, and a mononuclear cell pleocytosis. Amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for cryptococca l meningitis or severe pulmonary cryptococcosis in an immunocompromised patient.

distractor_explanations.A: is an opioid used to manage acute pain or postoperative shivering. It does not play a role in the management of cryptococcal meningitis. Intravenous ceftriaxone (
distractor_explanations.C: is utilized in the treatment of bacterial meningitis, along with vancomycin and, depending on patient age, ampicillin. Bacterial meningitis presents acutely with fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status in a toxic-appearing patient. While immunosuppressed patients are at risk for bacterial meningitis, this patient's subacute history of mild symptoms is more consistent with cryptococca l meningitis. Additionally, CSF analysis in bacterial meningitis would show a neutrophilic predominance. Intravenous methylprednisolone (
distractor_explanations.D: is used in the treatment of allergic or autoimmune reactions, multiple sclerosis exacerbations, and a variety of other conditions. Multiple sclerosis presents with various neurologic lesions occurring over varying periods of time, with an acute exacerbation defined as a new neurologic impairment associated with a new brain or spinal cord lesion on MRI. It does not typically present with signs of meningeal irritation. Additionally, CSF in multiple sclerosis consists of a lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal protein concentration, and the presence of oligoclonal bands. Intravenous penicillin G (
distractor_explanations.E: can be used to treat a variety of bacterial infections, including neurosyphilis, which can present with headache, altered mental status, vision changes, cranial neuropathies, progressive dementia, and possible brain gummas (eg, focal areas of inflammation). Arteritis can also occur, leading to brain ischemia and infarction. CSF evaluation will show a lymphocytic pleocytosis and increased protein concentration.

Cryptococcal meningitis presents subacutely with headache, nuchal rigidity, photophobia, and progressive encephalopathy. CSF analysis will demonstrate an increased opening pressure, increased protein, and a mononuclear cell pleocytosis. Treatment is with

vignette.presentation:
40. A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of moderate pain, numbness, and tingling in her right hand. She states
that the pain is worse at night and is not relieved with acetaminophen or ibuprofen. She has a 10-year history of chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto)
thyroiditis treated with thyroid hormone therapy. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, tapping the palmar surface of the right wrist
elicits a tingling sensation in the thumb and index fingers. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentratio n is 2 µU/ml. Which of the following
is the most likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

question_stem: the most likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Immunologic damage to the brachia! nerve
Immunologic damage to the median nerve
Immunologic damage to the radial nerve
Immunologic damage to the ulnar nerve
Mechanical entrapment of the brachia I nerve
Mechanical entrapment of the median nerve
Mechanical entrapment of the radial nerve
Mechanical entrapment of the ulnar nerve

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Mechanical entrapment of the median nerve leading to carpal tunnel syndrome is the most likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms. The carpal tunnel describes a conduit in the wrist that is formed by the flexor retinaculum anteriorly and the carpal bones posteriorly. Both the median nerve and the flexor tendons of the fingers travel through this canal. Increased pressure in this canal can lead to compression of the median nerve, resulting in paresthesias of the first three digits, primarily on the palmar surface. When severe, weakness of the thumb with atrophy of the thenar eminence may occur. The Tinel test involves tapping the volar surface of the wrist in the midline. A positive test, as in this case, leads to tingling in the first two digits and occasionally the third digit, which corresponds with the distribution of the median nerve. This condition occurs commonly in those with jobs that involve repetitive wrist movement such as typing, but it can be idiopathic. It commonly develops in obese patients and is more common in women. Nighttime symptoms are frequently encountered, and the initial treatment requires wrist splints worn at night. Refractory or severe symptoms may be referred for surgical intervention.

distractor_explanations.A: , median (
distractor_explanations.B: , radial (
distractor_explanations.C: , or ulnar (
distractor_explanations.D: nerves may occur in neuralgic amyotrophy, also called Parsonage-Turner syndrome, which is thought to be related to immune-mediated damage of the nerves of the brachia! plexus. It most commonly involves the nerves of the upper or middle brachia! plexus but can involve more distal, singular nerves. Patients develop debilitating pain and weakness that gradually improve over months. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Carpal tunnel syndrome commonly results from compression of the median nerve within the carpal tunnel, which is formed by the carpal bones and the flexor retinaculum. Symptoms include paresthesias of the first three digits of the affected hand. Treatment is initially with wrist splints, but surgical intervention and carpal tunnel release may be required in some cases. .,.

vignette.presentation:
41. After falling from a horse during a steeplechase, a 42-year-old man has immediate paralysis in all four extremities and has loss of sensation below
the clavicles bilaterally. On examination by paramedics , he is alert, dyspneic, and unable to move his extremities or trunk. His pulse is 98/min,
respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. After transport to a trauma center, his sensory examination returns to normal, and
he regains normal strength of the arms and forearms, although the hands and lower extremities remain weak. Examination shows bladder
distention. An MRI of the cervical spine shows contusion with edema of the spinal cord at C3 and C4. Plain x-rays of the cervical spine show a
nondisplaced fracture of the vertebral body of C3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Spinal cord compression can occur in the setting of trauma, malignancy with vertebral metastases, and infections (eg, epidural abscess). Its presentation depends on the level of the lesion and the degree of spinal cord compression. Traumatic spinal cord injury is typically caused by fracture or dislocation of the vertebrae. Acute traumatic spinal cord injuries typically cause immediate compression or shearing of the spinal cord, with a secondary injury of the spinal cord occurring after the initial injury because of consequent inflammation, edema, and ischemia. Symptoms include back or neck pain, flaccid paralysis, numbness, bowel and bladder incontinence or retention, and hyporeflexia. Patients may also develop neurogenic shock, depending on the level of injury, with bradycardia and hypotension secondary to injury to the sympathetic outflow tract, as well as respiratory failure caused by diaphragmatic paralysis. Diagnosis is classically made using MRI of the spine, as well as spinal x-rays or CT to visualize skeletal abnormalities. Management includes clinical stabilization, and the use of intravenous glucocorticoid therapy to decrease spinal cord edema. Patients may also require intubation and mechanical ventilation, vasopressor support, cardiac pacing, and/or surgical spine stabilization.

42. A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after he was found in a state of confusion outside a convenience store. He
says he feels anxious. He has not had fever, headache, abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. He has a 3-year history of uncontrolled
hypertension. He has no allergies and takes no medications. He does not smoke. He usually drinks 12 to 14 beers daily. He says he has never
used illicit drugs. He is disheveled and agitated and picks at imaginary things in the air. He is disoriented to person, place, and time. His
temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 160/105 mm Hg. Examination shows diaphoresis and tremulousness.
There is seborrhea and rosacea of the face. There are no signs of head trauma. The neck is supple. There is diffuse hyperreflexia. Babinski sign is
absent bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient has developed delirium tremens, a serious complication of alcohol withdrawal. Alcohol increases the central nervous system activity of y-aminobutyric acid (GABA), the main inhibitory neurotransmitter. Abrupt discontinuation of alcohol therefore leads to sympathetic overdrive. Uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal typically presents with tremors, anxiety, restlessness, diffuse hyperreflexia, headache, nausea, and diaphoresis, which can occur hours after the cessation of alcohol use. Delirium tremens, the most concerning and life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal, involves severe confusion and disorientation, fluctuations in consciousness, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability (variable heart rate and blood pressure with hyperthermia). Delirium tremens typically begins 2 to 5 days after the patient's last alcoholic drink. Delirium tremens is managed supportively with benzodiazepines (GABAA receptor agonists) to address the psychomotor agitation associated with withdrawal and prevent the worsening of withdrawal manifestations. Management also includes fluid resuscitation, nutritional supplementation, and frequent assessment including vital sign checks.

distractor_explanations.A: refers to bleeding between the dura and arachnoid membranes, most commonly caused by head trauma in elderly patients and persons with alcohol use disorder. Patients typically present with a declining neurologic status or coma. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Delirium tremens is a life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal related to decreased GABA activity that presents with severe confusion, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instability along with other features of sympathetic overdrive (eg, diaphoresis, tremors, diffuse hyperreflexia). Benzodiazepines are GABAA receptor agonists utilized to treat agitation during withdrawal and prevent the worsening of withdrawal manifestations.
explanation.concept: Delirium tremens is a life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal related to decreased GABA activity that presents with severe confusion, agitation, visual hallucinations, and autonomic instab

areas on the chest and flexor surfaces of the upper and lower extremities. A CT scan of the head shows a subependyma l calcification near the

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder characterized by benign tumors in several organ systems. Hamartomas can form in the soft tissue (leading to Shagreen patches, or subcutaneous oval nodules) or brain (leading to epilepsy and intellectua l disability). Cardiac rhabdomyomas (leading to mitral regurgitation) and renal angiomyolipomas are also common. Other typical dermatologic findings include ash leaf spots (hypomelanotic macules) and angiofibromas, which are acneiform lesions without comedones (clogged hair follicles). Subependymal giant cell tumors are common, which typically demonstrate calcification and may increase the likelihood of developing seizures. Though these tumors are benign, patients are at risk for developing malignancies in the soft tissues, brain, or kidney. Diagnosis is typically clinical but may be confirmed by genetic testing indicating a mutated TSC gene. Management requires anticonvulsant medication for seizures and surgica l resection of rapidly growing or symptomatic tumors.

Adults can rarely demonstrate an idiopathic increase in vitamin D and consequen tly become hypercalcemic. Neither variant is hereditary nor associated with dermatologic findings. Neurofibromatosis (
distractor_explanations.B: is a hereditary neurocutaneous disorder. Type 1 presents with cutaneous neurofibromas (benign neoplasms derived from neural crest cells), cafe au lait spots, pigmented iris hamartomas (Lisch nodules), optic gliomas, and pheochromocytomas. Type 2 presents with cutaneous neurofibromas, bilateral vestibular schwannomas, additional schwannomas of the cranial nerves or in the spinal cord, intracranial meningiomas, and neuropathy. Subependymal brain lesions are atypical, and the dermatologic findings differ between tuberous sclerosis and neurofibromatosis. Sturge-Weber syndrome (

Patients typically present with hamartomas of the skin and brain, cardiac rhabdomyomas, and renal angiomyolipomas. Dermatologic findings include hypomelanotic macules (ash leaf spots) and acneiform lesions called angiofibromas, and neurologic findings include subependymal giant cell tumors, which may lead to seizures.

44. A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive difficulty climbing stairs, generalized muscle pain, and dry
mouth. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia . Current medications include atorvastatin, atenolol, and glyburide. He
has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. At his last visit 6 weeks ago, an x-ray of the chest showed a solitary lung nodule. Today, his
pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 136/82 mm Hg. Examination of the lower extremities shows bilateral proximal
weakness and hyporeflexia. Electromyography and nerve conduction studies show an incremental increase in the amplitude of evoked motor
response. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented these symptoms?

question_stem: most likely to have prevented these symptoms?

choices.text: More aggressive treatment of high blood pressure
More aggressive treatment of high blood pressure

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is an uncommon neurologic condition that affects neuromuscu lar junction transmission. Normally, action potentials lead to depolarization in the terminal bouton of the axon. Voltage-gated calcium channels consequently open and allow calcium influx, which triggers the exocytosis of neurotransmitter-filled vesicles into the synaptic cleft. Patients with LEMS possess antibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels on presynaptic lower motoneurons, which decreases calcium influx and the subsequent release of acetylcholine. This patient with a smoking history and proximal muscle weakness, with a known lung nodule, likely has paraneoplastic autoantibody production against voltage-gated calcium channels, causing LEMS in the setting of small cell lung cancer. Patients may also have depressed or absent deep tendon reflexes. The muscle weakness typically improves with exercise as small amounts of acetylcholine accumulate in the synaptic cleft over time, increasing the frequency of postsynaptic action potentials in skeletal muscle cells. This can be seen on nerve conduction studies, as well. Autonomic symptoms such as decreased salivation (and consequent dry mouth) may also occur. The diagnosis may be confirmed with nerve conduction studies and electromyography with exercise testing. In this patient, smoking cessation would have prevented the development of lung cancer and consequent LEMS.

distractor_explanations.D: would not have prevented this patient from developing lung cancer and subsequent LEMS. While ~-adrenergic blocker therapy can cause fatigue and statin therapy can cause myopathy, neither causes hyporeflexia. ....

explanation.educational_objective: Patients with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome possess antibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels on presynaptic lower motoneurons, which decrease calcium influx and acetylcholine release. This syndrome can be caused by paraneoplastic antibodies, particularly in the setting of small cell lung cancer, which is smoking-re lated. Patients typically present with progressive proximal muscle weakness that improves with exercise or repeated stimulation. .,.
